questions.text: Identify the most common complication of a celiac plexus block.
questions.solution:
The most common complication of a celiac plexus block is postural hypotension.

This occurs due to the resultant blockade of the lumbar sympathetic chain and the dilation of capacitance vessels in the splanchnic area. Therefore, patients should be adequately hydrated intravenously prior to this procedure and precautions should be taken to minimize the risk of orthostatic lightheadedness or syncope.

The celiac ganglia are found at the level of the body of the L1 vertebra. They are located lateral to the aorta, and posterior to the vena cava and the pancreas.

It is preferred when patients have pain originating from the abdominal viscera, as seen in intra-abdominal cancers.

Due to its proximity to the vena cava, accidental intravascular injection into the vena cava can occur, which can produce a severe systemic reaction. Damage to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes can result in chylothorax. Blocking the sympathetic chain leads to increased gastrointestinal motility due to unopposed parasympathetic activity, resulting in diarrhea.

It may lead to other complications such as pneumothorax, injury to the kidneys or pancreas, hemorrhage, sexual dysfunction, paraplegia due to injury to the lumbar artery of Adamkiewicz, and back pain.

questions.text: During the post-mortem examination of a patient who had a sudden cardiac death, significant hypertrophy in the apex of the heart was noted. Which of the following structures representing the chambers of the heart depict this apical enlargement?
questions.solution:
The chamber of the heart marked 3 depicting the left ventricle correctly represents the apex of the heart where hypertrophy was seen in the post-mortem finding.

The apex of the heart is the blunt round extremity of the heart formed by the left ventricle. The obtuse margin of this chamber mainly forms the left surface of the heart. It is directed anteroinferiorly and to the left side. It is overlapped by the left lung and the pleura. The apex is commonly located behind the fifth left intercostal space, near or medial to the midclavicular line. It also forms the inferior and diaphragmatic surface of the heart. 

Other options:

Option A: Arrow 4 depicts the left atrium. It forms the cardiac base of the heart, a quadrilateral area directed posteriorly.

Option B: Arrow 2 depicts the right ventricle, the inferior border of the heart. 

Option D: Arrow 1 depicts the right atrium. It is the right surface of the heart, also forming the anterior, and sternocostal boundaries. 

A specimen of the heart with the various parts labeled is given below:

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient on oral contraceptive pills presents with complaints of abdominal pain for the past few days. She is evaluated further. Which of the following tumor is most likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
The female patient with oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) usage and with complaints of abdominal pain is most likely to be associated with hepatic adenoma. It is the most frequent hepatic tumor in young women on oral contraceptive pills.

Hepatic adenoma

These are benign liver tumors seen in women aged 25 and 50 years. The lesions are solitary, well-defined, and vascular. They are found incidentally but can present in some cases with pain due to rupture or bleeding. They have malignant potential. Large hepatic adenomas are at an increased risk of rupture and intraperitoneal hemorrhage. Surgical excision is recommended if lesions are >5 cm.

Other options:

Option A: Hepatocellular carcinoma is one of the primary liver malignancies. Chronic hepatitis B infection and hepatitis C are considered risk factors. The cause of death in 60 percent of cases is related to cancer while the rest is due to an underlying pathology. Surgical resection is considered a treatment in patients with preserved liver function.

Option B: Focular nodular hyperplasia is a benign condition with an unknown etiology. It is usually seen in middle-aged women. It doesn't have any malignant potential and therefore there is no need for treatment or follow-up after confirming the diagnosis.

Option D: Hemangiomas are the most common liver lesions and they can rupture. Diagnosis is incidental and surgical resection is needed if the patient is significantly symptomatic or there is uncertainty in diagnosis.

Hepatic adenoma on CT scan is shown below.

 

Hepatocellular carcinoma on CT scan is shown below:

 

Liver hemangioma on CT scan is shown below:

Related Pearl: Liver tumors - commons

  • Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor
  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with acidity and abdominal pain for the past few months, not relieved by taking antacids. Endoscopy revealed prominent gastric folds and ulcers on the second part of the duodenum. Investigations revealed elevated serum gastrin levels and increased basal acid secretion. Which of the following is the next best investigation?

choices.text: Endoscopic ultrasound guided deep gastric biopsy
Blood gastrin levels following secretin administration
Monoclonal antibody-based H. pylori stool antigen test
Double contrast barium study of proximal  GI tract

questions.solution:
The presence of peptic ulcers and poor response to antacids, together with elevated serum gastrin levels and increased basal acid secretion are suggestive of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. The next best investigation to confirm the diagnosis is to perform a secretin stimulation test.

In normal individuals, the administration of secretin causes no change or a slight decrease in blood gastrin levels. However, in patients with ZE syndrome, the circulating gastrin levels paradoxically increase following secretin administration.

Other investigations include:

  • Tumor localization and staging using a combination of CT and endoscopic ultrasound
  • Radio-labeled somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • 68gallium DOTATATE PET scanning

Other options:

Option A: Endoscopic ultrasound-guided deep gastric biopsy is usually done to diagnose infiltrating gastric tumours such as linitis plastica (GLP) and gastric lymphoma.

Options C and D: Monoclonal antibody-based H pylori stool antigen test and double-contrast barium study of proximal GI tract are the tests indicated for the diagnostic evaluation of H. pylori peptic ulcer disease.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl, who is yet to attain her menarche, presents with an ovarian mass. Her serum biomarkers are normal except for elevated AFP. Staging laparotomy was performed and the histopathological image is given below. What is your diagnosis?

AFP- Alpha-fetoprotein
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the histopathological image showing Schiller-Duval bodies is suggestive of a yolk sac tumor/ endodermal sinus tumor.

Yolk sac tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. The tumors are solid masses that are yellow in color and hemorrhagic in nature. Schiller Duval bodies are pathognomonic findings that consist of a central capillary that is surrounded by tumor cells within a cystic area of the tumor. Alpha-fetoprotein is elevated. There is also the presence of intracellular and extracellular hyaline droplets. Clinical features typically include abdominal pain with a rapidly growing abdominal mass. 

Other options:

Option B: Dysgerminoma are the ovarian counterpart of seminoma. They are unilateral tumors composed of vesicular cells and clear cytoplasm. These tumor cells grow in sheets or cords and are infiltrated by lymphocytes. These cords are separated by scanty fibrous stroma. 

Option C: Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. Numerous signet-ring cells are seen in the Krukenberg tumor. Signet ring cells are mucin producing cells with an appearance of signet ring often originating from the gastric mucosa.

 

Option D: Granulosa cell tumors arise from granulosa cells which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. The image below shows the presence of Call- Exner bodies seen in granulosa cell tumor. These are glandlike small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: Given is the cadaveric specimen of the lateral compartment of the leg. Dissecting the structure marked 'X' would affect which of the following action(s)?

choices.text: Eversion of foot and plantar flexion of ankle
Eversion of foot and dorsiflexion of ankle

questions.solution:
The marked structure 'X' is the peroneus longus muscle seen in the lateral compartment of the leg and dissection of this leads to loss of eversion of the foot and plantar flexion of the ankle.

Peroneus longus is the muscle of the lateral compartment of the leg, lying superficial to the peroneus brevis. It arises from the head and superior 2/3rd of the lateral surface of the fibula.

The common peroneal nerve passes between the gap from their origin. They travel obliquely and lie in close proximity to the common synovial sheath of the ankle. Thus, dislocation of this muscle can be caused by the rupture of the fibular retinaculum. They distally terminate by attaching to the base of the 1st metatarsal and cuneiform bone. It is innervated by the superficial peroneal nerve (L5, S1). 

The peroneus longus is the principal evertor of the foot at the subtalar joint and weak plantar flexors of the ankle. Due to the angle at which it crosses the sole of the foot, it plays an important role in maintaining the longitudinal and transverse arches. It also maintains the concavity of the foot during tip­toeing. 

 

The given cadaveric image showing other labeled structures are - 

 

Other options - 

Option A: Inversion of the foot is carried out by the tibialis anterior, tibialis posterior, and the gastrocnemius-soleus complex via the calcaneal tendon. There is also a contribution from the extrinsic flexors of the toes.

Option B: Eversion of the foot is carried out by fibularis longus, fibularis brevis, and fibularis tertius along with the extrinsic extensors of the toes.

Option D: Eversion of the foot and dorsiflexion of the ankle are carried out by the peroneus tertius, the muscle of the anterior compartment of the leg. Tibialis anterior, main foot dorsiflexor causes inversion of the foot.

questions.text: A 29-week pregnant woman, who was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia, was prescribed oral iron tablets. However, she is unable to comply as she develops epigastric pain, increased vomiting, and constipation on taking this tablet. Which of the following iron preparations can be given in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Iron sucrose is the iron preparation to be given to a pregnant woman with intolerance to oral iron therapy. 

Iron sucrose is the parenteral iron formulation. Other parenteral iron preparations are iron dextran, sodium ferric gluconate, ferumoxytol, and ferric carboxymaltose. Indications of parenteral iron therapy are:

  • Iron malabsorption (sprue, short bowel syndrome)
  • Severe oral iron intolerance
  • Unresponsive to oral iron therapy
  • In patients who are receiving erythropoietin

Iron sucrose is given intravenously and gets split into iron and sucrose by macrophages. The increase in hemoglobin is equivalent to that of the oral iron formulations. The main adverse events of parenteral formulations include hypersensitivity reactions, headache, arthralgia, and urticaria. The patients should be monitored to avoid iron overload.

Other options:

All the other options are examples of oral iron preparations. Common adverse effects include nausea, epigastric discomfort, diarrhea, or constipation.

questions.text: During the normal delivery of a primigravida with polyhydramnios, an intern prematurely attempts to remove the placenta, leading to profuse bleeding. Examination reveals that the placenta is still partly attached and that the uterus is partly outside the introitus. The patient is in hemorrhagic shock, so initial resuscitative measures are taken. What is the appropriate management in this situation among the following options?

choices.text: Manual repositioning of the uterus alone
Attempt repositioning and administer a trial of tocolytics

questions.solution:
The patient is diagnosed with uterine inversion with the placenta still attached and the appropriate management in this condition is to attempt repositioning of the uterus and administer a trial of tocolytics.

The given clinical scenario of hemorrhagic shock after attempts of forceful removal of the placenta is suggestive of uterine inversion. It is a hemorrhagic complication encountered in the puerperium. Polyhydramnios in this patient contribute to uterine atony.

Risk factors for uterine inversion include:

  • Fundal attachment of the placenta
  • Uterine atony
  • Attempts at cord traction before placental delivery
  • Adherent placenta

There are 3 degrees of uterine inversion:

  • First-degree - the fundus of the uterus inverts into the uterine cavity
  • Second-degree - the uterine fundus protrudes through the cervix and lies in the vagina
  • Third-degree -  the whole of the uterus is inverted and protrudes through the introitus

Since uterine inversion presents with profuse bleeding and a severe degree of shock, it requires prompt diagnosis and management. Management includes:

  • Call for help and arrange blood products.
  • Evaluate for general anaesthesia.
  • Administer rapid crystalloid infusion through a large-bore IV cannula.
  • If the placenta has separated and the uterus recently inverted - The uterus is replaced by manually pushing up on the fundus with the palm and fingers in the direction of the long axis of the vagina.
  • If the placenta is still attached-
    • Attempt repositioning and administering a trial of tocolytics (Option C). This trial of tocolytics helps in uterine relaxation and also repositioning of the uterus. Terbutaline, magnesium sulfate, or nitroglycerin may be used. Once the uterus is repositioned, the placenta is removed manually. 
    • In case the attempt to reposition fails, the placenta is peeled off and once again uterine repositioning is attempted. Once the anatomy is restored, tocolytics are withheld and ureterotonic agents are started. Manual pressure (Bimanual compression) is applied. (Option B)
  • A Bakri balloon is used to maintain the repositioned uterus. (Option D)
  • If repositioning fails, Surgical intervention(laparotomy) is indicated.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man was admitted with a large wound on his leg for the past 3 months. Cultures from the wound margin revealed an MRSA infection. He was given linezolid. What is the mechanism of action of the above drug?

MRSA- Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus

choices.text: Binds to 30s subunit and inhibits protein synthesis
Binds to 50s subunit and inhibits protein synthesis
Disrupts the structure of cell membrane

questions.solution:
The drug linezolid binds to the P site of the 50s ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. It is an oxazolidinone that is active against various gram-positive organisms including methicillin-resistant staphylococci, and vancomycin-resistant staphylococci. 

Staphylococci become resistant by acquiring penicillin-binding protein (PBP) to become methicillin-resistant staphylococci. 

Linezolid and tedizolid are FDA-approved for the treatment of skin and soft tissue infections caused by streptococci and staphylococcus aureus (MSSA and MRSA). Linezolid is also approved for the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia due to S. pneumoniae and nosocomial pneumonia due to S. aureus.

Adverse effects include:

  • myelosuppression (anemia, leukopenia, pancytopenia)
  • thrombocytopenia (most common side effect)
  • serotonin syndrome if given along with serotonergic drugs due to monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibition
  • peripheral neuropathy, optic neuropathy, lactic acidosis

Other options:

Option A - Aminoglycoside antibiotics act by binding to the 30s ribosome and interfere with the initiation of protein synthesis. These bactericidal agents are mainly used to treat gram-negative bacterial infections. Ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity, and neuromuscular blockade are the most important adverse effects.

 Option C- Polymyxins act by interacting with the phospholipids and disrupting the structure of the cell membrane. It can be used systemically for bacteremia, pneumonia, bone/joint infections, burns, cellulitis, cystic fibrosis, endocarditis, gynecologic infections, meningitis, and ventriculitis. Polymyxin B is used topically for corneal ulcers, and eye and skin infections. Side effects include dose-related nephrotoxicity, muscle weakness, vertigo, and slurring of speech.

Option D - Glycopeptides inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding with D-alanyl-D-alanine and the class originator drug is vancomycin. It is used in the treatment of MRSA, clostridium difficile, meningitis and staphylococcal endocarditis. Redman syndrome (erythema, flushing, tachycardia and hypotension), ototoxicity, and nephrotoxicity are the most important adverse effects.

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

50s subunit binding:

  • C: Chloramphenicol, Clindamycin
  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman is being evaluated for ovulation function. Which of the following is seen after the ovulation has occurred?

LH- Luteinizing hormone

choices.text: Growth of ovarian follicles seen on USG

questions.solution:
An increase in basal body temperature is seen after ovulation has occurred.

The basal body temperature (BBT) decreases by around 1/2°F at the time of ovulation and then increases by 1/2-1°F during the progestational half of the cycle. This occurs due to the thermogenic action of the hormone progesterone. When this is represented graphically, a biphasic pattern is observed and is strongly predictive of ovulation, as shown in the image below.

 

However, this method cannot accurately predict ovulation. It provides a retrospective diagnosis of ovulation and is not useful therapeutically.

Other options:

Option A:  Urinary LH peak (increase in LH) is usually seen 1 day prior to ovulation and is used to predict the time of ovulation. It is detected by daily monitoring of urinary LH levels and spans for about 48-50 hours.

Option C: Growth of ovarian follicles is seen on USG prior to ovulation. The follicle is observed to grow at the rate of 1-2 mm per day before follicular rupture, and ovulation occurs when it is 20 mm or more in size. This is a reliable and safe method of predicting ovulation.

Option D: The appearance of a fern pattern is seen before ovulation. After ovulation, the progesterone thickens the cervical mucus, leading to the loss of fern pattern.

Positive fern test as seen before ovulation is shown in the image below.

questions.text: According to the Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcome (KDIGO) classification of chronic kidney disease (CKD), end-stage renal disease is defined when the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) falls into which of the following categories?
questions.solution:
When GFR is less than 15 mL/min, it is classified as end stage renal disease.

End stage renal disease represents stage 5 of chronic kidney disease. It is characterized by accumulation of toxins and electrolytes which is normally excreted in the urine. GFR and urine output is severely compromised in this stage and patient is usually dependent on dialysis to improve renal functioning. 

Stages of Chronic Kidney Disease
Stage GFR(ml/min/1.73sq.mt) Description
G1 ≥90 Normal or increased GFR with laboratory evidence of kidney damage. Patient is asymptomatic
G2 60-89 Slight decrease in GFR, with laboratory evidence of kidney damage. 
G3A 45-59 Moderate decrease in GFR with clinical and laboratory evidence of kidney damage. Onset of anaemia
G3B 30-44
G4 15-29 Severe decrease in GFR, with or without other evidence of kidney damage. Prominent anaemia
G5 <15 Established renal failure, along with uremic syndrome.

questions.text: A small scale dairy owner follows a pasteurization technique of heating the milk at 63°C for 30 minutes and subsequently cooling it very quickly to 13°C. Which of the following organisms can survive this method of pasteurization?
questions.solution:
Coxiella burnetti can survive this method of pasteurization.

The pasteurization technique described in the above question is the Holder method. This method involves heating milk at 63°C for 30 minutes following which the milk is quickly cooled to 13°C or lower.

Although this method can destroy spore-forming bacteria including Mycobacteria, Brucella, and Salmonella, Coxiella burnetti can survive this method of pasteurization as a result of being relatively resistant to heat.

Consumption of milk infected with Coxiella burnetti can give rise to Q-fever that can be acute or chronic. Acute disease resembles influenza, atypical pneumonia and hepatitis while chronic Q-fever manifests as infective endocarditis and can last for over 6 months.

To prevent this, the high-temperature, short-time pasteurization technique of heating milk to 71.5°C for 15 seconds called the flash process, is better suited to destroy viable Coxiella species.

questions.text: A young soccer player presents with complaints of pain in his right shoulder. He fell while alternating from jumping jacks to push-ups during a warm-up drill. His shoulder's radiograph is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the light bulb sign in the X-ray is suggestive of a posterior dislocation of the shoulder.

It occurs most commonly during a convulsion, or after an electric shock. It can also happen after a fall on the flexed, adducted arm, either by a direct blow to the front of the shoulder or due to a fall on the outstretched hand. 

There is internal rotation of humeral head which causes changes to the normal radiographic contour of the head of the humerus. 

Radiological signs described in posterior dislocation of the shoulder in the AP view are as follows:

  • Light bulb sign - Shape of humeral head appears like that of an electric bulb
  • Rim sign - Widening of the glenohumeral joint space > 6 mm
  • Vacant glenoid sign - Glenoid fossa looks empty as the humeral head has moved away from it
  • Trough sign - Vertical line seen on the anteromedial part of the humeral head due to the impression fracture by the glenoid labrum

questions.text:
Which of the following measures are followed under NVBDCP (National vector-borne disease control program) to eliminate kala-azar?

1. Mosquito net

2. rK39 rapid diagnostic kits 

3. Mass immunization

4. Spraying pyrethroid

5. Insecticide-treated mosquito net
questions.solution:
Among the given options rK39 rapid diagnostic kits and spraying with insecticides such as pyrethroid are used to eliminate kala-azar under NVBDCP.

National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) is a national health program that comes under the ministry of health and family welfare headed by the director-general of health services (DGHS). It works for the prevention and control of the following vector-borne diseases:

  • Malaria
  • Chikungunya
  • Dengue
  • Filariasis
  • Japanese encephalitis
  • Kala-azar 

Strategies for prevention and control of Kala-azar under NVBDCP:

  • Enhanced case detection through the introduction of rK39 rapid diagnostic kits (Statement 2)
  • Complete treatment by oral drug Miltefosine. 
  • Interruption of transmission through vector(sandfly) control by spraying/fogging with insecticides such as synthetic pyrethroid (Statement 4)
  • Incentives to:
    • ASHAs as Rs. 300 for identifying each case of kala-azar, Rs. 100 for ensuring one round, and Rs. 200 for two rounds of insecticide spraying. 
    • The patient being treated in the hospital as Rs. 500 for compensation of daily wage for the time he spends in the hospital during the treatment for kala-azar and Rs. 2,000 for PKDL.

Other options:

Statements 1 & 5: Distribution of mosquito nets is done to control mosquito-borne diseases and not kala-azar. Kala-azar is transmitted by the sand flies which are much smaller than mosquitoes and therefore can pass through smaller holes in the bed net.

Statement 3: There is no available vaccine for kala-azar and hence mass immunization is not used in the control of kala-azar.

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

questions.text: A woman at 20 weeks of gestation has come for regular follow-up. Which cardiovascular changes listed below should you expect to find in this woman?
questions.solution:
The cardiovascular change that would be found in this normal patient is lateral displacement of the apical impulse. 

Cardiac functional changes become apparent in the first eight weeks of gestation. Lateral displacement of the apical impulse occurs due to progressive elevation of the diaphragm. This leads to a larger cardiac shadow on radiographs.

At apical or pulmonary area, systolic murmur may be heard due to decreased blood viscosity and torsion of great vessels. Mammary murmur is a continuous hissing sound heard over the tricuspid area in the left second and third intercostal spaces.

Other options:

All the other options are pathological changes.

Option A: Mid-diastolic and late diastolic murmurs can be seen in conditions like mitral stenosis. 

Option B: Pansystolic murmur can be seen in conditions like chronic mitral regurgitation and ventricular septal defect. 

Option C: Bradycardia in pregnancy can be seen in conditions like maternal complete heart block and cardiac pacemaker users.

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient complaints of fatigue and recurrent infections. He also notes epistaxis, visual disturbances and peripheral neuropathy. Peripheral smear shows rouleaux formation and marrow biopsy shows Dutcher bodies. Coomb's test is also positive. Which of the following malignancies does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
The malignancy that the patient most likely has is Waldenström's macroglobulinemia.

Waldenström macroglobulinemia is a neoplasm of small lymphocytes and a variable number of IgM-secreting plasma cells. It occurs in older adults. It most commonly occurs in association with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. It can also be associated with viral infections.

It occurs due to MYD88 L265P somatic mutation. Diffuse marrow infiltration by plasma cells, plasmacytoid lymphocytes, and lymphocytes (all from the same clone) is observed. Normocytic normochromic anaemia is seen with rouleaux formation. Coomb's test is positive. Cells do not form tumor masses or produce lytic lesions. There is hyperviscocity of blood.

Clinical features include lymphadenopathy, hyperviscosity of blood, hepatosplenomegaly, epistaxis, transient paresis, visual disturbance and other non specific symptoms like headache, dizziness, and weakness.

Investigations typically reveal increased levels of IgM. Lymphocytes commonly contain Dutcher bodies (intranuclear inclusions). Bence–Jones proteins are found in 20–30%. Coomb's test is positive. M’ or monoclonal spike is seen. Treatment is usually required when the patient is symptomatic and the preferred drug is ibrutinib. Other first-line drugs include rituximab and bortezomib.

Other options:

Option A: Diffuse large B cell lymphoma is characterized by the presence of large B cells with vesicular chromatin and distinct nucleoli.

Option B: Burkitt's lymphoma is characterized by a starry sky appearance due to the spread of reactive macrophages around the tumor cells against the background of pale cytoplasm. 

Option C: Follicular lymphoma - This is characterized by nodules of varying size with a cleaved nucleus and is composed of lymphocytes.

questions.text:
The lipid profile of a 48-year-old hypertensive male patient is given below. Which of the following antihypertensives would have a beneficial effect on his lipid profile?

Total cholesterol - 320 mg/dL

Low-density lipoproteins - 220 mg/dL

High-density lipoproteins- 40 mg/dL

Triglycerides - 299 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The patient in the given scenario has a deranged lipid profile. Among the given drugs, prazosin would have a beneficial effect on the lipid profile of this patient as it decreases LDL and triglyceride levels as well as increases HDL levels.

Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 antagonist. It acts by blocking the alpha-1 receptors in the arterioles and veins, thereby decreasing peripheral vascular resistance. It has little or no alpha-2 blocking effect.

Uses:

  • Hypertension
  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia
  • In vasospastic disorders like Raynaud's disease

Adverse effects: First-dose phenomenon: Within 30-90 minutes of the initial dose of prazosin or when the dosage is increased, there is marked orthostatic hypotension or syncope. This is known as the first-dose phenomenon. After a few initial doses, tolerance develops to this side effect. Initiating low doses at bedtime is recommended to minimize this phenomenon. Orthostatic hypotension can be a problem with long-term therapy. Other side effects are headache, dizziness, and asthenia.

Other options:

Options A and D- Furosemide and hydrochlorothiazide are diuretics, and they cause derangement of lipid profile.

Option C- Propranolol, being a non-selective beta-blocker, causes derangement of the lipid profile. The release of free fatty acids from the adipose tissue is attenuated in the presence of a non-selective beta-blocker. Non-selective receptor antagonists raise triglycerides, lower HDL cholesterol, and raise LDL cholesterol.

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her 2-month-old baby saying that her baby defecates after every feed. This reflex is called as
questions.solution:
The reflex given in the clinical scenario is a gastrocolic reflex. In this reflex, distension of the stomach by food results in the evacuation of the colon. This reflex is mainly transmitted by the autonomic nervous system through prevertebral sympathetic ganglia.

Other options:

Option A- When food leaves the stomach, the passage of chyme through the ileocecal valve increases due to vigorous peristalsis. This forces the chyme into the cecum. This is called gastroileal reflex.

Option B- Entry of food into the small intestine and colon results in the inhibition of gastric motility and gastric secretions. This is called enterogastric reflex.

Option C- Entry of chyme into the colon results in the inhibition of emptying of ileal contents into the colon. This is called colonoileal reflex.

questions.text:
An elderly male patient presented with fever, rigors, and dysuria. On per-rectal examination, his prostate was tender and swollen. His PSA level was 7.4 ng/dl. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

PSA- Prostate specific antigen
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever and dysuria with a tender and swollen prostate, along with elevated levels of PSA suggests a diagnosis of acute bacterial prostatitis. It should be managed with antibiotics, preferably trimethoprim or ciprofloxacin.

A rigorous and prolonged treatment is indicated to eradicate the infection eradication and avoid recurrent attacks.

Acute bacterial prostatitis is usually hematogenous from a distant focus or secondary to acute urinary tract infection (UTI). The most common organism is Escherichia coli. An associated increase in levels of PSA(>4ng/ml) may be present due to prostate inflammation.

Option A & B: In chronic bacterial prostatitis, patients present with threads in urine and pus cells seen during prostatic massage. It is mainly caused by Chlamydia and managed with doxycycline and when caused by anaerobes like trichomonas, it is treated by metronidazole.

Option C: Per urethral resection is the treatment of choice for prostatic abscesses where patients mainly complaint of fever and rigors.

questions.text:
All of the following are virulence factors of Candida albicans, except ________.

ALS - agglutinin-like sequence
questions.solution:
All of the above are virulence factors of Candida albicans except glucuronoxylomannan (GXM).

GXM is the capsular polysaccharide of Cryptococcus. During infection, GXM is solubilized in spinal fluid, serum, or urine and can be detected by an enzyme immunoassay or by the agglutination of latex particles coated with antibodies to the polysaccharide. This test is diagnostic of cryptococcosis if done with proper control.

 The virulence factors of Candida albicans:

  • Agglutinin-like sequence (ALS) surface glycoproteins, that bind to the host cell membrane receptors and mediate attachment to the epithelial and endothelial cells.
  • Secreted aspartyl proteinases (SAPs), that degrade host cell membranes and destroy immunoglobulins.
  • Phospholipase (PLB1) is secreted by the yeasts and pseudohyphae.
  • Fungal biofilm, which is protected by the extracellular matrix material prevents the penetration of the host’s immune response and antifungal drugs.

Clinically, infection with candida can present as cutaneous and mucosal candidiasis, systemic candidiasis, and rarely, chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis. Cutaneous and mucosal infections manifest as thrush affecting the tongue, lips, gums, and palate. It is seen as a patchy to confluent, whitish pseudomembranous lesion and is commonly associated with AIDS. Candida may also invade the vaginal mucosa leading to vulvovaginitis, and the nails, and around the nail plate (onychomycosis).

Serum beta 1,3 glucan assay can be used in the diagnosis of systemic candidiasis. 

Given below is an image of oral thrush.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with post-menopausal bleeding. To rule out endometrial carcinoma, she underwent a diagnostic procedure that was performed using Hegar's dilator and Sim's curette. This procedure is also done for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above-mentioned procedure performed in a patient with post-menopausal bleeding using Hegar's dilator and Sims's curette is dilatation and curettage (D&C). Another indication for this procedure is abnormal uterine bleeding.

D&C is a minor gynecological procedure where the cervix is dilated and endometrial tissue is curetted (scraped) from the uterine cavity. It is used as both a diagnostic and therapeutic measure. It is indicated in many conditions, including: 

  • Abnormal uterine bleeding to study the hormonal pattern that is causing uterine bleeding
  • Post menopausal bleeding to rule out endometrial cancer
  • To rule out endometrial hyperplasia and cancer in a patient on tamoxifen for breast cancer
  • Endometrial cancer to decide stage and treatment modality
  • Secondary amenorrhea to look for tubercular endometritis

Therapeutic indications include removing endometrial polyps, medical termination of pregnancy, and evacuation of missed/incomplete abortion.

The image below shows various instruments used in D&C.


Other options:

Option B: Endometriosis is a condition where there is ectopic benign endometrial tissue outside of the uterine cavity. It is better diagnosed by laparoscopy (gold standard), CA-125 measurement, and ultrasound.

Option C: D&C is contraindicated in pelvic inflammatory disease.

Option D: Cervical carcinoma, in cases where they are suspected or confirmed,  D&C is not the preferred procedure. 

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: The vessel marked in the image is a branch of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the given MR angiography of the circle of Willis is the anterior cerebral artery. It is a branch of internal carotid artery. 

Anterior cerebral arteries arise from the internal carotid artery and are part of the circle of Willis. The left and right anterior cerebral arteries are connected by the anterior communicating artery.

Anterior cerebral artery occlusion distal to the anterior communicating artery manifests as:

  • Contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss that mainly affects the leg and foot, due to the involvement of the paracentral lobule.
  • Inability to identify objects correctly, apathy, and personality changes due to involvement of frontal and parietal lobes. 

 

Other options:

Vertebral and basilar artery contribute to the posterior cerebral circulation while the internal carotid artery contributes to the anterior cerebral circulation. Vertebral artery arises from the sublcavian artery. The two verterbral arteries combine to form the basilar artery. 

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: You are observing flow cytometry being performed at a laboratory for MHC class 1 antigen. Identify the cells that lack this antigen.
questions.solution:
Red blood cells are anucleated cells that lack MHC class I antigens.

MHC class I antigens are present on platelets and all nucleated cells, except sperm cells. They are responsible for the presentation of peptide antigen to CD8 T cells.

The human major histocompatibility complex (MHC), or the HLA complex, is a cluster of genes whose products are responsible for antigen presentation to T cells, transplant rejection, etc. HLA complex of genes is present on the short arm of chromosome 6. The genes are clustered in three regions named MHC region-I, II and III.

MHC class II antigens are present only on antigen-presenting cells (macrophages, dendritic cells, B cells). They present the peptide antigen to CD4 T cells. APCs also contain MHC class I antigens. 

MHC region III comprises of genes that code for complement factors like C2, C4, C3 convertase, factor B and properdin, heat shock protein, tumor necrosis factor and steroid 21-hydroxylases.

Related Pearl: MHC Classes I and II

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Expressed on all nucleated cells (except sperms) and platelets

Expressed on antigen-presenting cells: macrophages, B lymphocytes, dendritic cells

Consist of a polymorphic α, heavy-chain, linked non-covalently to β2-microglobulin

Heterodimer consisting of non-covalently associated α and β chains, both of which are polymorphic.

α chains are encoded by three genes- HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C

Encoded by HLA-D, with subregions: HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR.

Display antigenic peptides that are derived from viral and tumor proteins

Present antigens that are internalized into vesicles, and derived from extracellular microbes 

Class I complexes are recognized by CD8+ T cells

 

Class II complexes are recognized by CD4+ T cells

Endogenous peptide is the type of antigen presented to CD8+ T cells

 Exogenous antigen is the type of antigen presented to CD4+ T cells 

Presents antigen via the cytosolic pathway

 Presents antigen via the endocytic pathway 

Antigen binding site is present between α1/α2 groove

 Antigen binding site is present between α1/β1 groove 

α3 binds to CD8 molecules on cytotoxic T cells

 β2 binds to CD4 on helper T cells

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby was brought to the pediatric outpatient department with fever and breathing difficulty. On examination, fine inspiratory crackles, and expiratory wheezes were heard. A radiograph of the baby is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is bronchiolitis. The radiograph shows the presence of peribronchial thickening and perihilar fullness. These findings along with the features of fever, breathing difficulty, fine inspiratory crackles, and expiratory wheezes in a 3-month-old baby suggest bronchiolitis.

Bronchiolitis occurs due to viral lower respiratory tract infections, most commonly by the respiratory syncytial virus. It is common in children less than 6 months of age. 

Clinical features of bronchiolitis include fever, cough, fine inspiratory crackles, expiratory wheezes, and breathing difficulty. Cyanosis may be seen in severe cases.

Radiographs may be normal in some patients. In the majority of them, there will be interstitial infiltrates, hyper-expansion of the chest, and peribronchial thickening. 

Management of this condition is mainly symptomatic. Children should be provided with adequate fluids and oxygen therapy if required.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with painless, gross hematuria. He was evaluated for the same, and a cystoprostatectomy was done. The gross specimen image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of the cystoprostatectomy specimen shows a large, fungating growth from the bladder wall involving the entire bladder with the two lobes of the prostate not being much affected. The most likely diagnosis is bladder carcinoma. 

Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom that is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise. Subsequent clots and urinary retention can occur. Increased frequency and discomfort during urination may be seen. It can lead to pelvic pain due to extravesical spread, loin pain due to hydronephrosis, and suprapubic pain if the nerve is involved.

Depending upon the depth of invasion, bladder carcinoma is divided into 3 groups:

  • Flat, non-invasive carcinoma in situ (CIS)
  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer - does not invade detrusor muscle but can invade lamina propria. It accounts for 70% of cases.
  • Muscle-invasive bladder cancer - invades the detrusor muscle.

Diagnosis and staging are done by cystoscopy and resection of the tumor. A bimanual examination should be performed after the resection of the tumor. Complete urinary tract imaging is required using contrast computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance (MR) urography.

Management:

  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer - Endoscopic resection and intravesical instillations of mitomycin C/ epirubicin, immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG)
  • Muscle invasive bladder cancer - Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection +/- neoadjuvant chemotherapy

Other options: 

Option A- Leukoplakia is squamous metaplasia of the bladder characterized by white particles (keratin) in the urine. Diffuse leukoplakia of the bladder is pre-malignant and can lead to squamous cancer of the bladder. It has to be assessed by cystoscopy and localized areas may be resected.

Option C- Prostate carcinoma presents with symptoms only during advanced disease. It causes bladder outlet obstruction, pelvic pain, hematuria, and renal failure. It is surgically managed by radical prostatectomy, which only involves the removal of the prostate and seminal vesicles and preserving the bladder. Unlike the given gross specimen one or more lobes are predominantly involved in prostatic carcinoma.

Option D- Schistosomiasis of the bladder is a parasitic infection by Schistosoma haematobium. Cystoscopy would show nodules, pseudotubercles, ulceration, or sandy patches. Chronic infection can lead to squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.

 

Related Pearl: Etiological Factors for Bladder Carcinoma

questions.text: The rotation of the midgut is primarily based on the axis of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The rotation of the midgut is primarily based on the axis of the superior mesenteric artery. 

The mechanism of midgut rotation is given and represented in the image below - 

The midgut once formed lies outside the abdominal cavity and has to rotate and enter the abdominal cavity. When viewed ventrally, this rotation occurs for 270º in an anti-clockwise direction with the axis formed by the superior mesenteric artery. The artery divides the intestinal loop into a pre-arterial and post-arterial segment. The total rotation can be divided into three stages of 90º each:

Stage 1 - Initially the loop lies in the sagittal plane, the pre-arterial segment cranial, and the post-arterial segment caudal. The first 90º anticlockwise rotation occurs resulting in the pre-arterial segment lying on the right and the post-arterial segment lying on the left of the axis.

Stage 2 - The pre-arterial segment undergoes lengthening to form coils of the jejunum and ileum. The second 90º anticlockwise rotation occurs resulting in the coils of the jejunum and ileum lying behind the superior mesenteric artery and occupying the posterior left half of the abdominal cavity. As a result the duodenum also lies behind the artery.

Stage 3 -  In this stage, the post arterial segment enters the abdominal cavity by the last 90º anticlockwise rotation resulting in the transverse colon lying in front of the superior mesenteric artery and the cecum lies on the right in the abdominal cavity just below the liver. The cecum gradually descends to its final location in the right iliac fossa.

questions.text: A middle-aged man is being evaluated for epigastric pain and burning sensation for the past few weeks. He also gives a history of occasional black discoloration of the stools. A barium study was done for the patient. Which of the following findings on barium study would indicate that the ulcer is benign?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of gastric ulcers and the presence of Hampton's lines on barium study would indicate that the gastric ulcer is benign.

Hampton's line is a thin radiolucent line seen at the base of a gastric ulcer in barium studies. It represents the preserved gastric mucosa with undermining of the more vulnerable submucosa. It indicates the benign nature of the gastric ulcer.

Other features of a benign ulcer include:

  • The smooth rim of lucency at the base of the ulcer.
  • Converging folds
  • Round, linear, or oval-shaped ulcer
  • Symmetrical, gently sloping ulcer mass.

Difference between benign and malignant gastric ulcer:

Barium swallow findings Benign Malignant
Hampton’s line Present Absent
Extends beyond the gastric wall Yes No
Folds Smooth, even Irregular, nodular, may fuse
Carman meniscus Absent Present
Ulcer shape Round, oval, linear Irregular

Carman meniscus sign is seen in malignant gastric ulcers. It refers to the lenticular shape of barium in the shallow/flat malignant ulcer, in which the inner margin is convex toward the lumen. Other features of malignant ulcers include irregular ulcer, nodular mound, and thickened, irregular interrupted, and fused folds around the ulcer, loss of mucosal pattern, and incomplete healing.

Related Pearl: Barium Studies

Barium swallow: Used to assess the pharynx, esophagus, and stomach. (Barium paste is used)

The image below is a barium swallow showing eosinophilic esophagitis and associated stricture:

Barium meal: Used to assess stomach and duodenum. (95% BaSO4 is used)

Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used)

Barium enema: Used to assess the large intestine (25% BaSO4 is used)

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presented with complaints of fever and fatigue for the past few weeks. Examination revealed hepatomegaly and splenomegaly. The peripheral blood smear is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The peripheral blood smear shows numerous Auer rods in the cytoplasm of progranulocytes, characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Acute myeloid leukemia is a spectrum of hematological malignancies where poorly differentiated cells of the hematopoietic stem cells infiltrate the blood and bone marrow. They are the most common acute leukemias in elderly people. Histopathology from bone marrow aspirate reveals Auer rods (needle-like azurophilic granules) in the cytoplasm of the progranulocytes. There is also presence of bilobed nuclei and multiple coarse azurophilic granules. 

Auer rods are predominantly seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia which is a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia. Acute promyelocytic leukemia is associated with t(15;17)(q22;11-12), which results in the formation of the fusion gene called PML-RARa. The condition is associated with a high incidence of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Treatment includes administration of all-trans retinoic acid.

Other options:

Option A: Acute lymphocytic leukemia present with a hypercellular marrow that is packed with lymphoblasts. These lymphoblasts, when compared to myeloblasts, have more condensed chromatin with less prominent nucleoli. Histochemichal staining show that lymphoblasts are myeloperoxidase-negative and often contain a periodic acid–Schiff–positive cytoplasm.

Option B: Chronic myeloid leukemia is characterised by scattered macrophages with green-blue colored cytoplasm called sea blue histiocytes. 

Option D: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia usually contain proliferation centers that are pathognomonic for chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Smudge cells can also be seen. They are small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm that gets disrupted during the process of smearing.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

The 5th edition of WHO (2022) classification classifies acute myeloid leukemia (AML) as follows:

AML with defining genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes):

  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia with PML::RARA fusion
  • AML with RUNX1::RUNX1T1 fusion
  • AML with CBFB::MYH11 fusion
  • AML with DEK::NUP214 fusion
  • AML with RBM15::MRTFA fusion
  • AML with BCR::ABL1 fusion
  • AML with KMT2A rearrangement*
  • AML with MECOM rearrangement
  • AML with NUP98 rearrangement
  • AML with NPM1 mutation
  • AML with CEBPA mutation
  • AML, myelodysplasia-related#
  • AML with other defined genetic alterations

  • AML with minimal differentiation
  • AML without maturation
  • AML with maturation
  • Acute basophilic leukaemia
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukaemia
  • Acute monocytic leukaemia
  • Acute erythroid leukaemia
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia

Most AML with defining genetic abnormalities are diagnosed with < 20% blasts except AML with BCR: ABL1 and AML with CEBPA mutation that require at least 20% blasts for diagnosis.

*AML with KMT2A rearrangement is the new term that replaces “AML with t(9;11)(p22;q23); KMT2A-MLLT3

#AML with myelodysplasia-related changes has been renamed as AML, myelodysplasia-related (AML-MR).

questions.text: A patient presents with itching of the skin of the leg. On examination, the affected area is hyperpigmented and atrophic, with a non-tender subcutaneous nodule over the shin. The causative organism is suspected to be linked to blackflies. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The patient with hyperpigmentation, atrophic and itchy lesion, and a non-tender subcutaneous nodule over the shin, and in whom blackflies are suspected to be involved, is likely to be infected with Onchocerca volvulus. 

Onchocerca volvulus is a tissue nematode. The life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus is completed partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female blackflies, the intermediate host.

During a blood meal, the female blackfly ingests the microfilariae from the skin and lymphatics of an infected person. It is within the vector that the microfilariae develop into first-stage larvae and subsequently into third-stage infective larvae.

When the infected black fly bites another person, it introduces third-stage filarial larvae into the skin of the human host.

The image given below depicts the life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus.

The larvae penetrate into the bite wound and develop into adult worms in the subcutaneous tissues. They may be seen within subcutaneous nodules called onchocercomas or may live freely in the tissues.

The adult worm can live in the human host for about 15 years while the microfilariae for about a year.

Other options:

Option A: Loa loa completes its life cycle in humans, the definitive host, and in mango flies/day-biting flies of the genus Chrysops, which are the intermediate hosts/vectors. The microfilariae develop into third-stage larvae in the vector, which is the infective form.

The image given below depicts the life cycle of Loa loa.


Option B: Leishmania donovani completes its life cycle in the female sandfly, the vector, and in definitive hosts which include man, dogs, and other mammals. The promastigote form in the midgut of the sandfly is the infective form.

The image given below depicts the life cycle of Leishmania donovani.


Option C: Wucheraria bancrofti passes its life cycle partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female Culex mosquitoes, the intermediate hosts.

The image given below depicts the life cycle of Wucheraria bancrofti.

Related Pearl: Arthropod- borne diseases

questions.text:
A 25-week primigravida has been on labetolol 100 mg twice a day for 2 months. She now presents with epigastric pain. Her 24-hour urine protein is 400 mg and her platelet count is 70,000/microliters. What other investigation abnormality can be noted in her present condition?

AST - aspartate transaminase

ALT - alanine transaminase

LDH - lactate dehydrogenase

choices.text: Decreased serum AST and ALT levels
Target cells in peripheral blood smear

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe preeclampsia with HELLP syndrome. Another investigative abnormality that can be noted in this patient is hepatic hematoma in MRI.

Preeclampsia is characterized by hypertension with proteinuria. Proteinuria occurs when the amount of protein excreted through urine in 24-hours is greater than 300 mg. It is an important diagnostic criterion for severe preeclampsia as it shows that there is system-wide endothelial leakage.

HELLP syndrome is an acronym that stands for: 

  • Hemolysis
  • Elevated Liver enzymes 
  • Low Platelets

Microangiopathic hemolysis manifests as:

  • Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels
  • Reduced haptoglobin levels
  • Schizocytosis, spherocytosis, and reticulocytosis on peripheral blood smear

Elevation of AST and ALT (liver enzymes) levels occurs due to periportal hemorrhagic necrosis in the liver. Furthermore, hemorrhagic infarcts can extend to form a subcapsular hematoma that stretches the Glisson capsule. This results in characteristic epigastric/right quadrant pain and tenderness. It can be diagnosed using a CT or MRI. 

Overt thrombocytopenia occurs when platelet count is less than 100,000 per microliter, as seen in severe disease.

HELLP syndrome can also be associated with other complications such as eclampsia, placental abruption, stroke, coagulopathy, and pulmonary edema. 

Cesarian is the commonest mode of delivery. Platelet transfusion is required if counts are less than 50,000 mm3. Magnesium sulfate is given as antiseizure prophylaxis. Corticosteroid therapy is also given to improve maternal and perinatal outcomes. Unless the bleeding is ongoing, hepatic hematoma is managed conservatively (otherwise surgical intervention or angiographic embolization). 

Other options:

Option A & B: Serum AST, ALT, and LDH levels increase in HELLP syndrome.

Option D: Target cells in peripheral blood smear can be seen in conditions such as thalassemia.

questions.text: A baby born at 26 weeks of gestation presented with cyanosis, tachypnea, and grunting 3 hours after birth. Auscultation revealed decreased air entry and bilateral homogenous opacification of the lungs on the chest radiograph. This is likely due to a defect in the synthesis of?
questions.solution:
A preterm baby having respiratory distress along with homogenous opacification of the lungs is suggestive of respiratory distress syndrome which is likely due to a defect in the synthesis of dipalmitoyl lecithin.

Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease, is due to the decreased production and secretion of the lung surfactant. It is primarily made of phospholipids such as dipalmitoyl lecithin (otherwise known as dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine). The other minor components are phosphatidylglycerol, apoproteins, and cholesterol. It is synthesized in type II pneumocytes/granular pneumocytes in the endoplasmic reticulum (shown below).

RDS is commonly seen in preterm babies less than 34 weeks of gestation. Surfactant deficiency leads to an increase in the surface tension over the alveoli causing the alveoli to collapse easily during expiration. Therefore, the baby has to put more effort into expanding the lungs. Tachypnea, cyanosis, nasal flaring, prominent expiratory grunting, and intercostal and subcostal retractions are some of the common findings seen in this condition. 

Chest X-ray shows features such as reticulogranular pattern, ground-glass opacity, and air bronchogram. White-out lungs can be seen on chest X-rays in severe disease.

Management in mild to moderate RDS is with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) where the positive pressure keeps the alveoli open in a spontaneously breathing baby. Severe cases will require mechanical ventilation. Steroids increase the production of the surfactant and therefore steroids are administered antenatally to mothers with preterm labor.

Other options - 

Option A: Dipalmitoyl serine is a phospholipid present in the cell membrane, which plays a role in apoptosis (programmed cell death).

Option C: Dipalmitoyl cephalin or phosphatidylethanolamine is present in the cell membrane. 

Option D: Dipalmitoyl inositol or phosphatidylinositol acts as a precursor for the secondary messenger system. It also helps in cell signaling and membrane trafficking.

questions.text:
A college-going student presented with sustained dental injuries in a street fight. Examination reveals that his permanent lower right canine tooth was missing. According to the FDI system, what dental numbering would you give to this tooth while writing his case sheet?

FDI - Federation Dentaire Internationale
questions.solution:
According to the FDI system, the dental numbering to be given to this tooth while writing his case sheet would be 43.

As per the FDI system, the permanent lower right canine tooth is represented by the number 43.

Federation Dentaire Internationale (FDI) system is a two-digit system.

  • The first digit represents the quadrant: 1 for right upper, 2 for left upper, 3 for left lower, and 4 for right lower.
  • The second digit represents the teeth of each quadrant, numbered 1 to 8, starting from the central incisor and moving away from the midline.

Number 4 indicates the lower right quadrant according to the FDI system and number 3 indicates the canine tooth. So 43 indicates the lower right canine.

questions.text: A patient with poorly controlled diabetes and peripheral neuropathy complains of pain and swelling in the left foot after sustaining a trivial injury. Examination revealed the following findings. The radiograph reveals midfoot dislocation. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of loss of sensation and flat foot is suggestive of sensory and motor neuropathy in a diabetic patient along with joint involvement, pointing to a diagnosis of Charcot foot. 

Charcot foot is a condition in which patients develop neuropathic destruction of joints. Diabetic neuropathy is a common cause. It may be painless but most cases present with pain. Other features include redness and swelling. 

The principle of treatment is to maintain the shape of the foot in order to avoid pressure ulcers at a later stage. Surgical options are aimed at preventing deformity by early stabilization, reconstruction, and prevention of complications like ulcers by removing bony prominences. 

Other options:

Option B: Osteomyelitis is a common complication in diabetics, often presenting with foot pain and swelling but without immediate dislocation on imaging.

Option C: A fracture-dislocation may result from a traumatic event, it typically suggests acute injury rather than the underlying chronic changes associated with neuropathic conditions.

Option D: Cellulitis is a bacterial infection following any broken skin or any pre-existing condition. It is characterized by pain, fever, and leucocytosis.

questions.text: Buspirone is used as one of the first-line drugs in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Buspirone is primarily used as one of the first-line drugs in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder. It is an anxiolytic drug and has a partial agonistic action on 5HT1A receptors. It is not effective in treating other types of anxiety.

Other options:

Option B: In patients with panic disorder, buspirone increases anxiety since it causes the increased firing of locus coeruleus, which is the underlying mechanism of panic disorder.

Option C: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors such as paroxetine, citalopram, and sertraline are used in the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorders. 

Option D: Epilepsy is a disorder of brain function characterised by periodic and unpredictable seizures. They are managed with anti-seizure drugs.

questions.text: A newborn baby is vaccinated against tuberculosis disease as shown in the image below. Identify the incorrect statement about this vaccine.

choices.text: The dose given at birth is 0.05 ml and the adult dose is 0.1 ml
A normal individual becomes Mantoux-positive 8 weeks after administration
It is a live vaccine administered intradermally
Freeze-dried preparation is less stable than liquid preparation.

questions.solution:
The image above shows the administration of the BCG (bacillus of Calmette and Guerin) vaccine used against tuberculosis disease and among the two types of BCG vaccine preparations, the freeze-dried vaccine is a more stable preparation than the liquid vaccine. It also has a greater shelf-life and most of the current BCG vaccines are distributed in freeze-dried form.

BCG is the only widely used live bacterial vaccine. The WHO has recommended the Danish 1331 strain for the production of the BCG vaccine.

It is recommended to use normal saline for reconstituting the vaccine since distilled water may cause irritation. The reconstituted vaccine should be used within 3 hours and the left-over vaccine should be discarded.

The dose for neonates (< 4 weeks ) is 0.05 ml. In adults, the strength commonly used for vaccination is 0.1 mg in 0.1 ml volume. It is injected intradermally using a tuberculin syringe just above the insertion of the left deltoid muscle. 

After 2-3 weeks of vaccination, a papule develops at the site of vaccination. It slowly increases in size and then subsides or breaks into a shallow ulcer after 5 weeks. It heals spontaneously in 6-12 weeks leaving a permanent, tiny, round scar that is roughly 4-8 mm in diameter. Under normal patient circumstances, the individual becomes Mantoux-positive after a period of 8-14 weeks. 

The image below shows a BCG scar in an infant:

BCG vaccination has been associated with adverse reactions such as :

  • Prolonged severe ulceration at the site of vaccination
  • Suppurative lymphadenitis
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Disseminated BCG infection 
  • Death.

To avoid complications, the BCG vaccine should be strictly intradermal. It is also recommended to not give any other injection into the arm which received the BCG vaccine for at least 6 months.

BCG vaccination is contraindicated in situations where its effect might get exaggerated in patients. Some of these conditions are as follows:

  • Generalized eczema
  • Infective dermatosis
  • Hypogammaglobulinaemia
  • Immunodeficiency state
  • Pregnancy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with complaints of breathlessness on walking a few yards. He adds that he has an uncomfortable awareness of his heartbeat, especially on lying down. Examination reveals widened pulse pressure and pulsating uvula. Which of the following would be the most likely auscultatory finding in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of breathlessness and palpitations, along with the findings of widened pulse pressure and pulsating uvula, is suggestive of aortic regurgitation(AR). The most likely auscultatory finding in this patient is Austin-Flint murmur.

Aortic regurgitation may either be caused due to valvular heart diseases like endocarditis and rheumatic fever; diseases of the aortic root, like aortic dissection and medial degeneration, or a combination of both.

Men are more commonly affected than women. Patients present with features of an uncomfortable awareness of the heartbeat, especially on lying down, and exertional dyspnea.

The dyspnea is followed by orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and excessive diaphoresis. Anginal chest pain may occur, both at rest as well as during exertion; these episodes of chest pain can be prolonged and often do not respond well to sublingual nitroglycerin.

Auscultatory findings in aortic regurgitation include a diastolic murmur and Austin Flint murmur. The former is a typically high-pitched, blowing, decrescendo murmur. It is called a 'cooing dove' murmur when the murmur is of musical quality. Its presence usually signifies the eversion or perforation of an aortic cusp. 

An Austin Flint murmur is a soft, low-pitched, rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur. It is created by the regurgitant stream displacing the anterior leaflet of the normal mitral valve.

Other options:

Options B and D: Opening snap and Graham Steel murmur are seen in mitral stenosis. The Graham Steel murmur is a decrescendo diastolic murmur seen in mitral stenosis patients who have developed pulmonary hypertension, and resultant pulmonary regurgitation.

Option C: Gallavardin phenomenon is seen in aortic stenosis, where the coarse systolic murmur of aortic stenosis may sound higher pitched and more acoustically pure at the apex.

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

questions.text: A 46-year-old man who was treated with haloperidol for delirium developed fever, tachycardia, increased blood pressure, muscle stiffness, and altered mental status. Investigations revealed elevated levels of creatine phosphokinase (CPK). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features in a patient who has been administered haloperidol, are most likely suggestive of the neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a life-threatening complication that can occur anytime during antipsychotic treatment. Haloperidol is known to cause NMS. The condition may occur within 24-72 hrs after initiation of the treatment, and if untreated, may last for 10 to 14 days.

Clinical features include motor and behavioral symptoms like muscular rigidity, dystonia, akinesia, mutism, obtundation, and agita­tion. Autonomic symptoms include fever, diaphore­sis, and increased pulse and blood pressure.

Investigations reveal elevated levels of WBC count, creatinine phosphokinase (CPK), myoglobin, and liver enzymes. Occasionally, myoglobinuria may be seen in patients who develop acute renal failure.

Dantrolene and bromocriptine are commonly used for the treatment. Amantadine may be used in some cases. Electroconvulsive therapy may also be used. 

Other options:

Option A: Serotonin syndrome occurs due to an increase of plasma serotonin to toxic levels, due to concurrent administration of SSRI and an MAO inhibitor, L-tryptophan or lithium. The patients initially present with diarrhea and restlessness. As the condition worsens, they develop extreme agitation, hyperreflexia, autonomic instability, myoclonus, seizures, hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, and rigidity. There may be delirium, coma, status epilepticus, cardio­ vascular collapse, and death in the worst cases.

Option B: Tardive dyskinesia is characterized by abnormal, irregular, involuntary choreoathetoid movements of the muscles of the head, limbs, and trunk. Perioral movement is most common. The condition usually develops as a delayed response to antipsychotics, about 6 months after treatment.

Option C: Hypersensitivity reaction to haloperidol may include anaphylactic reaction, angioedema, rash, urticaria, face edema, laryngeal edema, bronchospasm, and laryngospasm.

Related Pearl: Psychiatric emergency: Fever with altered mental status

In a clinical setting of fever with altered mental status, it is important to differentiate between the following.

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
Serotonin syndrome
Anticholinergic syndrome
Malignant hyperthermia
