questions.text: A 50-year-old man has to undergo renal transplant surgery. You were asked to collect his blood samples for HLA matching in a yellow-colored vacutainer. Which of the following is present in the yellow-colored vacutainers?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used vacutainer for HLA typing is a yellow vacutainer containing acid-citrate dextrose.

Other uses of yellow vacutainers are DNA sampling and paternity testing. Other components that can be used in yellow vacutainers include Sodium polyanethol sulfonate (SPS) which is used to collect blood culture for microbiology specimens.

Other options:

  1. Ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA) - It is used for routine hematology samples and is a part of violet vacutainers.
  2. Sodium fluoride - It is used for the determination of glucose and is a part of grey vacutainers
  3. Sodium citrate - It is used for coagulation studies and is a part of blue vacutainers.

Related Pearl: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

questions.text: A truck driver presents with a painless, circumscribed ulcer over the penis. He had unprotected sexual intercourse two weeks ago. Examination reveals a non-tender ulcer with an indurated base. Exudate shows the following picture on microscopy. What type of motility is exhibited by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative agent is Treponema pallidum, which exhibits corkscrew motility.

The clinical vignette of a painless, non-tender, circumscribed ulcer over the penis with an indurated base that developed subsequent to unprotected sexual intercourse, and the finding on darkfield microscopy are suggestive of primary syphilis.

It is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete that is actively motile. The motility is best observed on dark ground or phase-contrast microscopy.

The movement is described as corkscrew-like with the organism moving backward and forward while rotating around the long axis. In addition, secondary curves are observed to appear and disappear, as the organism moves.

Primary syphilis occurs subsequent to inoculation of treponema pallidum following sexual contact. It manifests as a local, nontender ulcer over the genitalia called a hard chancre, in 2-10 weeks. 

It can be diagnosed using VDRL, RPR test and can be confirmed by FTA – ABS testing or TPHA, TPI testing.

The bacteria can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy. Smear specimens are stained using Fontana stain and pathological tissues are stained using Levaditi stain. Silver impregnation technique can also be used. 

Other options : 

Option B: Darting motility is exhibited by Vibrio cholerae. It is the causative agent of cholera, an acute diarrheal disease characterized by vomiting and stool that is colorless and watery called 'rice water stool'.

Option C: Gliding motility is exhibited by Mycoplasma. It can cause primary atypical pneumonia and genital infections in humans.

Option D: Tumbling motility is exhibited by Listeria monocytogenes. It is the causative agent of listeriosis, which can manifest as meningitis or sepsis in neonates, meningoencephalitis in the elderly, and immunocompromised.

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Motility Microorganism
Darting/vibratory motility  Vibrio,Campylobacter
Swarming motility Cl. septicum, B.cereus, Proteus, some Vibrio sp
Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes
Stately motility Clostridia
Spinning motility Fusobacterium gyrans
Cork-screw motility  Treponema pallidum
Falling leaf motility Giardia
Twitching motility Eikenella corrodens
Differential motility (Motility varies at different temperatures) Yersinia enterocolitica & Listeria monocytogenes
Jerky motility  Trichomonas vaginalis
Gliding motility Mycoplasma, Entamoeba
Lashing motility  Saprophytic spirochetes

questions.text:
A 28-year-old female patient had complaints of weakness and easy fatiguability. The patient's hemogram results and peripheral smear are given below. Which of the following enzymes is dependent on the deficient vitamin?

HB - 5.8 g/dl

TLC - 1200

Platelet - 60,000 

MCV - 102 fl

MCH- 40 pg/cell
questions.solution:
The patient's complaints of weakness and easy fatiguability with a  peripheral smear showing macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils are suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency and the enzyme dependent on this vitamin is methionine synthase. 

There are 2 enzymes dependent on vitamin B12:

  • Methyl malonyl CoA mutase
  • Methionine synthase

Deficiency of vitamin B12 leads to impairment of methionine synthase and thereby causes accumulation of homocysteine and trapping folate as methyltetrahydrofolate.  

Other options:

Option A: Folate reductase catalyzes the conversion of folic acid to dihydrofolic acid and tetrahydrofolic acid in two steps. It is an NADPH-dependent reaction.

Options C and D: Cystathioninine synthase is involved in the production of cystathionine from homocysteine and serine. Cystathionase is involved in the breakdown of cystathionine from homocysteine and serine.

Both these enzymes require PLP (pyridoxal phosphate), the active form of vitamin B6.

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text: Which of the following when ingested causes milk-alkali syndrome?
questions.solution:
Calcium carbonate when ingested causes milk-alkali syndrome.

Milk alkali syndrome occurred in patients who was administered high doses of NaHCO3 and CaCO3 along with milk or cream for the management of peptic ulcers.

The increased intake of calcium can lead to increased sodium excretion and depletion of total body water. This in turn leads to bicarbonate resorption and alkalosis. This cycle repeats when calcium and alkali are ingested together. 

Characteristics of the milk-alkali syndrome include:

  • Alkalosis
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Renal insufficiency

The syndrome is rare now and generally occurs with a large intake of calcium supplements along with milk.

questions.text: A patient comes to you asking for emergency contraception. She had unprotected sex 4 days ago. Which of the following emergency contraceptives can be used in this case?
questions.solution:
Since the patient had unprotected sex 4 days ago, an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) can be used for emergency contraception. It can be inserted within 5 days of coitus as a method of emergency contraception. All other methods of emergency contraception mentioned above need to be administered within 72 hours.

An IUCD prevents the implantation of a fertilized ovum. It does so by acting as a foreign body within the uterine cavity. This leads to increased contractility, tubal peristalsis, and promotes leukocytic infiltration in the endometrium so that the fertilized egg is unable to implant.

Administration of postcoital contraceptive agents that interfere with postovulatory events that can lead to pregnancy is known as the emergency contraception method. They are used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse.

Other options:
Centchroman (option A) is administered as two tablets of 50 mg taken 12 hours apart, within 72 hours of intercourse. It acts by preventing the implantation of the blastocyst in the endometrium. It is the only contraceptive that neither suppresses ovulation nor interferes with the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis.

Mifepristone (option C) is administered as a single 10 mg tablet within 72 hours. It is a steroid with an affinity for progesterone receptors. It prevents fertilization by blocking the action of progesterone on the endometrium. This leads to sloughing and shedding of decidua, thus preventing implantation.

Levonorgestrel (option D) is administered as two tablets of 0.75 mg strength taken 12 hours apart, within 72 hours of intercourse. It prevents ovulation and causes desynchronization of the endometrium through its receptors (luteal phase deficiency).

Related Pearl: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

Category Failure rate in first year Contraceptive
First tier  < 2 % IUCD, Implants, Sterilization
Second tier  3-9 % Hormonal - oral, injected, transdermal patches, transvaginal rings
Third tier  10-20 % Barrier, Fertility awareness method
Fourth tier  21-30 % Spermicidal preparations

questions.text: A child is brought with symptoms of fever and sore throat. On examination, he was found to have blisters in the mouth and greyish oval vesicles on the palms and soles. Infection by which of the following organisms is typically associated with the above presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a child presenting with symptoms of fever, sore throat, blisters in the mouth, and greyish oval vesicles on the palms and soles is consistent with hand-foot-and-mouth disease and the associated organism is the Coxsackie virus.

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease is an exanthematous fever that commonly affects children below 10 years of age and is caused due to infection by the coxsackieviruses, with the A16, A9, and B 1-3 serotypes most commonly implicated.

The incubation period is around 5-7 days and children usually present with symptoms of low-grade fever, sore throat, and malaise. An early feature of the illness in adults is stomatitis, characterized by painful blisters in the mouth.

These blisters may break down to form ulcers. Greyish oval vesicles may be observed on the palms and soles and these are more likely to be seen in children. They fade after 2–3 days.

Laboratory diagnosis involves the isolation of the virus from the lesions or feces and inoculation into suckling mice. serodiagnosis is not useful, as is tissue culture. Management is supportive with intravenous immunoglobulin reserved only for severe cases.

Below is an image of a child with hand-foot-and-mouth disease.

Other options:
Option B: Epstein-Barr virus causes infectious mononucleosis. It commonly affects young adults and manifests as fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and mild, transient rash.

Option C: Herpes simplex virus type 2 is responsible for the majority of genital herpes infections. It is a venereal disease that can give rise to vesicular-ulcerative lesions affecting the genitalia.

Option D: Varicella-zoster virus can cause chickenpox and herpes zoster. The former usually affects children and presents as a rash that is centripetal in distribution, mainly involving the trunk and sparing the distal parts of the limbs. Herpes zoster is usually observed in adults after the fifth decade of life and the rash is unilateral and confined to the area supplied by a single sensory ganglion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a quantitative management technique used in the management of health programs?
questions.solution:
Information systems used in the management of health programs are based on behavioral science and are not a quantitative method of management of a health program.

The management of health programs entails the purposeful and effective use of resources, materials, and finances. It is based  on principles of behavioral sciences as well as quantitative methods.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with the following skin lesions. Identify the virus causing these lesions.
questions.solution:
The above image showing red-purple macules and plaques in an HIV-positive patient is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma, and is caused by the human herpes virus 8 (otherwise known as Kaposi Sarcoma-associated Herpes Virus (KSHV) ).

The sarcoma is a soft tissue carcinoma characterized by red papules and has a vascular origin. There are two forms of Kaposi sarcoma namely the sporadic form and the HIV-associated form. The latter form is more aggressive and involves the skin, gastrointestinal tract, and mucous membranes. The lesions are widespread and progressive in nature. They contain spindle cells that promote pro-inflammatory factors leading to the occurrence of malignancy. 

HHV8 virus infiltrates B lymphocytes, macrophages, epithelial, and endothelial cells predisposing the patient to a number of malignancies. KSHV is a known causative agent of four diseases:

  1. Kaposi's sarcoma
  2. KSHV-associated multicentric Castleman's disease (MCD)
  3. Primary effusion lymphoma
  4. KSHV inflammatory cytokine syndrome 

It is one of the seven currently known human cancer viruses or oncoviruses. The other oncoviruses include HBV (Hepatitis B virus), HTLV (Human T lymphotrophic virus), HCV (Hepatitis C virus), MCV (Merkel cell virus), EBV (Ebstein Barr virus), and HPV (Human papillomavirus).

Other options:

Option A: Human papilloma virus types 16 and 18 cause cervical cancer due to mutations in the RAS gene.

Option B & C: Pox virus and HHV 7 are not oncogenic viruses.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with inoperable lung cancer is brought by his wife to the psychiatrist. She says that he has lately been withdrawn from the rest of his family and has been avoiding them. He also has sleep disturbances and suicidal thoughts. These signs correspond to which of the following stages of grief?
questions.solution:
The given signs correspond to the fourth stage of grief, that is, depression.

During the fourth stage of grief, patients show clinical signs of depression, which include withdrawal, psychomotor retarda­tion, sleep disturbances, hopelessness, and suicidal ideation. This may either be in anticipation of the loss of life that would inevitably occur or the effects of the illness on their lives. 

The presence of major depressive disorder or suicidal idealation might necessitate treatment with antidepressants or electroconvulsive therapy.

The five stages of grief are:

  • denial
  • anger
  • bargaining
  • depression
  • acceptance

But, not all stages manifest in the same order in all patients and can also be applied to loss in other contexts such as the loss of a loved one.

Related Pearl: The 5 stages of grief model by Kübler-Ross

  • Denial - Patients may become numb and dazed at the news of their own imminent death and refuse to accept the diagnosis. 
  • Anger - Patients may get angry towards God or themselves. 
  • Bargaining - Patients may start to bargain with God or friends and doctors for a cure to buy some more time.
  • Depression - Patients may go into depression.
  • Acceptance - Patients finally accept that their death is inevitable and make further preparations (eg., making a will, etc). 

Related Pearl: Normal vs abnormal grief

 Normal vs abnormal grief

Grief/bereavement

Pathological Grief/depression

Sadness, tearfulness, decreased sleep, decreased appetite, decreased interest in the world

Sadness, tearfulness, decreased sleep, decreased appetite, decreased interest in the world

Symptoms wax and wane

Symptoms pervasive and unremitting

Shame and guilt are less common

Shame and guilt are common

Threaten suicide less often

Threaten suicide more often

Symptoms can last up to 1 year

Symptoms continue for more than one year

Usually, return to baseline level of functioning within 2 months

Patients do not return to normal functioning

Treatment includes supportive psychotherapy

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient, a known case of colon carcinoma came to the hospital with complaints of loss of appetite for 3 months.  Which of the following drugs is best suited to be prescribed in this patient to increase appetite?
questions.solution:
Cyproheptadine has an appetite-stimulating effect and has been used to promote weight gain in poor eaters.

It mainly blocks 5 hydroxytryptamine receptors and also has H1 antihistaminic and sedative properties. Side effects include drowsiness, dry mouth, ataxia and weight gain.

Loratidine, Cetirizine and Azelastine are second generation antihitamines.

Loratidine (option A) is a long acting H1 antihistamine and is useful in urticaria and atopic dermatitis

Cetirizine (option B) inhibits release of histamine and cytotoxic mediators from platelets and has superior efficacy ion urticaria and atopic dermatitis. 

Azelastine (option C) inhibits the intracellular adhesion molecule (ICAM-1) on nasal mucosa and is useful in allergic rhinitis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy was brought to the casualty with fever, urticaria, wheezing and colicky abdominal pain. Stool examination revealed the following egg. Identify the false statement regarding this nematode.

choices.text: Egg containing filariform larva is infective

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the egg shown in the image are suggestive of ascariasis caused by Ascaris lumbricoides. An embryonated egg containing the rhabditiform larva is the infective form.

The image given shows an elliptical-shaped egg with a thin irregular shell containing a mass of disorganized granules, suggestive of an unfertilized Ascaris egg.

Man is the only natural host. There is no intermediate host. The infection is acquired via the consumption of food or water contaminated with eggs. The eggs hatch after reaching the duodenum to release rhabditiform larvae. These penetrate the intestinal mucosa and enter the portal vessels. From the liver, larvae reach the systemic circulation, and lungs and then reach the small intestine to produce symptoms.

The life cycle of Ascaris lumbricoides is given below.

 

Clinical features due to the migrating larvae are fever, dry cough, and asthmatic wheezing. Loeffler's syndrome may be present which is characterized by the presence of larvae in the sputum or gastric washing. Chest imaging may show signs of eosinophilic pneumonitis.

Individuals infected by the adult worm can be asymptomatic but can also present with protein-energy malnutrition, vitamin A deficiency, toxic effects like urticaria, and angioedema due to hypersensitivity.

The worms can clump together and give rise to a volvulus, intussusception, intestinal obstruction, or even perforation. Additionally, they can also cause ectopic ascariasis, resulting in acute biliary obstruction, pancreatitis, and obstructive appendicitis.

Treatment includes pyrantel pamoate, albendazole, mebendazole, or ivermectin. 

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: You are called to see a 5-day-old, term neonate, who has not passed meconium yet. On clinical examination, you note a palpable goiter in this baby. All of the following can present with the given clinical picture except:

choices.text: Anti-thyroid drugs consumed by mother during pregnancy

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism with palpable goiter. Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism, but it is the least likely to present with the given clinical picture because it is not associated with palpable goiter.

In thyroid dysgenesis, there is either an absence of thyroid tissue (agenesis) or the presence of rudimentary tissue in a normal anatomical location (hypoplasia). The thyroid tissue can also be present in an ectopic location other than the thyroid gland.

Congenital hypothyroidism can be classified into two types:

  1. Congenital hypothyroidism without palpable goiter - the causes include thyroid dysgenesis, thyroid receptor blocking antibodies, and central (hypopituitary) hypothyroidism.
  2. Congenital hypothyroidism with palpable goiter - the causes include thyroid dyshormonogenesis, nutritional iodine deficiency, and consumption of antithyroid drugs during pregnancy by the mother leading to the placental passage of drugs to the fetus. 

Laboratory investigations in congenital hypothyroidism would demonstrate low T4 levels and increased TSH levels. 

Related Pearl: Differences between the two types of endemic cretinism

Neurological type Myxedematous type
Goiter  No goiter (USG shows thyroid atrophy)
Euthyroid  Permanent hypothyroidism
Intellectual disability, deaf-mutism, squint, proximal spasticity, and rigidity Intellectual disability, Deaf, coarse facial features, and myxedema.
Normal pubertal development and adult stature Delayed skeletal maturation and sexual development, severe short stature

questions.text: The parents of a three-year-old boy are seeking a therapist for their son. He is a three-year-old with normal developmental milestones but with poor speech abilities, inability to socialize with peers, restricted and repetitive behaviour with impaired non-verbal communication. Which of the following conditions is the boy most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a 3-year-old boy having poor speech abilities and inability to socialize but has normal developmental milestones is most likely suffering from autism.

Autism spectrum disorder refers to a phenotypically heterogeneous group of neurodevelopmental syndromes, characterized by a wide range of impairments in social communication along with restricted and repetitive behaviors. It is four times more common in boys than in girls.

Prior to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Dis­orders (DSM-5), autism spectrum disorder was conceptualized as five different disorders, that included autistic disorder, Asperger's disorder, childhood disintegrative disorder, Rett syndrome, and pervasive developmental disorder not otherwise specified.

The DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for autism spectrum disorder are:
  • Persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction that includes a failure to communicate, lack of empathy, abnormalities in eye contact, stereotyped or absent speech, and either hyper or hypo-arousal to the environment
  • Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities, as manifested by any two of the following: (i) Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements, use of objects or speech (ii) insistence on sameness, inflexible adherence to routines, or ritualized patterns of verbal/nonverbal behavior (iii) highly restricted and fixated interests (iv) hyper or hypoactivity to sensory input
  • Symptoms are present in the early developmental period, but may not fully manifest until later in life.
  • Symptoms cause impairment in social, occupational, and other important areas of functioning.
  • The disturbances cannot be explained by any intellectual disability.

It can be diagnosed by using the Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule-Generic (ADOS-G).

Other options:

Option A: Schizophrenia is characterized by hallucinations or delusions, and childhood-onset schizophrenia has a lower incidence of seizures, intellectual disability, and poor social skills. It is rare in children younger than 5 years. 

Option C: Language Disorder is equally common in boys and girls. The child actively uses non-verbal communication like gestures and any impaired social communication, restricted and repetitive behavior is absent.

Option D: ADHD (Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder) is characterized by a poor attention span with distractibility, hyperactivity, and impulsivity.

questions.text: A 6-week-old boy presents with low-pitched inspiratory stridor, present since a few days after birth. It subsides with prone positioning and increases with crying.  The observation made on direct laryngoscopy is shown in the image below.  What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of inspiratory stridor since birth with omega-shaped epiglottis, as shown in the image, is suggestive of laryngomalacia. The next step in management is expectant observation.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx. In this condition, the supraglottic portion of the larynx is excessively flaccid and subsequently gets sucked in during inspiration. This results in inspiratory stridor, a feature typical of laryngomalacia. It subsides on placing the child in a prone position but increases with crying. 

Direct laryngoscopy shows an elongated epiglottis that is curled upon itself, making it appear omega (Ω)-shaped. Other features include floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids.

Treatment of laryngomalacia is mainly conservative, as it self-corrects by the time the child is 2 years of age. Tracheostomy may be required in some cases with severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

Other options:

Options A & C: Endotracheal intubation and IV ceftriaxone are immediate management modalities of acute epiglottitis, which is a medical emergency. It is characterized by sore throat, dysphagia in adults, dyspnoea, and stridor in children, which are both rapidly progressive and associated with fever up to 40°C. Thumb sign, that is, a swollen epiglottis, is observed on a lateral view x-ray of the neck.

Option D: Nebulisation with racemic adrenaline is the immediate management of acute laryngotracheobronchitis. It is characterized by a low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and a barking cough.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypertensive woman presents with sudden, violent, uncontrollable flailing movements of her left proximal upper limb for the past one week. A lesion in which of the following structure is most commonly found in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given movement disorder describes hemiballismus and the lesion in subthalamus is most commonly found in this condition. 

Hemiballismus is a violent form of choreiform movement where wild, flinging, large-amplitude movements are seen affecting one side of the body. It mainly affects the proximal muscles and can be confined to one limb or both upper and lower limbs.

It is commonly seen in partial lesions i.e, infarct or haemorrhage in the subthalamic nucleus. Thalamus, putamen, and parietal cortex are less commonly involved.

This movement disorder is usually self-limiting and tends to resolve spontaneously after weeks or months. Dopamine antagonistic agents can be given to manage it as well. 

Other options:

Option B: A lesion in the putamen can give rise to chorea. This is described as flicking movements of the hands, face, or any other part of the body.

Option C: A lesion in the globus pallidus can give rise to athetosis. This involves spontaneous and continuous writhing movements of the hand, arm, neck, or face.

Option D: A lesion in the caudate nucleus would hamper cognitive control of motor activity, that is, voluntary movements generated due to the thoughts in a person's mind.

Related Pearl: Site of Lesion of Movement Disorders

Movement disorder

Site of Lesion

Athetosis

 Globus pallidus

Chorea

Putamen, Caudate

Hemiballismus

Subthalamic Nucleus

Parkinsonism

Substantia Nigra

questions.text: An intern uses the following instrument to catheterize the patient during his surgery postings. What is the size of the catheter used by the intern?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is Foley's catheter. The presence of a red coloured ring in the balloon port indicates its size as 18 F.

Catheter size is measured in the Charrière or French scale. The French scale refers to the external diameter of the catheter, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter. As a general rule, catheter size should be the smallest size that can accomplish the desired drainage (i.e., 12 to 14 Fr for clear urine and 20 to 24 for thick pus or blood-filled urine).

Other options:

Option A: 14 F foley's catheter has a green ring in the balloon port.

Option B: 12 F foley's catheter has an white ring in the balloon port. 

Option D: 20 F foley's catheter has a yellow ring in the balloon port.

The image below shows Foley catheters with different coloured rings in the balloon ports.

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text: A young man who had severe anemia underwent a blood transfusion with packed red blood cells. One hour later he appeared pale and developed fever with chills, flank pain, and dark-colored urine. A direct Coombs test was positive. Which of the following is implicated in this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Type II hypersensitivity reaction is implicated in this patient presenting with acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) following blood transfusion. It occurs most often due to ABO incompatibility and commonly occurs due to negligence in patient identification or tube labeling.

Type II hypersensitivity reaction is antibody-mediated. In ABO incompatibility, preformed IgM antibodies attack the antigens on donor red cells which causes complement fixation. This results in complement-mediated lysis, intravascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria. Complement activation produces fever with shaking chills. The patient appears pale due to hemolysis and has acute flank pain with dark-colored urine (hemoglobinuria).

The direct Coombs test is usually positive. Direct Coombs test/antiglobulin test is done on the surface of red blood cells. The Coombs reagent consists of anti-human antibodies. On combining with the red blood cells, the test becomes positive, if there are RBC antibodies present in the sample. This is because the anti-human antibodies in the reagent bind with the human antibodies in the RBCs and form a link. 

Other options:

Option A: Type I hypersensitivity reaction is IgE mediated. An anaphylactic blood transfusion reaction is a type I hypersensitivity reaction. However, it presents within seconds to minutes of blood transfusion with hypotension, urticaria, angioedema, and wheezing.

Option C: Type III hypersensitivity reaction, also known as immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction, occurs when antigen-antibody complexes deposition leads to complement activation. Examples include SLE, serum sickness, and the Arthus reaction.

Option D: Type IV hypersensitivity , also known as a cell-mediated or delayed hypersensitivity reaction, is caused by activated T lymphocytes. Examples include contact dermatitis and tuberculin skin testing.

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

questions.text: A patient presents with vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea for 3 days. His stools were greasy and foul-smelling. A wet preparation of the stool sample showed the presence of trophozoites shaped liked a tennis racket. What is the likely causative organism of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a child having loose greasy, foul-smelling stools, vomiting, abdominal pain along with stool examination showing trophozoites that are tennis-racket shaped is strongly suggestive of giardiasis. The causative organism of this condition is Giardia lamblia.

Infection is common in children and occurs by the ingestion of cysts in contaminated water and food. A single cyst can hatch out into two trophozoites, which eventually colonize the duodenum and upper part of the jejunum. It is the only protozoan parasite found in the lumen of the small intestine in humans.

Images of the cyst and trophozoite of giardia are given below:

Giardiasis is diagnosed by identification of cysts or trophozoites in the feces or small intestines, or by nucleic acid amplification tests. Wet mount preparation of stool samples may show the presence of a small, oval cyst surrounded by a hyaline cyst wall or a trophozoite that is shaped like a tennis racket. It is also referred to as heart-shaped or pyriform-shaped.

Metronidazole and tinidazole are the drugs of choice for treatment.

Other options :

Option A: Entamoeba histolytica causes amoebic dysentery. Microscopic examination of a saline wet mount of the stool shows the presence of diamond-shaped, clear, and refractile crystals called Charcot-Leyden crystals and nuclear masses called pyknotic bodies. Cysts are spherical with a single nucleus. Trophozoites have an irregular shape with the presence of pseudopodia. An image of the cyst is shown below:


Option C: Cryptosporidium parvum may be asymptomatic or cause a self-limiting febrile illness, with watery diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, and weight loss in immunocompetent individuals. Diagnosis is by demonstration of the oocysts in feces. The oocyst is spherical or oval and is acid-fast, appearing red on a blue background. It is shown below:


Option D: Balantidium coli is the only ciliated protozoan and it is present in the large intestine as a commensal. Living trophozoites are large with a macronucleus and have rapid revolving motility. The cysts are large and round with a macronucleus, as shown below.

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms of various protozoa

Parasite Infective form Diagnostic form

Giardia lamblia Quadrinucleate cyst Trophozoites, cyst

Acanthamoeba Trophozoites and cysts Trophozoite in CSF

questions.text: Which of the following RNA is involved in mRNA splicing?
questions.solution:
snRNA or small nuclear RNA plays a role in mRNA splicing. They take part in the formation of spliceosomes.

Other options:

Option A: miRNA (micro RNA) is derived from large primary transcripts through specific nucleolytic processing. It modulates gene expression by altering mRNA function. They bind to matching pieces of mRNA, turn it into a double strand and arrest the translation. 

Option B:  rRNAs are involved in protein synthesis. They facilitate the interaction of mRNA, tRNA, and amino acids to interact with each other for the translation process. 

Option C: siRNA or interfering RNA is mainly involved in RNA interference. They degrade the mRNA through specific cytoplasmic organelles called P bodies. 

Related Pearl: Types of RNA

Protein coding RNA

Non Protein coding RNA

mRNA

Ribosomal RNAs (rRNA)

Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs)

Transfer RNAs (tRNA)

Small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs)

Micro and silencing RNAs (miRNAs and siRNAs)

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant woman in the active stage of labor requests epidural anesthesia. Immediately following the injection of 1.5% lidocaine with 1:200,000 epinephrine through the epidural catheter, the patient complains of lip numbness and becomes very apprehensive. Her heart rate is 110/min and her BP is 90/60 mmHg.  What is this most likely due to?
questions.solution:
The above condition is most likely due to accidental intravascular injection of local anaesthetic into the epidural vein resulting in local anaesthesia systemic toxicity (LAST).

Features of LAST:

  1. CNS (in the order of appearance)
    • Tinnitus, blurred vision, dizziness, tongue paresthesia, and circumoral numbness
    • Excitatory signs such as nervousness, agitation, restlessness, and muscle twitching leading to tonic-clonic seizures
    • CNS depression with slurred speech, drowsiness, unconsciousness, and then respiratory arrest
    • Patients who have received CNS depressant drugs may present with only CNS depression without any preceding excitatory signs
  2. CVS
    • Prolonged PR intervals and widened QRS complexes, and sinus bradycardia/arrest
    • Ventricular arrhythmias, including fibrillation, are more likely to occur with bupivacaine than lidocaine.

Prevention:

  • Careful aspiration for CSF (to rule out intrathecal placement) and blood (to rule out intravascular placement) before injecting the local anaesthesia
  • Use of a test dose with lidocaine and adrenaline
  • Incremental injection techniques instead of a bolus dose
  • Close observation for early signs of intravascular injection

Treatment:

  • Supplemental oxygen should be given.
  • Seizures: Benzodiazepine; if not available, a small dose of propofol or thiopentone. If seizures persist, a neuromuscular blockade to minimize acidosis and hypoxemia
  • Cardiac arrest: standard ACLS protocol with few modifications
  • Lipid emulsion therapy
  • Last resort: cardio-pulmonary bypass

questions.text: A patient who is known to have pulmonary adenocarcinoma presents with severe dyspnea. A chest X-ray was taken which reveals the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of dyspnoea and chest X-ray findings suggests a diagnosis of massive pleural effusion  

The chest X-ray above shows a massive left-sided pleural effusion that is displacing the heart and trachea to the right. 

Pleural effusion is the abnormal accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavity. It can be seen on chest X-rays as homogenous opacification of the lower chest as well as the blunting of the lateral costophrenic angle and hemidiaphragm. If pleural effusion can be seen to the level of the fourth anterior rib, it means that a fluid volume of around 1000mL would be present. A massive pleural effusion would cause a mediastinal shift to the opposite side and an opacification of the hemithorax. 

Other options:

Option A: Consolidation is the filling of alveolar spaces with fluid. If it is fairly dense, it can be easily localized. It can be seen in community-acquired pneumonia. The X-ray shown below shows a consolidation within the right mid and both lower lobes.  

 

Option B: Pneumatoceles are shaggy thin-walled cavities that are seen on chest X-ray. Pneumatoceles can be seen in respiratory tract infections and are most often caused by S. aureus in children and P. jirovecii in immunocompromised adults. It is shown below.

 

Option C: Pneumothorax is air in the pleural space that is often caused by trauma. It can be seen in the chest X-ray as an area void of lung vascularity and a thin white line of visceral pleura that is separated from the parietal pleura by air.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes for a regular gynecological check-up. Pap smear testing showed HSIL. Therefore, biopsy was done, which showed dysplastic changes in 2/3rd of the epithelial thickness. What is the diagnosis?

HSIL - High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this patient is cervical intraepithelial neoplasia II (CIN II).

CIN is the histopathological description of a partial/full-thickness stratified squamous epithelium replaced by dysplastic cells arranged in a disorderly manner (abnormally altered morphology). However, the basement membrane remains intact, distinguishing it from cervical cancer.

Diagnosis is mainly based on routine screening as most women are asymptomatic (some may complain of postcoital bleeding/discharge or postmenopausal bleeding). Routine screening should start with sexually active (for more than three years) women above 21 years of age and should be repeated every 3-5 years until the age of 65 years.

Pap smear testing is done to identify cervical dysplasia, and the findings are classified according to the Bethesda system of cytology reporting, as follows:

  • Atypical squamous cells: Ascus - atypical cells of undetermined significance and ASC-H - cannot rule out high-grade lesion
  • Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL): includes CIN I
  • High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL): includes CIN II and CIN III
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

As the presence of an infection can produce false-positive findings, human papillomavirus (HPV) testing is also done along with Pap smear screening. Patients who are found to have HSIL are further subjected to biopsy. This is done by colposcopic study for the visual inspection with acetic acid (VIA) for acetowhite areas and taking biopsies of abnormal areas.

CIN, along with multiple sexual partners and infection with HPV strains 16, 18, 31, and 33, is a major predisposing high-risk factor for cervical cancer; thus, the need for routine screening in women.

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

questions.text: How will you diagnose the presence of ectopic mucosa in Meckel's diverticulum?
questions.solution:
99mTc-pertechnetate is used to diagnose the presence of ectopic mucosa in Meckel's diverticulum.

Meckel's diverticulum has a 2:1 male predominance and is the most common congenital anomaly of the small intestine. It is situated on the antimesenteric border of the ileum, usually 45 to 60 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve, and occurs due to incomplete closure of the vitelline duct.

It can present as

  • incidental findings during surgery
  • gastrointestinal bleeding in the form of hemorrhage in children
  • intestinal obstruction in the form of volvulus, intussusception (urge to defecate, vomiting, red current stools) 
  • diverticulitis (right lower quadrant pain)

In children, 99mTc-pertechnetate is preferentially taken up by the mucus-secreting cells of gastric mucosa and ectopic gastric tissue in Meckel's diverticulum and is the most accurate diagnostic modality. However, in adults, less ectopic gastric tissue is seen, so the test is not very accurate. The sensitivity and specificity can be improved by the use of cimetidine.

In case of false-negative results, barium studies, mesenteric arteriography, or double-balloon endoscopy can be used for diagnosis.

Treatment is diverticulectomy or segmental resection of ileum containing diverticulum. In children, an incidentally found asymptomatic diverticulum has to be resected. 

Related Pearl: Rule of two’s in Meckel's diverticulum

  • 2% prevalence
  • 2:1 male predominance
  • Located approx 2 feet (60 cm) proximal to the ileocecal valve in adults
  • Approx 2 inches in length
  • Half of those who are symptomatic are under 2 years of age.
  • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)

Related Pearl: The most commons in GIT

Most common Structure/Conditions
Congenital intestinal atresia Imperforate anus
True diverticulum Meckel's diverticulum
Site of ischemia Colon
Site of fistulization Esophagus
Site of GI polyp Colorectum
Malignancy of GI tract Adenocarcinoma colon
Cause of esophagitis Acid reflux
Benign tumor of the esophagus Leiomyoma
Esophageal cancer in India and worldwide Squamous cell carcinoma
Esophageal cancer in Western countries Adenocarcinoma
Type of chronic gastritis Type B gastritis (Helicobacter pylori gastritis)
Malignancy of the stomach Adenocarcinoma
Site of extranodal lymphoma Stomach
Mesenchymal tumor of the stomach Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST)
Tumor of small intestine/appendix Carcinoid

questions.text: A 20-year-old primigravida is in labor and it was noted that the action potentials of a single unit of myometrium caused the entire uterus to contract or relax simultaneously. This is possible due to the presence of which intercellular connections?
questions.solution:
The intercellular connections responsible for the myometrial cells causing the entire uterus to contract or relax simultaneously are gap junctions. During the time of labour, the number of these gap junctions is also increased under the influence of estrogen, thereby increasing the intensity of uterine contractility. 

Gap junctions are intercellular junctions that allow the passage of ions and smaller molecules between the cells. It permits rapid cell-to-cell spread of action potentials that provide for coordinated and smooth contraction. 

They are present in intercalated discs, uterus, urinary bladder, ureter, choroid plexus between the cells etc. The cells in these organs constitute a unit or syncytium containing thousands of smooth muscle fibres that contract together as a single unit. 

 Thus, the functions of gap junctions include - 
  • Passage of ions, sugars, amino acids, and other solutes with molecular weight up to about 1000 Da. It permits these substances to pass between the cells without entering the extracellular fluid. 
  • Provide both chemical and electrical coupling between cells. 

The structural unit present in the gap junctions is connexons, made of subunits called connexins. These connexons determine the permeability and selectivity of these junctions. 

Mutations of the connexin have predisposed to conditions like arteriosclerosis, myoclonic epilepsy, idiopathic atrial fibrillation, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (X-linked) etc. 

 

Other options - 

Option B: Tight junctions or zonula occludens are present around the apical margins of the cells in epithelia such as the intestinal mucosa, the walls of the renal tubules, and the choroid plexus. They have ridges, half from each cell which adheres so strongly that there is no space between the cells. These tight junctions permit the passage of ions, solutes, and intracellular signalling molecules in between adjacent cells via the paracellular pathway.

Option C: Hemidesmosomes attach cells to the underlying basal lamina and are connected intracellularly to intermediate filaments. They contain integrins.

Option D: Adherent junctions or zonula adherens is a continuous structure on the basal side of the zonula occludens. It contains cadherins.

questions.text: You observe a patient in the neurology ward with dysphagia, dysarthria, and dysphonia. On examination, brisk jaw jerk is seen. Imaging studies reveal bilateral corticobulbar lesions. What is the possible diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A patient presenting with dysphagia, dysarthria, dysphonia, and brisk jaw jerk along with an imaging finding of bilateral corticobulbar lesions points to a diagnosis of pseudobulbar palsy. 

Bilateral corticobulbar lesions produce pseudobulbar palsy which is an example of upper motor neuron palsy. It has the following features:   chewing, weakness of the facial muscles, dysarthria, palatal weakness and regurgitation of fluids, dysphagia, and dysphonia.

Other options:

Option A - Syringomyelia is a disease of the central spinal cord, caused by an enlargening syrinx within the central canal leading to compressive symptoms. It is characterized by wasting of muscles in the lower neck, shoulder, asymmetric or absent reflexes in the arms, and arms along with loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper limbs.  

Option B - Syringobulbia occurs when the syrinx of syringomyelia extends into the medulla. It is characterized by palatal or vocal cord paralysis, episodic vertigo tongue weakness with atrophy, and horizontal nystagmus. 

Option C - Bulbar palsy presents with lower motor neuron paralysis which include clinical features such as fasiculations, hypotonia, increased muscle wastage, absent Babinski's sign, decreased muscle stretch reflexes and segmental distribution of weakness more distally while pseudobulbar palsy presents with upper motor neuron paralysis features such as increased spasticity, hypertonia, involvement of lower part of the face, rigidity and brisk reflexes.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy had abdominal pain for the past 1 week and associated swelling of his knees with non-blanching rashes. His platelet levels were normal. What is the probable immunoglobulin involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a boy presenting with abdominal pain, swelling of knees, non-blanching rashes, and a normal platelet count is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein purpura. The immunoglobulin involved in the pathogenesis of this condition is IgA.

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a common small vessel vasculitis in childhood. Vasculitis occurs due to immune complex depositions involving IgA. It is characterized by a purpuric rash and is commonly accompanied by arthritis and abdominal pain. Renal manifestations vary from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis.

Laboratory studies generally show a mild leukocytosis, a normal platelet count, and occasionally eosinophilia. IgA and C3 complements are elevated in the serum.

questions.text: In a patient with a head injury who presents with fixed dilated pupils and rapidly deteriorating neurological signs, where is the burr hole made?

choices.text: Temporal region contralateral to the side of pupillary dilatation
Midline as it is not known which side of pupil dilated first
Left temporal region if no localising sign found
Right temporal region if no localising sign found

questions.solution:
In the given situation, the best choice would be to do a burr hole in the left temporal region since no localizing sign was found and it is not known which pupil dilated first.

When making the initial burr hole, the temporal region is entered first. The side chosen for this initial temporal burr hole depends on the following:

  • In > 85% of cases starting ipsilateral to a dilated pupil will be the correct side 
  • If both pupils are dilated, use the side of the first dilating pupil, if known
  • If pupils are equal, or it is not known which side dilated first, place the burr hole on the side of obvious external trauma
  • If there are no localization clues, hole is placed on the left side – to evaluate and decompress the dominant hemisphere.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man previously with a fall on an outstretched hand was managed conservatively. Now he presents with persistent pain and swelling in that hand. X-ray shows a visible fracture line with little bridging callus and rounded fracture ends. Which of the following fractures has resulted in this complication?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a history of fall on an outstretched hand which is now presenting as visible fracture line with little bridging callus and rounded fracture ends in the x-ray is suggestive of non-union of scaphoid fracture.

Non-union is defined as a fracture that has not healed for the past 9 months and is due to mechanical instability or impaired vascularity.

The blood supply of a bone influences the healing after fracture. Certain anatomical sites have limited blood supply. It includes the talar neck, the proximal metaphyseal–diaphyseal junction of the fifth metatarsal, the femoral neck, and
the waist of the scaphoid. These sites are prone to developing non-union of the fracture site.

Radiologically, a lucent line with either increased or absent bridging callus (in hypertrophic and atrophic non-union respectively) is seen between the bone fragments in non-union.

Lunate fracture (option B) is rare and it has the risk of non-union. Malunion is the most common complication in fractures of the distal radius (option C) and can occur in fractures of the metacarpal neck (option D) usually in the fifth finger.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man who is a  known case of hypertension was started on a beta-blocker. Which of the following adverse effects is least likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Sedation is least likely to be seen with beta-blockers. Beta-blockers usually cause sleep disturbances like insomnia and nightmares.

The main adverse effects of beta-blockers are:

  • Cardiovascular side effects - exacerbation of heart failure, bradyarrhythmias, cold extremities, worsening of peripheral vascular disease, Raynaud phenomenon.
  • Respiratory side effects like life-threatening bronchoconstriction can occur.
  • Neurological side effects include fatigue. insomnia, nightmares and depression.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman complains of urine dribbling from the vagina. On further examination and investigation, she is diagnosed with a vesicovaginal fistula. Which of the following is a criterion for classifying the condition as complicated vesicovaginal fistula?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the criterion for classification as a complicated vesicovaginal fistula is a size of > 3 cm.

A vesicovaginal fistula can be classified as simple or complicated. Their features are given in the table below. 

Simple  Complicated
Size < or = 3 cm Size > 3 cm
Located near the cuff or supratrigonal Located away from the cuff / there is involvement of trigone 
No prior malignancy Pelvic malignancy present
No prior radiation Prior radiation therapy
Vaginal length remains normal Vaginal length shortened

Vesicovaginal fistulas mostly result either from any form of obstetric trauma like prolonged or obstructed labour or complicated caesarian delivery or as a complication of pelvic surgeries like hysterectomy.

Patients usually present with unexplained, continuous urinary leakage from the vagina after a recent procedure. Other non-specific symptoms include fever, pain, ileus and bladder irritability.

Clinical assessment by the introduction of a speculum helps to determine the size, number, and location of the fistulae. A methylene blue test helps confirm the diagnosis and determine the type of repair operation.

The repair operation includes the Latzko procedure. The procedure involves denuding the vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges and approximating the raw surfaces. Another is the Chassar-Moir technique of widely separating the bladder and vagina and suturing them separately in two layers.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

 

Related Pearl: Methylene blue - 3 swab test

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. A diluted solution of methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a transurethral catheter. After 15 to 30 minutes, the swabs are removed serially and inspected for dye.

Interpretation:

  • Upper swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lower swab gets stained - the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child came to the hospital for treatment of acute leukemia. He suffers from a rare congenital disorder known as  Bloom syndrome.  What is the defective mechanism that has caused the disorder?

choices.text: Defective non homologous end joining repair

questions.solution:
Bloom syndrome is a rare congenital disorder associated with defective homologous repair and patients with this disorder are at risk of developing acute leukemia.

It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by the loss of function mutations in a helicase that is needed for a homologous recombination repair. The individuals have developmental anomalies and are at increased risk for developing different types of cancers.

Other options:

Option A: Defective Nonhomologous End-Joining Repair (NHEJ) is seen in severe combined immunodeficiency disease.  It comprises a group of genetically distinct syndromes, having defects in cell-mediated and humoral immunity. Affected infants present with thrush, diaper rash, and failure to thrive.

Option C: Defective DNA mismatch repair is associated with hereditary non-polyposis colonic cancer (HNPCC). It is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with carcinomas of the colon and caecum. Affected individuals inherit an abnormal copy of the mismatch repair gene.

Option D: DNA nucleotide excision repair (NER) is defective in xeroderma pigmentosum. Inherited loss of function mutations in the genes responsible for the repair mechanisms gives rise to xeroderma pigmentosum. It is characterized by a high risk of skin cancers.

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

DNA damage repair type

Diseases

Defective Nonhomologous End Joining Repair (NHEJ)

Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID)

Radiation sensitive severe combined immunodeficiency disease(RS-SCID)

Defective Homologous Repair (HR)

AT-like disorder (ATLD)

Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS)

Bloom syndrome (BS)

Werner syndrome (WS)

Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS)

Breast cancer suspectibility 1 and 2 (BRCA1, BRCA2)

Defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP)

Cockayne syndrome (CS)

Defective DNA Base Excision Repair (BER)

questions.text: A teenage patient presented with a history of dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. On ultrasonography, a transverse vaginal septum was seen. What is the most common complication that can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most common complication that can be seen in this patient is endometriosis.

Transverse vaginal septum leads to obstructed flow of menstrual blood. This may lead to retrograde menstruation, which increases the likelihood of the development of endometriosis, according to Sampson's theory of endometriosis.

Transverse vaginal septum occurs as a result of the failure of Müllerian duct fusion or failure of vaginal plate canalization. It may be obstructive or non-obstructive. The commonest site of a transverse septum is the junction between the upper and middle third of the vagina.

Patients with an obstructive or imperforate vaginal septum present with symptoms similar to the imperforate hymen. Symptoms include amenorrhoea, cyclical abdominal pain, urinary symptoms, and a palpable pelvic mass. The vagina may appear shortened and the cervix may not be identifiable. Secondary sexual characteristics appear normal. The diagnosis can be confirmed with ultrasound or MRI.

There is an increased risk of endometriosis. Other complications such as pyomucocolpos, pyometra, and pyosalpinges can also develop in infants with obstructive vaginal septums. 

Treatment is by manual dilatation of the perforation or surgical excision of the septum. 

Other options:

Option B: Tubo-ovarian abscess develops in pelvic inflammatory disease.

Option C: Dermoid cysts are cystic ovarian tumors that are often associated with mucinous cystadenomas.

Option D: Theca lutein cysts are found in association with hydatidiform moles, choriocarcinoma, and gonadotropin or clomiphene citrate therapy. They regress with the management of the mole and choriocarcinoma and discontinuation of gonadotropin therapy.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.

  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.

questions.text: A 3 year old boy playing unsupervised was brought with complaints of difficulty in breathing  for the last few hours.  The X-ray image is given below. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Urgent endoscopy and removal of foreign body
Remove the foreign body within 2 hours

questions.solution:
The clinical picture of the child presenting with difficulty in breathing and the given x-rays are suggestive of a foreign body lodged in the esophagus, most likely a coin and the most appropriate management is urgent endoscopy and removal of the foreign body. 

The given x-rays are anteroposterior and lateral views of the chest and neck showing the flat surface and edge of the coin respectively. Coins, disk batteries, and small toy items are commonly ingested by children. 

Initial symptoms are choking, gagging, and coughing followed by excessive salivation, dysphagia, food refusal, vomiting, or pain in the neck and throat. Respiratory symptoms such as stridor, wheezing, cyanosis, or dyspnea are seen if esophageal foreign body impinges on the larynx or tracheal wall.

Imaging with AP views of chest, neck, and abdominal x-rays and lateral views of chest and neck x-rays should be done. Chest CT is warranted if airway perforation is suspected.

Treatment:

  • Asymptomatic patients with blunt objects/coin ingestion can be observed for up to 24 hours to wait for the passage of the coin into the stomach (option A)
  • Immediate endoscopic visualization must be done in symptomatic patients. Flexible endoscopy with suitable grasping forceps is used to remove the foreign bodies. 
  • Button batteries should be removed within 2 hours (Option C) since they can induce a mucosal injury as early as one hr and can invade all the layers within 4 hrs. They can resemble a coin but are differentiated by the double halo on the X-ray.

questions.text: A 15-month-old child who is posted for a minor surgical procedure is brought by his mother for preoperative evaluation. What would be the recommended period of fasting for this child?

choices.text: 6 hours for light meal, 2 hours for clear fluids
6 hours for fried foods, 2 hours for clear fluids
6  hours for light meal, 4 hours for clear fluids
6 hours for fried foods, 4 hours for clear fluids

questions.solution:
The recommended preoperative fasting period for this child is 6 hours for a light meal and 2 hours for clear fluids.

Recommended preoperative fasting periods for all above 1 year of age are 2 hours for clear fluids, 6 hours for a light meal, and 8 hours for fried, fatty food.

Recommended preoperative fasting periods for neonates and infants are 6 hours for solids/ formula feeds/ cow's milk, and 4 hours for breast milk.

The goal of recommending preoperative fasting periods is to reduce the risk of pulmonary aspiration.

questions.text: Which among the following is a role of an accredited social health activist (ASHA)?

choices.text: Review and consolidate reports received from the health workers
Supervise deliveries conducted by dais and assist them
Organize and conduct tubectomy and vasectomy camps
Act as a depot holder for provisions such as condoms and drug kits

questions.solution:
It is the role of an accredited social health activist (ASHA) to act as a depot holder for essential provisions such as condoms and drug kits.

An ASHA is a trained female community health activist and a resident woman of the village with a formal education of up to eighth grade. She should preferably be in the age group of 25 to 45 years and have qualities such as good communication skills and leadership skills. The general norm of selection recommends having one ASHA for 1000 population but in tribal, hilly, and desert areas the norm could be relaxed to one ASHA per habitation.

 Other roles of ASHA:

  • To create awareness and provide information to the community on determinants of health such as nutrition, basic sanitation, and hygienic practices
  • To counsel women on birth preparedness, the importance of safe delivery, breast-feeding, complementary feeding, immunization, and contraception
  • To counsel women on the prevention of common infections including reproductive tract infection/ sexually transmitted infection 
  • To mobilize the community and facilitate their access to health and health-related services
  • To arrange and escort pregnant women and children requiring treatment/admission to the nearest pre-identified health facility
  • To inform the sub-center/ primary health center about the births and deaths in her village and any unusual health problems/ disease outbreaks in the community
  • To promote the construction of household toilets under the total sanitation campaign

Other options: 

Option A: Reviewing and consolidating reports received from the health workers is the role of a female health assistant. 

Option B: Supervision of deliveries conducted by dais and assisting them is the role of a female health worker called auxiliary nursing midwifery (ANM).

Option C: The organization and conduction of tubectomy and vasectomy camps is done by a medical officer of a primary health center.  

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: A 21-year-old boy comes to the clinic in summer with red plaques over axillae and inguinal folds. A biopsy of the skin lesions revealed a ‘dilapidated brick wall’ appearance. What is the most likely reason for this appearance?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathological appearance are indicative of Hailey-Hailey disease. The reason for the dilapidated brick wall appearance is the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes, which occurs due to the breakdown of intercellular bridges.

Hailey–Hailey disease is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by erosions and blistering in the flexures. It typically presents between the second and fourth decade with painful, pruritic, and often malodorous lesions of flexures or other sites of friction.

Secondary infection with Staphylococcus aureus (most common), Herpes simplex virus and Candida is a common complication. A skin biopsy helps confirm the diagnosis. The histology of lesions demonstrates widespread acantholysis, with acantholytic clefts and bullae seen suprabasally. Mild dyskeratosis may also be present, as seen in the image below.

Secondary infection with, Staphylococcus aureus, viruses like herpes simplex virus and Candida is a common complication. A skin biopsy helps confirm the diagnosis.

First-line treatment involves a reduction in friction, with the use of emollients and a moderately potent topical steroid. Long‐term antibiotics may be required for those with secondary infections.

 

Other options:

Option A: Widening of intercellular spaces between keratinocytes due to fluid accumulation is seen in spongiosis. It is seen in acute and subacute eczematous reactions.

Option B: An increase in the number of keratinocytes in the prickle cell layer of the epidermis is seen in acanthosis. Some of the conditions that it is seen in include psoriasis, epidermal naevi, viral warts, lichen planus, melanoma, Darier's disease, etc

Option D: Nuclear pyknosis and bright pink condensation of the cytoplasm of keratinocytes is an abnormality in epithelial cell keratinization and refers to dyskeratosis. It is seen in squamous cell carcinoma, Bowen disease, solar keratosis, and Darier disease.

Related Pearl: Classification of Vesiculobullous Disorders

According to Pathology

  • Immunobullous disorders/ Primary blistering disease: occur due to autoimmunity

Intraepidermal

Subepidermal

Pemphigus vulgaris

Bullous pemphigoid

Pemphigus foliaceous

Pemphigus vegetans

 Epidermolysis bullous acquisita
 Pemphigus erythematosus  
  • Mechanobullous disorders: Due to defect in the structure of epidermis
    • Epidermolysis bullosa
    • Bullous ichthyosiform erythroderma
  • Other disorders
    • Infections - VZV, HSV, Bullous impetigo, SSSS
    • Metabolic - Porphyria, Diabetes, Hemodialysis
    • Drug eruptions - Fixed drug eruption, Steven Johnson Syndrome, Erythema Multiforme

According to Site

Intraepidermal

Sub-epidermal (Dermo-epidermal)

1. Subcorneal (granular layer)

  • Pemphigus foliaceous & erythematosus
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
  • Miliaria crystalina
  • Bullous impetigo
  • Friction blister
  • Subcorneal pustular dermatosis

2. Spinous layer

  • Eczematous (atopic) dermatitis
  • HSV/VZV infection
  • Molluscum contagiosum
  • Familial benign pemphigus (Hailey-hailey disease)

3. Suprabasal

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Darrier’s disease

4. Basal layer

  • Erythema multiforme
  • Epidermolysis bullosa simplex

1. Junctional (at basal lamina)

  • Junctional epidermolysis bullosa
  • Bullous pemphigoid
  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis

2. Dermolytic (below basal lamina)

  • Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita
  • Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophicans
  • Deep burns
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda

questions.text: A retired 65-year-old man was found to have a mass in the right lower lobe of the lung on chest x-ray. A  biopsy sample was taken from the mass. The image below shows the findings of histopathological examination and Immunohistochemical staining with calretinin. Which of the following was the most likely profession of the patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing malignant epithelioid mesothelioma (a neoplasm most commonly associated with asbestos exposure) is most likely suggestive of asbestosis. Hence, the most likely profession of this patient would be an asbestos factory worker.

The histopathological image shows cuboidal and flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma. These are strongly positive for calretinin. These features point toward the diagnosis of malignant epithelioid mesothelioma. The most common cancer associated with asbestosis is lung adenocarcinoma; however, mesothelioma is the most specific malignancy.

Malignant mesothelioma is a rare and aggressive malignant tumor of the pleura, associated with heavy asbestos exposure. It arises from either the visceral or parietal pleura. Less common sites include the peritoneum, pericardium, tunica vaginalis, and genital tract. 

Clinical features include chest pain, dyspnea, and recurrent pleural effusions. The lung is invaded directly, and metastatic spread may involve the hilar lymph nodes, the liver, and other distant organs. 

Grossly, it appears as a diffuse lesion arising either from the visceral or parietal pleura. The affected lung is ensheathed by a thick layer of soft, gelatinous, greyish-pink tumor tissue.

The image given below shows the gross pathology of mesothelioma:

Microscopically, they are of three types:

  • Epithelial - shows cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma
  • Sarcomatous/mesenchymal- has a histological appearance resembling fibrosarcoma
  • Biphasic/mixed

The image given below shows an epithelioid type of mesothelioma showing cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma.

The image given below shows malignant mesothelioma under immunohistochemical staining with calretinin.

Other options :

Option B: Sandblasters are at increased risk of developing silicosis. Silicosis is associated with the calcification of hilar lymph nodes, which leads to the appearance of eggshell calcification. Histopathology in silicosis shows whorled collagen fibers. HRCT in patients with silicosis shows a characteristic crazy paving pattern.

The image below shows whorled collagen in a silicosis nodule:

 

Option C: Welders are at increased risk of exposure to iron oxide, leading to siderosis.

 

Option D: Coal miners are at increased risk of developing coal workers' pneumoconiosis.  

The image below shows histopathological appearance of coal worker's pneumoconiosis:

Related Pearl: Differentiation of Mesothelioma from Adenocarcinoma
