questions.text: Which of the following causes the inactivation of acetyl-CoA carboxylase?
questions.solution:
Phosphorylation causes inactivation of the enzyme acetyl CoA carboxylase.

Acetyl-CoA carboxylase plays an important role in regulating fatty acid synthesis. It converts acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA in the presence of ATP and also requires the coenzyme biotin. This reaction also requires bicarbonate as a source of carbon dioxide.

The enzyme is activated by citrate, dephosphorylation, and insulin hormone and inactivated by phosphorylation, glucagon, epinephrine, and acyl CoA.

Related Pearl: Fatty Acid Synthesis Pathway

Steps

Reactions

Activation

Acetyl-CoA carboxylation

Elongation

The malonyl-CoA pathway

Condensation step 

Covalent linking of acetyl-CoA and Malonyl-CoA (with the release of CoA and carbon dioxide)

Reduction step 

Acetoacetyl-ACP to ß-hydroxybutryl-ACP (using up one NADPH2)

Dehydration step 

ß-hydroxybutryl-ACP to crotonyl-ACP (with the release of a water molecule)

Another reduction step

Crotonyl-ACP to butryl-ACP (using up a second NADPH2)

questions.text: A middle-aged man was brought to the casualty after being assaulted with a sharp axe and is found to have a wound over his scalp as shown in the image below. Identify the type of wound sustained.
questions.solution:
From the history of assault with a sharp axe (sharp heavy weapon) and given image showing deep gaping wound margins, the type of wound sustained is a chop wound.

Chop wounds are deep gaping wounds caused by a blow with the sharp cutting edge of a fairly heavy weapon like an axe, sword, meat cleaver, or hatchet. The dimensions of the wound correspond to the cross-section of the penetrating portion of the blade. The margins of the wound depend on the condition of the weapon, a sharp margin with slight bruising is seen with a sharp-edged weapon, and a ragged and bruised margin is seen with a blunt edge. Undermining occurs in the direction towards which the chop is made.

Other options:

Option A: An incised wound is clean-cut, regular, well-defined caused by sharp lightweight weapons like a knife, razor, scalpel, etc. Incised wounds will have a characteristic head of wound and tailing of a wound.

The image below shows two spindle-shaped incisions:

Option C: A laceration involves tearing or splitting of the skin, mucous membrane, muscle, or any internal organ, with its depth being more than the covering epithelium of the skin and is produced by the application of blunt force.

Option D: Stab wounds are caused by penetration with long narrow instruments of pointed ends into the body cavity, which are of two types - penetrating wounds have only entry wounds and perforating have both entry and exit and exit wounds.

The image below shows a fishtail in a stab wound:

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with a thyroid swelling underwent thyroidectomy and the histopathological examination of the specimen shows the following image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Orphan Annie eye nuclei seen on histopathological examination of a neck swelling in a middle-aged female suggests a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid (PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy with a female preponderance and peaking in the 3rd-5th decade.

Risk factors include radiation exposure and a family history of thyroid carcinoma. Mostly, patients are asymptomatic or they might present with a palpable thyroid nodule. It mainly metastasizes through the lymphatic route.

Comprehensive thyroid ultrasound with bilateral central and lateral neck lymph nodes mapping should be done as part of the imaging workup. Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI of the neck and chest and intraluminal imaging (laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, or esophagoscopy) may be required in patients with potentially more advanced local and regional disease.

Management includes

  • ipsilateral thyroid lobectomy for a low-risk, unilateral, 1-4 cm tumor without extrathyroidal extension/ evidence of metastatic disease as well as for a tumor that is < 1 cm in size. 
  • total thyroidectomy if high risk of recurrence.

The below image shows orphan Annie eye nuclei-

Histopathological features:

  • Branching papillae
  • Orphan Annie eye nuclei are nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin  
  • Psammoma bodies are concentric calcified structures within the papillae

 

Other options-

Option B: Follicular carcinoma shows uniform cells forming small follicles and they are filled with colloid and normal thyroid tissue. The below image shows follicular thyroid carcinoma.

 

 

Option C: Medullary carcinoma has polygonal to spindle-shaped cells forming nests or trabeculae and contains amyloid deposits in the stroma. The below image shows medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option D: Anaplastic carcinoma shows large pleomorphic giant cells, spindle cells, and, mixed cells. The below image shows anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Malignancy - Most Commons

  • Most common primary thyroid malignancy – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid - Medullary carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma
  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis - Papillary carcinoma

questions.text: A male patient was diagnosed with an aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery. He has ocular symptoms suggestive of third cranial nerve palsy. Which of the muscles marked in the given image is not supplied by this nerve?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked as '3' in the image is superior oblique, which is innervated by the trochlear nerve (4th cranial nerve). The other muscles marked in the image, i.e., 1- superior rectus, 2- levator palpebrae superioris, and 4- inferior oblique, are supplied by the oculomotor nerve (3rd cranial nerve).

Muscles present around the eye:

  • Levator palpebrae superioris - elevates the upper eyelids
  • Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique

Levator palpebrae superioris originates from the lesser wing of the sphenoid, anterior to the optic canal. It inserts into the tarsal plate, superior conjunctival fornix, and skin. 

The four recti muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera in the anterior half of the eyeball.

The superior oblique originates from the body of the sphenoid, superior and medial to optic canal. The inferior oblique originates from the medial floor of the orbit and maxilla. They are inserted into the sclera of the outer posterior quadrant of the eyeball in the superior surface and inferior surface, respectively.

All the extraocular muscles (including the inferior oblique) are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

  • Lateral rectus, which is innervated by the abducens (VI) nerve
  • Superior oblique, which is innervated by the trochlear (IV) nerve

Related Pearl: Extraocular Muscles and Their Actions

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient comes to your clinic with a rash shown in the image below. The onset was insidious and the rashes are mildly itchy. Wood's lamp shows pale yellow fluorescence. Microscopy of the causative organism would show which of the following morphological features?

choices.text: Sclerotic cells with brownish cell walls

questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and image are of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor. It is caused by fungi belonging to the Malassezia species which on microscopic examination shows the presence of yeasts and hyphae in skin scrapings.

Malassezia species are lipophilic fungi. They cause degradation of lipids producing acids like azelaic acid that inhibit tyrosinase, resulting in hypopigmented patches. 

Malassezia species that are commonly involved in Tinea versicolor are-

  • Malassezia globosa
  • Malassezia sympodialis
  • Malassezia furfur

Clinically, Tinea versicolor presents with hypopigmented patches or hyperpigmented or reddish patches due to inflammation. It commonly affects the upper trunk, upper arms, neck, and abdomen. They are mildly itchy if at all and have fine scales that are branny/furfuraceous.

Under Wood's lamp examination, the lesions show a pale yellow fluorescence. On KOH mount and microscopy the Malassezia species appear as short unbranched, non-pigmented hyphae and spherical cells. This is also called the ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ appearance or ‘bananas and grapes’ appearance. 

Treatment involves selenium sulfide, topical or oral azoles. 

The image attached below shows the classic spaghetti and meatballs appearance on KOH mount.

 

Other options: 

Option A: Sclerotic cells with brownish cell walls are observed in chromoblastomycosis.

Option B: Sulfur granules are observed in mycetoma infection.

Option D: Yeasts with capsules are characteristic of cryptococcosis.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo

Ivory or milky white

questions.text: You are assigned to a  team investigating a community outbreak of diarrhoea in a tribal area. The detection of which organism will provide definitive proof of faecal contamination?
questions.solution:
Escherichia coli is used as an indicator and provides definitive proof of faecal contamination. According to WHO drinking water safety guidelines, E.coli should not be detectable in any 100 ml sample.

The presence of faecal pollution in a water sample suggests that the water from which the sample was drawn may be contaminated with enteric pathogens. Two tests are done in succession to identify the presence of E.coli:

  • Presumptive coliform count is calculated by inoculation of the water sample into tubes containing a suitable liquid medium which are then incubated and examined after the appropriate period. 
  • Differential coliform count/ Eijkman test is done, following the presumptive test, by taking subcultures made from all the bottles showing acid and gas to fresh tubes containing pre-warmed MacConkey medium which are examined after 24 hours. Tubes exhibiting gas are deemed to contain E.Coli which is definitive proof of faecal contamination.

Other factors used in the assessment of the quality of drinking water are pH, turbidity (or particle count), odour and colour.

The guideline values set by WHO for some chemicals are as follows:

  • Fluoride - 1.5mg/litre.(Guidelines can vary according to the region due to differences in the volume of water consumed and intake from other sources)
  • Nitrate : 50 mg/litre
  • Nitrite  : 3 mg/litre
  • Inorganic mercury 0.006 mg/litre
  • Chromium: 0.05 mg/litre
  • Cadmium 0.006
  • Benzene: 0.01 mg/litre

 

Other options: 

Option A- Recent faecal contamination of water is suggested by the presence of enterococcus (faecal streptococci). Faecal streptococci are found in faeces, but in much smaller numbers than E.coli. Only in doubtful cases, the finding of faecal streptococci in water is regarded as important confirmatory evidence of recent faecal pollution of water. Streptococci are useful for routine control testing after laying new pipelines or repairs in distribution systems and to detect groundwater contamination.

Option C- Clostridium perfringens also occur regularly in faeces, but in much smaller numbers than E.coli. The spores are capable of surviving in water for a long time, and they usually resist chlorination. The presence of spores of Clostridium perfringens in natural water suggests that faecal contamination has occurred. But in the absence of the coliform group, it suggests that faecal contamination is long ago. They can also be used to assess filtration systems.

Option D- Bacteroides species are an indicator for the effectiveness of disinfection and physical removal processes for viruses but are not applicable in regular monitoring and surveillance.

questions.text: In a microbiology lab, 50% of employees received the prophylactic pneumococcal pneumonia vaccine while the remaining 50% did not. Which of the following statistical tests can be used to see whether the vaccination program made any difference in the health outcomes of the employees?
questions.solution:
The Chi-square test is the statistical test that can be used to determine whether the vaccination program made any difference in the health outcomes of the employees. This is because it can test for differences in two or more categories when all the variables are qualitative or nominal (variables having two or more categories and a natural ranking or ordering). The variables in this case are qualitative.

The Chi-square test is a non-parametric test of significance employed for two proportions using qualitative variables. It has the advantage of being of use when more than two groups are to be compared. It also offers information on the significance of any observed differences.

Other options:

Option A: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option B: The student’s t-test is used for quantitative data. Here the data is qualitative, hence it can't be used.

Option C: Medical record linkage is the assembly and maintenance of a file for each individual in a population using important records relating to his health. It is a suitable method of studying associations between diseases.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Inhibition by Renshaw cells is being studied by a physiologist. All of the following are the properties of these cells, except:
questions.solution:
Feedforward inhibition is not a property exhibited by Renshaw cells. 

Renshaw cells are involved in feedback inhibition and lateral inhibition.

Feedback inhibition (Recurrent inhibition): Signals from neurons may inhibit themselves by negative feedback. This is known as feedback inhibition or recurrent inhibition. Signals from a neuron may stimulate the Renshaw cell, which in turn inhibits the same neuron.

Lateral inhibition: Stimulation of one motor neuron inhibits adjacent motor neurons. This is known as lateral inhibition. Signals from the spinal motor neurons stimulate Renshaw cells, which are inhibitory interneurons. Renshaw cells transmit inhibitory signals to the adjacent motor neurons, by releasing the neurotransmitter glycine. This helps in sharpening signals in order to maintain the desired direction of signal transmission. 

Feedforward inhibition: Signals from neurons stimulate inhibitory cells. These inhibitory cells then inhibit a different group of neurons. This is called feedforward inhibition. For example, granule cells stimulate the inhibitory basket cells and stellate cells via parallel fibers. These basket and stellate cells then inhibit the Purkinje cells. This is known as feedforward inhibition.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was admitted to the hospital with recurrent infections. His gait was uncoordinated and ocular examination revealed ocular telangiectasia in the right eye. Which of the following is the most likely mode of inheritance of the disease described in the clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of uncoordinated gait and ocular telangiectasia in the given scenario are suggestive of ataxia-telangiectasia, and the mode of inheritance of this disease is autosomal recessive.

Ataxia-telangiectasia is a syndrome complex that comprises neurologic, immunologic, endocrinologic, and cutaneous disorders. The gene involved in this condition is the mutation in the ATM gene mapped to the long arm of chromosome 11(11q22-23). There is defective DNA repair and increased sensitivity to ionizing radiation. A hypoplastic thymus is present in this condition.

The age of onset of telangiectasia is around 3 to 6 years. By 12 years of age, affected children are usually confined to wheelchairs due to progressive ataxia. 

Clinical features:

  • Progressive cerebellar ataxia
  • Oculocutaneous telangiectasias
  • Chronic sinopulmonary disease
  • High incidence of malignancy: adenocarcinomas and lymphoreticular tumors (lymphoma, leukemia, and Hodgkin's disease)
  • Humoral and cellular immunodeficiency

questions.text: A 28-year-old man, homozygotic for atypical pseudocholinesterase, is set to undergo surgery. The response expected in this patient on administering succinylcholine and the dibucaine number would be:

choices.text: Prolonged duration of action, Dibucaine number 80
Prolonged duration of action, Dibucaine number 20
Shorter duration of action, Dibucaine number 80
Shorter duration of action, Dibucaine number 20

questions.solution:
The response expected in this patient on administering succinylcholine would be a prolonged duration of action of succinylcholine and a dibucaine number of 20.

This is due to the presence of homozygous atypical pseudocholinesterase enzyme in this patient.

Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant that is rapidly metabolized by pseudocholinesterase into succinylmonocholine as soon as it enters the circulation. 

Simultaneously, succinylcholine molecules diffuse away from the neuromuscular junction, the net effect being a reduced duration of action of succinylcholine.

Abnormal pseudocholinesterase enzyme resulting from homozygous or heterozygous gene defects, cannot metabolise succinylcholine efficiently, leading to a prolonged duration of action.

In patients heterozygous for the atypical pseudocholinesterase, the duration of action is prolonged modestly (2-20minutes) whereas in homozygotes it may be prolonged up to 4-8 hours.

Dibucaine is a local anaesthetic that inhibits normal pseudocholinesterase activity by about 80% but inhibits atypical enzyme activity by only 20% and the percentage of inhibition of pseudocholinesterase activity is called the dibucaine number. It is a measure of pseudocholinesterase function.

Therefore, a patient with normal pseudocholinesterase has a dibucaine number of 80 and a patient with homozygous abnormal pseudocholinesterase will have a dibucaine number of 20.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of diplopia, restricted eye movements, and inability to close the lids of his left eye. He previously sustained chemical burns to the same eye. On examination, the eye appears as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of diplopia, lagophthalmos, restricted eye movements with a history of chemical burns to the same eye and the image shown indicates a diagnosis of symblepharon.

It refers to the partial or complete adhesion of the palpebral conjunctiva to the bulbar conjunctiva. These adhesions occur when raw surfaces on two opposed areas of the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva remain in contact as they heal. The raw surfaces appear following chemical injuries, burns, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, ulcers, diphtheria, ocular pemphigus or eye surgeries.

Most patients present to resolve the cosmetic disfigurement caused as a result of this condition but can also have restricted eye movements, resulting in diplopia and an inability to close the lids, i.e. lagophthalmos.

When the bands of fibrous tissue subsequently formed between the lid and the globe involve the fornices, it is called symblepharon posterior. When they are present anteriorly, it is called symblepharon anterior. Sometimes, the lids may be completely adherent to the globe, in a condition called total symblepharon.

This condition is mostly managed surgically. The attachments are released and the raw areas are covered with a conjunctival, buccal mucous membrane or amniotic membrane grafts. A therapeutic contact lens or symblepharon ring may also be used to separate the raw surfaces.

The prevention of symblepharon by the early and frequent use of a glass rod or therapeutic bandage contact lens is of the utmost importance.

Other options:

Option A: Ankyloblepharon involves the presence of adhesions between the margins of the two lids.

Option B: Blepharophimosis is a condition where the palpebral fissure appears to be smaller than normal.

Option D: Ectoprion refers to the outward turning of the lid margin. Patients present with epiphora as the primary symptom, especially when the lower lid is involved. Other symptoms include local irritation, discomfort and mild photophobia when associated with chronic conjunctivitis.

questions.text: You are an intern in the OPD seeing a 3-year-old female child with severe disfigurement and photosensitivity. On examination, skin thickening and brownish teeth are seen. Urine examination reveals increased uroporphyrin 1.  What condition is she suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the increased levels of uroporphyrin 1 suggest that she is suffering from congenital erythropoietic porphyria, also known as Gunther's disease.

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria is an autosomal recessive porphyria due to the uroporphyrinogen III synthase defect. It presents with severe photosensitivity from birth, skin thickening, hypo and hyperpigmentation of the skin, and sun-exposed areas prone to infection and disfigurement. Hypertrichosis of the face and limbs may be seen. The skin over sun-exposed areas develops bullae and vesicles which can rupture and get infected. Brownish teeth may be seen due to the deposition of porphyrins. Hemolysis and splenomegaly may be seen.

Laboratory values show increased levels of urinary, fecal, and red cell uroporphyrin 1.

Treatment includes transfusions for treating the anemia, and splenectomy to reduce the hemolysis. Bacterial infections should be treated and protection from sunlight should be done.

Other options:

Option A: Erythropoietic protoporphyria is caused by the deficiency of Ferrochetalase and presents with photosensitivity.

Option B: Hereditary coproporphyria is due to deficient coproporphyrinogen oxidase (CPOX) and presents with abdominal pain, photosensitivity, and neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Option C: X-linked sideroblastic anemia is caused by deficient δ-aminolevulinate synthase 2 (ALAS 2) and manifests as anemia.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
