questions.text: A 29-year-old G2P1 comes to the physician at 36 weeks of gestation. At 28 weeks, she was diagnosed with gestational diabetes. She was unable to maintain her blood sugar levels with a diabetic diet and was planned to start on insulin. Which of the following is not true regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: Insulin is the drug of choice for gestational diabetes mellitus
Insulin is started when  post prandial 2 hour blood glucose > 120 mg/dl
Insulin must be continued after the delivery
Insulin does not cross the placenta

questions.solution:
A patient of gestational diabetes mellitus is at an increased risk for developing overt diabetes and should undergo a glucose tolerance test at 6 weeks postpartum to determine further management (like insulin requirement).

Fifty percent of women with gestational diabetes develop overt diabetes within 20 years. Hence, they are recommended to undergo screening & revaluation between 4-12 weeks postpartum.

To start oral hypoglycemic or subcutaneous insulin directly would be incorrect as they may not have diabetes.

Insulin is the drug of choice for the treatment of gestational diabetes mellitus. It does not cross the placenta and tight glycemic control can typically be achieved.

Insulin therapy is started if :

  • fasting levels persistently exceed 95 mg/ dL in women with gestational diabetes
  • women with 1-hour postprandial levels that persistently exceed 140 mg/dL or
  • women with 2-hour postprandial levels > 120 mg/dL.

The starting dose is typically 0.7 to 1 units/kg/d and is given in divided doses. A combination of intermediate-acting and short -acting insulin may be used.

questions.text: A young woman with major depression was brought to the emergency after having consumed 20 tablets of acetaminophen (500 mg each) in a self-harm attempt. The time of ingestion is unknown. She complains of severe right subcostal pain. On examination, you note jaundice, mucosal bleeding, and tender hepatomegaly. Which of the following is the best management plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation with jaundice, hepatomegaly, and coagulopathy after ingesting a toxic dose of acetaminophen is suggestive of fulminant hepatic failure. Liver transplantation is indicated in the above scenario.

Acetaminophen is an analgesic and antipyretic. It is a non-selective COX inhibitor and acts at the peroxide site of the enzyme. It is usually well tolerated with few gastrointestinal side effects and occasional rashes.

The most fatal complication is hepatic necrosis. It occurs following a single overdose of 10-15g. Doses >20-25 g are fatal. The manifestations are due to the conversion of acetaminophen to NAPQI. 

Activated charcoal (option A) is given within 4 h of ingestion of acetaminophen.

Plasma concentration of acetaminophen >300 μg/mL at 4h or >45 μg/mL at 15 h post-ingestion can lead to severe liver damage. N-acetylcysteine (option C) is considered a definitive antidote for acetaminophen poisoning to prevent hepatic injury. In this case, the patient is already presenting with features of hepatic failure, hence N-acetylcysteine would not be effective.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with an upper limb deformity as given in the image below. He has had recurrent respiratory infections and is breathless while walking. You hear a wide split and fixed second heart sound through all phases of respiration. Identify the heart disease likely to be present in this child.
questions.solution:
The heart disease likely to be present in this child is an atrial septal defect (ASD).

The given clinical history along with the image is suggestive of Holt Oram syndrome. The syndrome is characterized by hypoplasia of the thumb, phocomelia, atrial septal defect, and triphalangism. 

Clinical features of ASD include exercise intolerance and failure to thrive although many children are asymptomatic. On auscultation, there is a widely split and fixed second heart sound in all phases of respiration, along with an ejection systolic murmur. Occasionally an ejection click is heard over the pulmonary area.

Chest X-ray shows enlarged right atrium and right ventricle. The diagnosis can be further affirmed in ECG which interprets right ventricular volume overload with normal peripheral vascular resistance. The location and size of the ASD can be confirmed in 2D scanning of the defect. Treatment involves closure of the defect either by surgery or by percutaneous catheter device insertion over the defect. 

Other options:

Option B: Transposition of great vessels (TGV) - ejection systolic murmur of grade 1 or 2 with features of cyanosis and failure to thrive.

Option C: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) - continuous murmur is distinctly heard on auscultation due to systolic and diastolic overloading of the pulmonary artery. 

Option D Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC) - pulmonary ejection systolic murmur with a tricuspid flow murmur.

questions.text: Which of the following is part of the WHO criteria for Severe Acute Malnutrition(SAM)?

choices.text: Mid-upper arm circumference less than 14.5 cm
Mid-upper arm circumference less than 13.5 cm
Mid-upper arm circumference less than 12.5 cm
Mid-upper arm circumference less than 11.5 cm

questions.solution:
Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is best defined as mid-upper arm circumference <11.5cm.

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by the WHO (World Health Organization) as any of the following:

  1. Weight-for-length (or height) below −3 SD (standard deviations) of the WHO Child Growth Standards
  2. Presence of bipedal edema
  3. Mid-upper arm circumference <11.5 cm

Related Pearl: World Health Organization (WHO) classification of nutritional status of infants and children

Nutritional status
Criteria (from birth to 5 years)

Obese

Weight-for-height/length >3 SD

BMI-for-age >3 SD
Overweight

Weight-for-height/length >2 SD and ≤3 SD

BMI-for-age >2 SD and ≤3 SD
Moderately underweight Weight-for-age <–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely underweight Weight-for-age <–3 SD
Moderate acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

BMI-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference ≥115 mm and <125 mm
Severe acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length <– 3 SD

BMI-for-age <– 3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm

Bilateral pitting edema
Moderately stunted (or) moderate chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely stunted (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age <–3 SD
Moderately wasted Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely wasted Weight-for-height/length <-3 SD

SD - Standard deviation (from the median)

questions.text: A patient of bipolar disorder on lithium therapy presented with polydipsia and polyuria. Investigations revealed increased 24-hour urine output and low urinary osmolality. Water deprivation test suggested diabetes insipidus. Which of the following aquaporin (AQP) channels are involved here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lithium induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. AQP-2 is involved here. 

Diabetes insipidus (DI) is a condition in which there is the absence of or poor response to anti-diuretic hormone (ADH). This results in reduced permeability of the distal tubules and collecting ducts to water. This furthermore leads the kidneys to excrete large amounts of dilute urine that clinically manifests as polyuria and polydipsia. 

DI can be:

  • Central DI - due to vasopressin deficiency or
  • Nephrogenic DI - due to failure of kidneys to repond to ADH

Lithium decreases the kidney's ability to concentrate urine. Lithium enters the distal tubular cells in the kidney via luminal ENaC. However, it accumulates in the distal tubular cells due to the inability of Na+K+ATPase to secrete lithium via the basal membrane. High levels of lithium in the cells inhibits GSK-3ß. This inhibition leads to vasopressin insensitivity, downregulation of AQP 2 channels, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

Other options:

Option A: AQP-1 is located on the basolateral and apical membrane of the proximal tubules. It regulates rapid movement of water out of the tubule along the osmotic gradients set up by the active transport of solutes. This helps in maintaining the isotonicity. 

Options C and D: AQP-3 and AQP-4 are present on the basolateral side of the cell membrane. They provide a path for water to rapidly exit the cells, and are not regulated by ADH.

Related Pearl: Water transport along nephron

Segment

Mechanism of Water Reabsorption

Proximal tubule(67%)

Osmosis, AQ 1

Loop of Henle (15%)

Descending thin limb only; aquaporin 1 channels

Early distal convoluted tubule(0%)

No water reabsorption

Late distal tubule and collecting duct (8-17%)

Passive(aquaporin-2) under the influence of ADH

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality. 

  Urine osmolality before water deprivation Urine osmolality after water deprivation Urine osmolality after desmopressin administration
Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

questions.text: A woman presents with a history of sudden spontaneous lacrimation upon eating or drinking. Impingement of a cranial nerve is suspected. The lesion behind this pathology is located at:

choices.text: Facial nerve proximal to geniculate ganglion

questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario, the patient is likely to have crocodile tears syndrome. The lesion behind the given pathology is the facial nerve located proximal to the geniculate ganglion.

Crocodile tears syndrome or Bogorad syndrome, also known as gustatory lacrimation is caused due to anomalous regeneration of the facial nerve fibres. When the facial nerve is damaged proximal to the geniculate ganglia, the regenerative fibers supplying the salivary gland aberrantly supply the lacrimal gland. These fibres connect the submandibular salivary gland with preganglionic secretomotor fibres of the lacrimal gland. Hence, the patient presents with spontaneous lacrimation in response to the stimuli such as the taste of food or during eating. It can be treated by sectioning the greater petrosal nerve or tympanic neurectomy.

The anatomy of the geniculate ganglia is best understood with the course of the facial nerve. 

The course of the facial nerve is divided into intracranial (cisternal), intratemporal, and extratemporal portions.

Intracranial portion- The facial nerve nucleus lies in the caudal pontine reticular formation near the trapezoid nucleus and nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. Fibers from this nucleus curve around the abducens nucleus and emerge at the cerebellopontine angle.

Intratemporal portion is from the internal acoustic meatus to the stylomastoid foramen. This is further divided into meatal, labyrinthine, tympanic (horizontal), and mastoid (vertical) segments.

  • Meatal- The facial nerve passes through the internal acoustic meatus along with the nervus intermedius, cochlear nerve, superior and inferior vestibular nerves. It passes above the transverse crest. It is separated from the superior vestibular nerve by Bill's bar.
  • Labyrinthine segment is from the internal acoustic meatus to the first genu near the geniculate ganglion. It is the shortest and narrowest part of the facial nerve and is susceptible to vascular compression.
  • Tympanic part- is the horizontal part of the facial nerve. It curves around the oval window niche then lies just anterior and inferior to the lateral semicircular canal. After this, the nerve makes a second bend (genu) to continue as a vertical part.
  • Mastoid part- is the longest part and runs up to the stylomastoid foramen.

Branches from the intratemporal facial nerve

  • Greater superficial petrosal nerve- It arises from the geniculate ganglion. It contains parasympathetic fibers for the lacrimal gland and palate.
  • Nerve to stapedius- It arises from the facial nerve in the posterior wall of the tympanic cavity. It supplies stapedius muscle
  • Chorda tympani leaves the facial nerve around 6mm above the stylomastoid foramen. It contains parasympathetic fibers that supply the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands via the submandibular ganglion and taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

Extratemporal portion

The facial nerve emerges from the base of the skull at the stylomastoid foramen and supplies the posterior belly of the digastric, stylohyoid, occipitofrontalis, and other facial muscles.

 

Clinical aspect:

Injury proximal to the geniculate ganglion will lead to damage to the greater superficial petrosal nerve, nerve to stapedius, chorda tympani, and muscular branches. There is loss of lacrimal secretions, loss of stapedial reflex, loss of taste in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue, and facial paralysis. Aberrant regeneration of these fibers results in crocodile tears syndrome.

questions.text: The government of India starts a new initiative where rehabilitation centers are opened across the country to support wounded army soldiers with medical and psychological aid. Which level of prevention does this initiative fall under?
questions.solution:
The rehabilitation of wounded soldiers with medical and psychological aid falls under the tertiary level of prevention.

The tertiary level of prevention signifies intervention in the late pathogenesis phase. Tertiary prevention can be defined as "all measures available to reduce or limit impairments and disabilities, minimize suffering caused by existing departures from good health, and promote the patient's adjustment to irremediable conditions."

Other levels of prevention are:

Primordial prevention involves the prevention of the emergence or development of risk factors in countries or population groups in which they have not yet appeared. This is employed for health problems like obesity and hypertension, which have an early onset due to the mode of lifestyle like smoking, unhealthy eating patterns, and sedentary life. These patterns are discouraged from early childhood. The main intervention in primordial prevention is through individual and mass education.

Primary prevention is defined as "action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur''. It signifies intervention in the pre-pathogenesis phase of a disease or health problem and is accomplished by measures promoting general health and the quality of life of people by specific protective measures. Examples include immunization, sanitation, and the protection of food. They include two strategies :

  • Population (mass) strategy: where the target group is the whole population
  • High-risk strategy: where the target group is limited to the people who are most at risk of developing a particular disease

Secondary prevention is defined as the "action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications."The specific interventions are early diagnostic tests like screening tests and adequate treatment. The main aim of secondary prevention is to arrest the disease process, and it is largely the domain of clinical medicine and health programs initiated by governments.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

Level

Primordial

Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

Phase of disease

Underlying socio-economic & environmental conditions leading to causation

Specific causal or risk factors

Early stage of disease

Late stage of disease

Aim

Establish and maintain conditions that minimize hazards to health

Reduce the incidence of disease

Reduce prevalence by shortening duration

Reduce number and impact of complications

Actions

Inhibition of emergence of socio-economic, environmental and behavioural conditions

Protection of personal and community health by eliminating risks

Early detection and intervention to minimize disability

Soften the impact of long-term disease and disability, minimize suffering

Modes of Intervention

Health education

Health promotion and specific protection

 

Diagnosis and treatment

Disability limitation and rehabilitation

Targets

Total population or select groups

Total population or high risk individuals/groups

 

Individuals/ Patients

Patients

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented to the hospital with severe anemia. Examination revealed hypoplasia of the thumb, small testis, and short stature. Bone marrow aspirate showed hypocellular bone marrow. Further genetic analysis revealed mutation in FANCA gene. All of the following are true about this boy's condition except?
questions.solution:
Autosomal dominant mode of inheritance is a false statement. The given clinical scenario points toward Fanconi's anemia and the mode of inheritance of this disease is autosomal recessive.

Fanconi's anemia is an inherited disorder. It occurs due to a defect in protein complexes required for DNA repair resulting in marrow dysfunction, usually due to a mutation in the FANCA gene. It leads to an increased risk of aplastic anemia and leukemia. The disease is also associated with hypoplasia of kidneys and spleen and bone deformities primarily affecting the thumb or radii. The renal disease leads to hypophosphatemia. In adults, physical abnormalities are not marked, but isolated macrocytic anemia and premature graying of hair can be observed. 

Blood investigations reveal macrocytic anemia or thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow examination shows hypocellular bone marrow.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl was brought to the clinic by her mother with complaints of frequent upper respiratory tract infections. Her mother said that the girl also had a tendency for easy bruising. After thorough investigations, a diagnosis of Chediak-Hegashi syndrome was made. What is the defect in this disorder?

choices.text: Defect in both T cells and B cells

questions.solution:
Chediak-Higashi syndrome involves a defect in the process of phagocytosis. 

Chediak-Higashi syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder due to defects in the lysosomal transport protein LYST —a protein required for the normal packaging and distribution of granules (encoded by CHS1 gene). This defect results in defective chemotaxis, phagolysosome fusion, degranulation of T-cells and NK cells, and ADP granule function in platelets. 

Clinically, patients with Chediak-Higashi syndrome may present with-

  • Persistent skin, respiratory and gastro-intestinal infections- Especially due to staphylococcus aureus.
  • Partial oculo-cutaneous albinism.
  • Platelet dysfunction- There is increased bleeding time leading to easy bruising and excessive bleeding, however, the platelet count is normal.
  • Neurological dysfunction- Progressive peripheral neuropathy, nystagmus, mental retardation.
  • Accelerated phase with lymphoma-like illness and hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis — a life-threatening condition that is characterized by high prolonged fever, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and cytopenia and carries a very poor prognosis.

Diagnosis is done by detecting the presence of peroxidase-positive giant primary granules in neutrophils and other granule-bearing cells on Wright’s stain. Genetic detection may be confirmatory. 

Other options:

Option A: Disorders of complement system, such as  C1 inhibitor deficiency, results in hereditary angioedema.

Option B: Combined defect in both B cells and T cells result in severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome (SCID).

Option C: Disorders of T cells include conditions such as Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome and DiGeorge syndrome. Disorders of B cells include conditions such as hyper IgM syndrome and IgA deficiency. 

The image below shows a neutrophil in Chediak Higashi Syndrome showing polymorphonuclear leukocytes with abundant giant intracytoplasmic granules:

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: A 3 yr old child presents with a swelling in the skull. The radiological finding was suggestive of lytic lesions. Bone biopsy was performed and the ultrastructure of the biopsied tissue showed Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm with a tennis racket appearance.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario with a young child presenting with a skull swelling with lytic lesions on radiography and Birbeck granules on ultrastructure examination suggests a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).

LCH is a clonal proliferation of pathological Langerhans cells. Men are more affected than women. Patients present with pain and swelling over the affected areas. Commonly affected sites are the skull, pelvis, femur, and mandible.

Radiographs show a lytic lesion with periosteal new bone formation. In the skull, lesions appear as a hole within a hole, and in the vertebra, vertebra plana (flattening of the vertebral body) can be seen.

Histopathologically, it is characterized by the presence of Langerhans cells. The tumor cells contain abundant cytoplasm with folded or grooved nuclei. Ultrastructurally, they contain tennis-racket-shaped intracytoplasmic inclusions called Birbeck granules.

In the majority of cases, spontaneous resolution occurs and systemic anti-inflammatory drugs are effective in reducing the symptoms. 

The below images are the histopathological picture of LCH and Birbeck granules respectively:

 

Other options:

Option A: Hyperparathyroidism is the excessive secretion of PTH. Cortical erosion and osteoporosis are the characteristic radiographic features. 

Option B: Multiple myeloma is the malignant proliferation of plasma cells of B-cell lineage. It mainly arises from the bone marrow of the vertebra, pelvis, and femur. In the skull, punched-out osteolytic lesions with cortical thinning are seen causing a pepper pot appearance

Option C: Metastatic lesion is the most common bone malignancy. Common sites include the spine, proximal femur, pelvis, proximal humerus, femur, scapula, distal femur, and ribs. Lesions may be osteolytic/osteoblastic depending on the primary sites of the tumor. X-rays are used in staging. 

Typically, prostatic lesions are densely osteosclerotic, whereas renal and thyroid lesions are osteolytic. Lung and breast metastases produce mixed osteoblastic/osteolytic lesions.

Related Pearl: Skeletal and Radiological manifestation of Langerhan’s Cell Histiocytosis

Skull:

Solitary or multiple punched out lytic lesion without sclerotic rim.
Double contour or beveled edge appearance may be seen due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer table (hole within a hole sign).
Button sequestra representing residual bone.
Geographic skull.

Spine:

Vertebra Plana:it is the most common cause of vertebra plana in children;mostly seen in the thoracic spine.

Mandible:

Irregular radiolucent areas mostly involving superficial alveolar bone.

Floating tooth: loss of lamina dura.

Long Bones:

  • Permeative and aggressive appearing lesions occur
  • Mainly involves diaphysis or meta diaphysis
  • Endosteal scalloping, Periosteal reaction(in healing phase),cortical thinning,intracortical tunneling and associated soft tissue mass can be seen.

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation

questions.text: A very tall and thin young man who is a known case of medullary thyroid cancer is found to have mucosal neuromas. The patient mentioned that his father also had thyroid cancer. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has medullary thyroid cancer, along with mucosal neuromas, and marfanoid habitus, which makes the probable diagnosis as multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2B. 

Multiple endocrine neoplasias are characterized by the presence of tumors in two or more endocrine glands. The variants of MEN are MEN1, MEN2A, MEN2B/3 and MEN4.

MEN 1 is a syndrome complex associated mainly with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors. 

MEN 2A comprises mainly medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenoma. 

MEN 2B/3 consists of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibers, and megacolon.

MEN 4 is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, and reproductive organ tumors.

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented to the dermatologist with alopecia and the following disfiguring lesions. His history was suggestive of Raynaud's phenomenon. On examination, wide follicular pits were noted in the concha. ANA titres were normal. Identify the false statement regarding his condition.

choices.text: Topical steroids is the first line treatment for localised lesions
Histology shows lymphocytic interface dermatitis with basal layer degeneration
Antimalarials can be used for treatment
Non-scarring alopecia is typically seen in this condition

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the image showing discoid lesions on the face with central scarring and active erythematous margins with adherent scales are suggestive of discoid lupus erythematosus. Scarring type of alopecia is seen in discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE).

Histology of DLE shows lymphocytic interface dermatitis with basal layer degeneration, follicular plugging, dermal mucinosis, and epidermal atrophy.

The first-line treatment for localized lesions is topical corticosteroids. 

Hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine are oral antimalarial drugs that can be used along with oral steroids and have a good response rate.

questions.text: A Brazilian tourist presents with lesions on his chest and back as shown in the image below. On examination, no oral or mucosal lesions are found. Acantholytic cells are seen on Tzank smear. A histopathological sample is sent for further examination. Identify the type of blister present in this condition.
questions.solution:
The type of blister present in this condition would be a subcorneal blister.

The given clinical scenario with the image showing lesions over the chest and observation of acantholysis on Tzank smear, without oral or mucosal lesions is highly suggestive of pemphigus foliaceus.

Pemphigus foliaceus is a benign form of pemphigus, an inflammatory blistering disorder. It is caused by autoantibodies that result in the dissolution of intercellular attachments within the epidermis.

The skin lesion in this condition is a form of a subcorneal blister, where the stratum corneum forms the roof of the bulla. The bullae are superficial and mainly present as areas of erythema and crusting.

The lesions are commonly observed on the scalp, face, chest, and back. They represent superficial erosions at sites of blister rupture. There is no involvement of the mucosal epithelium in pemphigus foliaceus.

Other options:

Option A: A Subepidermal blister is one where the entire epidermis separates from the dermis. This type of blister is observed in bullous pemphigoid. The flexural aspects of the limb and abdomen are the most preferred sites. 

Option C: A Suprabasal blister is one where a portion of the epidermis, including the stratum corneum, forms the roof of the lesion. This is observed in pemphigus vulgaris. Pemphigus Vulgaris involves the mucosal surfaces, which is not seen in this patient. Other sites which are preferred are the scalp, face, neck, upper chest and back.

Option D: A Junctional blister is present at the level of the lamina lucida. This is observed in junctional epidermolysis bullosa. Common sites include around the nose, mouth, neck, trunk and buttocks. 

 

Related Pearl: Classification of Vesiculobullous Disorders

According to Pathology

  • Immunobullous disorders/ Primary blistering disease: occur due to autoimmunity

Intraepidermal

Subepidermal

Pemphigus vulgaris

Bullous pemphigoid

Pemphigus foliaceous

 Dermatitis herpetiformis

Pemphigus vegetans

 Epidermolysis bullous acquisita
 Pemphigus erythematosus  
  • Mechanobullous disorders: Due to defect in the structure of epidermis
    • Epidermolysis bullosa
    • Bullous ichthyosiform erythroderma
  • Other disorders
    • Infections - VZV, HSV, Bullous impetigo, SSSS
    • Metabolic - Porphyria, Diabetes, Hemodialysis
    • Drug eruptions - Fixed drug eruption, Steven Johnson Syndrome, Erythema Multiforme

According to Site

Intraepidermal

Sub-epidermal (Dermo-epidermal)

1. Subcorneal (granular layer)

  • Pemphigus foliaceous & erythematosus
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
  • Miliaria crystalina
  • Bullous impetigo
  • Friction blister
  • Subcorneal pustular dermatosis

2. Spinous layer

  • Eczematous (atopic) dermatitis
  • HSV/VZV infection
  • Molluscum contagiosum
  • Familial benign pemphigus (Hailey-hailey disease)

3. Suprabasal

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Darrier’s disease

4. Basal layer

  • Erythema multiforme
  • Epidermolysis bullosa simplex

1. Junctional (at basal lamina)

  • Junctional epidermolysis bullosa
  • Bullous pemphigoid
  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis

2. Dermolytic (below basal lamina)

  • Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita
  • Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophicans
  • Deep burns
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda

questions.text:
A microbiologist is about to run a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay on the serum of a patient suspected to have a Herpes simplex virus infection. Choose the correct sequence of steps done in PCR.
  1. DNA extraction
  2. Denaturation
  3. Annealing
  4. Extension
questions.solution:
Option D (1-2-3-4) is correct. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) involves the following steps: DNA extraction from the organism, DNA amplification (denaturation, annealing, extension), and gel electrophoresis of the amplified product.

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is a rapid automated method for the amplification of specific DNA sequences (or genes).

Steps:

  1. DNA extraction from the organism
  2. Amplification of the extracted DNA in a thermocycler where it is subjected to repeated cycles. Each cycle has three steps:
    1. Denaturation - heating to separate double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) into two separate strands (ssDNA)
    2. Annealing - addition of primer which anneals or attaches to the target ssDNA
    3. Extension - addition of free nucleotides to the growing end of the primer by DNA polymerase 
  3. Gel electrophoresis of the amplified product

Types of PCR:

  • Reverse transcriptase PCR- The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesize a complementary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR.
  • Real-time PCR- This helps quantify the PCR and gives an estimate of the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes. It is also known as qPCR (Quantitative PCR)
  • Multiplex PCR- Primers to more than one pathogen are used simultaneously and hence multiple products are obtained. 
  • Nested PCR- It involves the sequential use of two primer sets. The first primer set is used for amplification and the amplicon obtained is then used as a target sequence for second amplification. This ensures specificity. 

The image below shows the various ingredients involved in PCR.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with perifollicular hemorrhages and ecchymosis around hair follicles. Bleeding gums were seen on examination. Identify the zone marked in the radiograph below.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of scurvy and the radiolucent metaphyseal band underlying the dense zone of calcification in the x-ray shown is the Trummerfeld zone. 

Dietary deficiency of vitamin C leads to scurvy. It is common from 6-9 months of age. Defective osteoid production by osteoblasts with reduced endochondral bone ossification is likely to be the cause of the condition.

Clinical features include bleeding into the skin which includes petechiae, ecchymosis, perifollicular haemorrhages, bleeding into joints, and bleeding gums which are mainly due to the impaired formation of connective tissue.

Radiological features include 

  • Trummerfeld zone

  • Frankel's line which is an increased density at the metaphyseal ends (Option D)

  • Pelcan's spur which is seen in the metaphysis and is prone to fracture (Option B), and

  • Wimberger's sign (a pencil-shaped outline seen in the epiphysis) (Option A).

Treatment includes supplementation of vitamin C (200 mg/day).

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Important differences between vitamin D and vitamin C deficiencies

 
Vitamin D     deficiency  
Vitamin C     deficiency
Pathology Poor mineralization of bone Poor osteoid          formation
Clinical features

No/less irritability

Rachitic rosary (nodularity at the costochondral junction)

Irritability is predominant

Scorbutic rosary (angular & sharp costochondral junction)
Radiological features

Cupping 

Fraying

Splaying

White line of Frankel

Pelkan spur

Wimberger ring sign

Subperiosteal hemorrhage

Note: Irritability in scurvy is due to hampered neurotransmitter production (conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine and tryptophan to serotonin requires vitamin C).

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented with low backache and morning stiffness for the past 6 months with a history of symptomatic improvement with exercise. On examination, he had decreased chest expansion. What will be the earliest X-ray sign in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis and the earliest X-ray sign is the erosion of the sacroiliac joint.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joint. It is more common in young males and has a strong association with HLAB27.

Clinically, patients present with recurring backache which worsens in the early morning or with inactivity and improves with exercise. Later they develop fatigue, pain, joint swellings, and heel pain.

Extra-articular manifestations include uveitis, aortic incompetence, carditis, and apical lobe fibrosis.

Examination findings include loss of lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, diminished spinal movements, and decreased chest expansion.

X-ray findings:

  • erosion of sacroiliac joints - earliest sign
  • periarticular sclerosis (option B) in later stages 
  • squaring of vertebrae due to flattening of normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body is the earliest vertebral change
  • bamboo spine appearance (option C) due to bridging of adjacent vertebrae
  • wedging of the vertebra (option D) leading to hyperkyphosis

Treatment consists of maintaining posture and preserving mobility. Pain and stiffness can be controlled with anti-inflammatory drugs. In severe cases, TNF inhibitors are used. Surgery can be considered to correct the deformity.

The image below shows the bamboo spine's appearance:

Related Pearl: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Joints Commonly Spared

 Osteoarthritis

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints  
Psoriatic Arthritis PIP, DIP Ray distribution* 

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

questions.text: Identify the following method of testing antibiotic sensitivity.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an E-test (epsilometer) which is a diffusion and dilution method of testing antibiotic sensitivity.

It is a quantitative technique for determining antimicrobial susceptibility and minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC).

  1. An absorbent strip containing a predefined gradient (serial dilution) of antibiotic concentration immobilized along its length is placed on a lawn inoculum of a bacterium.
  2. An elliptical zone of inhibition is produced surrounding the strip. 
  3. The antibiotic concentration at which the ellipse edge intersects the strip is taken as the MIC value.

The given image shows another E-test.

The antibiotic sensitivity tests are classified as follows:

  1. Diffusion methods: 
    • Kirby–Bauer disk diffusion method
    • Stokes disk diffusion method
  2. Dilution methods: 
    • Broth dilution
    • Agar dilution
  3. Diffusion and dilution method:
    • E–test (Epsilometer)
  4. Automated methods:
    • VITEK 2 
    • Phoenix system 

The disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing is applied in the Kirby-Bauer method. 

To perform Kirby-Bauer’s disc diffusion method, a suitable standard dilution of a broth culture of the test bacterium is inoculated on the surface of a solid medium (Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar) as a lawn culture. After drying, various antibiotic discs are placed on its surface.

Zones of inhibition around the disc are recorded and interpreted according to the zone diameters available in the tables of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines. The results obtained are qualitative (resistant, sensitive, or partially sensitive)

The below image shows the Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion method.

 

The below image shows Tube dilution method.

The below image shows Stokes method

questions.text: A 37-year-old female patient complains of nipple discharge for the past 3 months. On examination, green-colored discharge is found oozing from the right nipple and no underlying lump was palpable. Imaging of the breast shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of green-colored nipple discharge along with the coarse rod and branching calcifications that give a 'broken needle' appearance in mammogram is suggestive of duct ectasia. 

The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green-colored secretions. In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, causing periductal mastitis, or even an abscess and fistula formation.

Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation, which involves the excision of all the major ducts.

Other options:

Option A- Fibroadenoma presents with a mobile breast lump and shows popcorn calcification on mammography.

 

Option C- Fat necrosis presents as a painless lump and can mimic a carcinoma which has to be ruled out by a biopsy. Fat necrosis shows lead pipe/ eggshell calcification.

 

Option D- Duct papilloma would present as a cystic swelling from a large lactiferous duct and is associated with blood stained discharge.

Related Pearl: Discharge from the Nipple

From the surface:

  • Paget’s disease
  • Skin diseases (eczema, psoriasis)
  • Rare causes (e.g., chancre)

From a single duct:

  • Blood-stained:
    • Intraductal papilloma (M/C cause)
    • Intraductal carcinoma
    • Duct ectasia
  • Serous (any colour):
    • Fibrocystic disease
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma

From multiple ducts:

  • Blood-stained:
    • Carcinoma (M/C cause)
    • Ectasia
    • Fibrocystic disease
  • Black or green:
    • Duct ectasia
  • Purulent:
    • Infection
  • Serous:
    • Fibrocystic disease (M/C cause)
    • Duct ectasia
    • Carcinoma
  • Milk:
    • Lactation
    • Rare causes (hypothyroidism, pituitary tumour)

questions.text: A man has been arrested and booked under Sec. 80 BNS. Which of the following offences has he been accused of?
questions.solution:
The man has been accused of and arrested for dowry death. Section 80 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) deals with dowry deaths.

This legal provision comes into effect when the untimely demise of a woman occurs by burns/bodily injury or any other cause apart from normal circumstances within the first 7 years of her marriage. Evidence of cruelty or harassment by her spouse or relatives of her spouse in connection with demands for dowry must be shown. 


Other options:
Option A: Section 105 deals with culpable homicide not amounting to murder. Under this, the convict shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than five years but may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to a fine if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing death, or of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death. If it is determined that the act is committed with the knowledge that it is likely to cause death, but without any intention to cause death or to cause such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, the punishment is imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years and a fine.


Option C: Culpable homicide is defined under section 100 of the BNS. It states whoever causes death by doing an act to cause death, or intending to cause such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide.


Option D: Grievous hurt is defined by Sec.116 BNS. Grievous hurt refers to any hurt that endangers life, or which causes the victim to be in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits for fifteen days. This includes emasculation, permanent privation of the sight of either eye, permanent privation of the hearing of either ear, the privation of any member or joint or the destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfiguration of the head or face, and fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl complains of low-grade fever and mild discomfort in her throat. On examination, a membrane is seen over the tonsil that can be removed easily. After removal of the membrane, an irregular ulcer is seen on the surface of the tonsil. A smear from the lesion shows a fusiform bacilli and another bacterium. What is the other bacterium?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Vincent's angina. It is caused by the fusiform bacillus and Borrelia vincentii.

Vincent's angina, also known as acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis or trench mouth, is a form of gingivitis characterized by painful, inflamed gingiva with ulcerations of the interdental papillae that bleed easily.

Patients usually present with low-grade fever, halitosis, malaise, lymphadenopathy, sore throat & a membrane over the tonsil. This membrane is easily removed to reveal irregular ulcers over the tonsil.

A throat swab will show both the organisms typical of the disease, namely fusiform bacilli and spirochetes, namely Borrelia vincentii. 

Treatment consists of debridement and oral administration of penicillin plus metronidazole, with clindamycin or doxycycline alone as an alternative.

questions.text: Which of the following statement about the quick sequential organ failure assessment (qSOFA) scoring system is false?

choices.text: Score of 2 suggests potentially life threatening sepsis
Systolic blood pressure  ≤100 mmHg is one of its parameters
Respiratory rates ≥22/min is one of its parameters
It relies on laboratory and imaging findings

questions.solution:
The statement that the quick sequential organ failure assessment (qSOFA) scoring system relies on laboratory and imaging findings is false.

qSOFA is a screening and monitoring tool for patients with suspected sepsis. The qSOFA suggests potentially life-threatening sepsis when at least two of the following parameters are met.

  • Systolic blood pressure ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥22 breaths per min
  • Altered mental status (Glasgow coma scale <15)

It assigns one point for each. A score >2 is associated with a significant risk of death or prolonged intensive care unit stay.

Related Pearl: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine
Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score
  0 1 2 3 4

Cardiovascular

Hypotension

 No hypotension

MAP <70 mmHg

Dopamine <5 or epi/norepi ≤0.1¤ 

 Dopamine >5 or epi/norepi ≤0.1¤ Dopamine >15 or epi/norepi >0.1¤ 

Coagulation

Platelets (×103 per μL)

 >150 ≤150 ≤100 ≤50  ≤20

Respiration

(PaO2/FIO2) (mm Hg)

 >400 ≤400 ≤300 ≤200 with respiratory support ≤100 with respiratory support

Mentation

GCS

 15 13–14 10–12 6–9 <6

Liver

Bilirubin(μmol/L)

 <20 20–32 33–101 102–204 >204

Kidney

Creatinine (μmol/L) or urine output

 <110 110–170 171–299 300–440 or <500 mL/day  >440 or <200 mL/day

MAP = mean arterial pressure. Epi = epinephrine. Nonrepi = norepinephrine. ¤ = Adrenergic agents administered for at least 1 h (doses in μg/kg per min).

 

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: The phase 1 reactions of drug metabolism include:
questions.solution:
Reduction is a phase 1 reaction of drug metabolism.

Drug metabolism can be classified into 2 phases:

  • Phase 1:
    • Oxidation
    • Reduction
    • Hydrolytic reaction
  • Phase 2:
    • Glucuronide conjugation (most common phase 2 reaction)
    • Glutathione conjugation
    • Acetylation
    • Methylation
    • Sulfation

questions.text: A 3-year-old unimmunized boy presented with conjunctivitis and a rash that spread from his face to his trunk. On examination, the doctor noticed findings as shown in the image below. What dose of Vitamin A will you give at the time of diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario as well as the Koplik's spot (bluish-white spots ) seen in the image above suggests a diagnosis of measles. Children who are above 12 months of age are given 2,00,000 lU of Vitamin A at the time of diagnosis. 

Vitamin A therapy is indicated in all cases of severe measles (and in areas with high case-fatality rates) as patients may develop an acute deficiency of vitamin A leading to keratomalacia and corneal scarring. A high dose of vitamin A is given immediately on diagnosis and repeated the next day. The recommended age-specific daily doses are:

  • 50,000 IU for infants aged <6 months
  • 1,00,000 IU for infants aged 6- 11 months
  • 2,00,000 IU for children aged ≥12 months.

An additional third dose should be given 4-6 weeks later if the child has clinical signs of vitamin A deficiency (such as Bitot's spots) with measles. 

Measles, otherwise known as rubeola, is caused by the paramyxovirus which is an RNA virus. The virus has an incubation period of 10 to 14 days. It is a droplet infection and the period of infectivity ranges from 4 days before to 4 days after the appearance of the rash. 

The prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomonic Koplik spots. Koplik spots are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the buccal mucosa at the level of the premolars.

This is followed by the appearance of a characteristic dusky red maculopapular rash that begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present. The image below shows the characteristic rashes and the Koplik spots seen in measles-

 The diagnosis of measles infection is mainly clinical but may be confirmed by serological demonstration of serum IgM antibodies. 

The management is mainly supportive in form of relieving common symptoms such as fever, cough, and nasal congestion and providing adequate nutritional support. 

According to the national immunisation schedule, the measles vaccine is administered by reconsitituting freeze-dried live attenuated vaccine called MR(measles, rubella) vaccine. The first dose and second doses are administered at  9-12  months and 16-24 months of age respectively. 

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance

questions.text: An infant with abdominal distension, fever, and jaundice was brought to the pediatric OPD. On further evaluation, a diagnosis of an autosomal recessive disorder due to a defect in the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase was arrived at. What is the likely disorder?
questions.solution:
The autosomal recessive disorder due to a defect in the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase in a child with abdominal distension, fever and jaundice is associated with Hepatorenal tyrosinemia (Type 1 tyrosinemia or tyrosinosis). It is the most common type of tyrosinemia. 

There are three types of tyrosinemias:

  • Type 1 (Hepatorenal tyrosinemia):
    • Defective enzyme: Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase 
    • Inherited as an autosomal recessive trait
    • Clinical features: Liver failure, hypoglycemia, boiled cabbage odour in the urine, and mental retardation. 
  • Type 2 (Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia/Richner-Hanhart syndrome):
    • Defective enzyme: Tyrosine transaminase 
    • Clinical features: Palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions, photophobia, mental retardation are seen. 
  • Type 3 (Neonatal tyrosinemia): 
    • Defective enzyme: 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase 
    • Clinical features: Normal liver function, developmental delay, seizures and intermittent ataxia are seen.
  • Hawkinsuria
    • Defective enzyme: 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase 
    • Inherited as an autosomal dominant trait
    • Clinical features: Transient failure to thrive and metabolic acidosis in infancy

questions.text: Which of the following findings is consistent with a diagnosis of myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
LDH 1>LDH 2 is known as the flipped LDH pattern. It is suggestive of myocardial infarction.

Under normal conditions, LDH 2 is predominantly present in the blood and LDH 1 is predominantly present in the heart. When cardiac tissue is damaged LDH 1 is released into the bloodstream.

LDH is a tetrameric enzyme with 4 subunits. It has four subunits with two isoforms: H isoform (heart) and M isoform (muscle)

LDH Type  Composition Location
LDH-1 HHHH Heart and RBC
LDH-2 HHHM Heart and RBC
LDH-3 HHMM Lungs, brain, lymphatic tissues, and platelets
LDH-4 HMMM Liver and skeletal muscle
LDH-5 MMMM Liver and skeletal muscle

questions.text:
A 19-year-old girl comes for treatment of hirsutism. She has irregular periods. She is obese and has facial acne as well. Androstenedione and testosterone levels are elevated. LH levels are raised and FSH is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for the condition?

LH- Luteinizing hormone 

FSH- Follicle-stimulating hormone

OCP- Oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of hirsutism, irregular periods, acne, and obesity with elevated androgens, normal FSH, and raised LH are suggestive of polycystic ovary disease (PCOD). In PCOD, the drug used for hirsutism and acne is OCPs with cyproterone acetate. Cyproterone has an anti-androgenic effect.

Management of PCOD is individualized. Weight reduction and lifestyle changes are the first-line therapy for PCOD. In a woman who is not planning for pregnancy, the management mainly involves treatment of irregular periods and hirsutism. Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 mcg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. Hirsutism and acne are managed with OCP with cyproterone acetate and topical agents such as eflornithine, clindamycin lotion 1%, erythromycin gel 2%, and isoretinoin. 

Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin and acarbose. Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical management includes laparoscopic ovarian drilling (LOD)in resistant cases and bariatric surgery in morbidly obese patients.

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)/ Polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD): It is also known as Stein-Leventhal syndrome.

It is a multisystem, metabolic, endocrine dysfunction that commonly occurs among women in the reproductive age group. It has multifactorial causation, such as lifestyle changes, stress, diet, obesity, and hyperinsulinemic states.

Important clinical features of PCOS are:

  • Menstrual abnormalities (70%) - oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, or dysfunctional uterine bleeding. Dysmenorrhoea is absent.
  • Obesity
  • Hirsutism, acne, and alopecia due to hyperandrogenism
  • Acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance
  • Infertility

Rotterdam criterion is used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Oligo/amenorrhoea, anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries (USG findings)

Hormone profile in PCOS:

Increased levels Normal levels Decreased level
  1. Oestrone/E2 level
  2. Serum LH 
  3. LH: FSH ratio 
  4. Testosterone 
  5. Epi-androstenedione
  6. Fasting insulin
  7. Triglycerides

Serum FSH 
  1. SHBG level 
  2. Fasting glucose/ insulin ratio < 4.5

Investigations:

  1. Hormonal studies
  2. USG is diagnostic of PCOS- It shows enlarged ovaries with multiple follicles in the periphery. It also rules out other pathologies like ovarian tumors, endometrial hyperplasia, etc.
  3. Laparoscopy (therapeutic). It reveals bilateral enlarged ovarian cysts.

Ultrasound image below shows an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery.

Note:

PCOS in association with diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia and cardiovascular disease presenting in reproductive age group is known as "X syndrome".

HAIR-AN syndrome in patients with PCOS is characterized by HyperAndrogenism, Insulin Resistance and Acanthosis Nigricans.

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A nasogastric tube could not be passed in a newborn having cyclical hypoxia. There is an absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge and there was no misting on a metal spatula under the nose. Which of the following is an effective substitute for tracheostomy in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of choanal atresia, and McGovern’s technique is an effective substitute for tracheostomy in this condition.

Choanal atresia is characterised by a persistent bucco-nasal membrane, leaving a sheet of tissue at the back of the nose and separating it from the pharynx.

Features of choanal atresia include: 

  • Cyclical hypoxia: This is observed in the newborn, where the baby cries, taking in air through the mouth. This relieves the hypoxia, but upon settling down for a while and closing its mouth, the baby struggles to breathe and becomes hypoxic again.
  • Presence of mucoid nasal discharge
  • Absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge
  • Failure to pass a catheter from the nose to the pharynx
  • Absence of misting on a cold metal spatula held under the nose

Choanal atresia can be confirmed by putting methylene blue dye into the nose and observing its passage to the pharynx or putting a radio-opaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral radiograph. The most useful investigation though is an axial CT scan.

Definitive treatment is correcting the atresia either by transpalatal or transnasal approach, which is usually done at 1.5 years of age.

McGovern's technique involves the use of a feeding nipple with a large hole, which provides a good oral airway in the infant, as shown in the image below.

 

Other options:

Option A: Trotter’s method is used to control epistaxis. The patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood, and breathe quietly from the mouth, as shown in the image below.

 

Option C: Epley’s manoeuvre is used in the treatment of Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo, as shown in the image below.

 

Option D: Pringle maneuver is used to minimize blood loss during hepatic surgery by clamping the vascular pedicle (free margin of lesser omentum), as shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Choanal atresia

It is due to the persistence of bucconasal membrane which separates primitive oropharynx from the primitive nasopharynx. It has the following features:

  • Bony obstruction is more common than membranous
  • Unilateral > bilateral
  • Unilateral cases may be asymptomatic and present in adult life
  • Bilateral cases are life-threatening and present with respiratory distress
  • Associated with CHARGE syndrome
    • C- Coloboma of the eye
    • H- Heart defects
    • A- Atresia of choana
    • R- Retarded growth and development
    • G- Genital anomalies
    • E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss.

CT scan is the investigation of choice

Image: Membranous, bilateral choanal atresia in a newborn

Immediate management involves placing a feeding nipple with a large hole at the mouth to force the baby to mouth-breathe - McGoverns technique.

Definitive treatment consists of correction of atresia by a trans-nasal or trans-palatal approach.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The barium swallow study of this patient is shown below. What is the most common type of esophageal carcinoma associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a markedly dilated esophagus and characteristic bird's beak appearance suggestive of achalasia cardia (dilated esophagus with distal narrowing). The most common type of carcinoma associated with this condition is squamous cell carcinoma.

Achalasia cardia is a premalignant condition. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common carcinoma that develops after a diagnosis of achalasia cardia. This occurs due to long-standing retained, undigested fermenting food causing mucosal irritation.

Achalasia cardia is a motility disorder primarily due to the destruction of nerves in the lower esophageal sphincter and secondarily due to degeneration of neuromuscular function of the body of the esophagus.

Clinical manifestations include dysphagia initially to liquids and later to solids, regurgitation, and weight loss. Other symptoms such as heartburn, postprandial choking, and halitosis can occur later.

Manometric studies are the gold standard for diagnosis.

Management includes:

  • Surgical esophagomyotomy.
  • Non-surgical measures like sublingual nitroglycerin, nitrates, or calcium channel blockers.
  • Injection of botulinum toxin
  • Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) 

Other options:

Option A: Gastric stromal tumor arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal.

Option C: Gastric lymphomas occur in the stomach and they are mainly non-Hodgkin's lymphomas.

Option D: Adenocarcinoma occurs in the distal third of the esophagus. It can also occur in patients with achalasia cardia but SCC is more common. 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was diagnosed with pilocytic astrocytoma involving the superior cerebellar peduncle. Which of the following tracts may be likely involved by the tumor?
questions.solution:
The anterior spinocerebellar tract enters the cerebellum through the superior cerebellar peduncle and is likely involved by the tumor.  

The first-order neurons carrying fibers for unconscious proprioception from upper and lower limbs synapse with the nucleus dorsalis in the spinal cord. The second-order neurons form the anterior spinocerebellar tract which majorly decussates to the opposite side at the same level and ascends to reach the cerebellum through the superior cerebellar peduncle. It also sends collaterals to the same side as well. Therefore, any lesion in the superior cerebellar peduncle affects the afferents from the anterior spinocerebellar tract. 

The superior cerebellar peduncle includes fibers from deep cerebellar nuclei that project to the brainstem, red nucleus, and thalamus. 

Pilocytic astrocytomas are usually seen in children and the younger adult populations. They commonly affect the cerebellum, but can also appear in the region around the third ventricle, optic nerves, spinal cord, and cerebral hemispheres. They are grade 1 tumors (current WHO classification of CNS tumors) and have a relatively good prognosis. 

Other options:

Cuneocerebellar, olivocerebellar and posterior spinocerebellar tracts pass through the inferior cerebellar peduncle. 

Related Pearl: Cerebellar peduncles and their connections

Peduncle Afferent fibers Efferent fibers

Superior cerebellar peduncle

Anterior spinocerebellar tract
  • Globose - emboliform-rubral pathway
  • Dentatothalamic pathway
Middle cerebellar peduncle -Largest, most lateral and only afferent Corticopontocerebellar pathway -
Inferior cerebellar peduncle
  • Posterior spinocerebellar tract
  • Cuneocerebellar tract
  • Olivocerebellar tract
  • Reticulocerebellar tract

  • Vestibulocerebellar tract

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child was accompanied by his father to the OPD with dry, scaly dermatitis. On evaluation, he had a deficiency of essential fatty acids. Deficiency of which of the following would have likely caused this child's presentation?
questions.solution:
The deficiency of the essential fatty acid, linoleic acid, is likely to have caused this child's presentation of dry and scaly dermatitis.

Essential fatty acid (EFA) refers to polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) required for biological processes but is not synthesized by the body.

The two essential fatty acids in humans are as follows:

  • Linoleic acid (Omega 6): It is the precursor of arachidonic acid
  • α-Linolenic acid (Omega 3): It is the precursor of eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid.

Clinical Significance of PUFA and EFA

  1. PUFAs are used for esterification and excretion of cholesterol.
  2. Deficiency of EFA causes acanthocytosis, hyperkeratosis, acrodermatitis, and hypercholesterolemia.
  3. EFA deficiency is connected with acrodermatitis enteropathica, hepatorenal syndrome, and CNS manifestations.
  4. Elevated PUFA levels are seen in Zellweger’s syndrome.
  5. DHA levels in the blood are low in patients with retinitis pigmentosa.
  6. Trans fatty acids will compete with EFAs and may increase the EFA deficiency and decrease the fluidity of membranes.

Other options:

Options A & B: Oleic and palmitoleic acids are non-essential fatty acids. They can be synthesized in the body naturally. 

Option D: Arachidonic acid is non-essential fatty acid as it can be synthesized from linoleic acid.

questions.text: Dextromethorphan used as an antitussive agent is a:
questions.solution:
Dextromethorphan is a centrally-acting NMDA receptor antagonist that is used as an antitussive.

The antitussive action of dextromethorphan is due to the d-isomer, whereas the l-isomer is an analgesic.

Hallucinations at higher doses, gastrointestinal discomfort, and dizziness are well-known side effects. Dextromethorphan must be administered with caution to those with abuse potential.

Antitussives are a group of drugs that act centrally to raise the threshold of the cough centre or peripherally on the respiratory tract to reduce the tussal impulse or both.

The mechanism of action of other antitussives is as follows: 

  • Local anaesthetic action (option A) is seen in benzonatate which acts peripherally by anaesthetising the stretch receptors located in the respiratory passages, lungs and pleura. By decreasing the activity of these stretch receptors, benzonatate may reduce the cough reflex. Side effects include dysphagia and dizziness. Acute ingestion may cause seizures and cardiac arrest.
  • Neuromodulators (Option B) such as gabapentin and pregebalin inhibits neurotransmission.They are beneficial in neuropathic pain syndrome and chronic idiopathic cough. Side effects are somnolence and dizziness.
  • Opioids (Option C) such as codeine and pholcodine act centrally on the medullary opioid receptor in the medullary cough centre. Side effects include sedation and constipation.

questions.text: The structures shown in the below image are found in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image shows psammoma bodies. They are found in meningioma.

Meningioma is a benign tumor arising from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid layer and is an intradural extramedullary tumor. 

Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellated structures formed as a product of dystrophic calcification. They are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by infarction and calcification of papillae tips. 

Conditions associated with psammoma bodies include-

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Meningiomas. 

Other options:

Option A: Russell bodies are cytoplasmic globular inclusions that are seen in multiple myeloma.

Option C: Verocay bodies are spindle cells that are arranged to form central “nuclear-free zones” ramified by palisading nuclei and are seen in Schwanomma.

Option D: Call-Exner bodies are diagnostic gland-like immature follicles that are filled with an acidophilic material and are seen in granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.

Related Pearl: Pathological Named Bodies

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female patient is brought with complaints of acute and bilateral impairment of vision. She also has features of transverse myelitis and intractable hiccups. Antibodies against AQP-4 were detected. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?

AQP-4 - Aquaporin-4

p-ANCA - perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody

choices.text: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus with CNS involvement

questions.solution:
The clinical features are consistent with a diagnosis of neuromyelitis optica (NMO).

NMO, otherwise known as Devic’s disease, is an autoimmune, inflammatory demyelinating disorder that is predominantly seen in middle-aged women. It is associated with specific IgG antibodies against AQP-4.

There are recurrent attacks of bilateral optic neuritis as well as severe transverse myelitis. NMO is also characterized by brain lesions such as:

  • area postrema in the lower medulla causing area postrema syndrome (intractable hiccups and vomiting)
  • cerebral hemispheres causing focal symptoms, seizures, and encephalopathy
  • hypothalamus causing endocrinopathies

It is a recurrent disease and acute attacks are treated with glucocorticoids. Steroid-resistant patients are given empirical plasma exchange. Prophylactic empirical regimens are recommended and include mycophenolate mofetil, rituximab, and a combination of steroids and azathioprine. The newer monoclonal antibodies used in prophylaxis include:

  • eculizumab
  • inebilizumab
  • satralizumab 

Other options: 

Option A: Autoimmune encephalitis can present with a range of neurological symptoms and sometimes associated myelitis. However, autoimmune encephalitis is generally associated with anti-NMDA receptor antibodies and not AQP-4 antibodies.
 
Option B: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can cause a variety of neurological symptoms, including visual impairment and transverse myelitis. However, SLE is not typically associated with AQP-4 antibodies.
 
Option D: Sjögren’s syndrome causes lymphocytic infiltration of exocrine glands and is characterized by keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes), xerostomia, and profound B-cell hyperactivity. Anti-SSA/Ro60 autoantibodies are seen in this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY)?

choices.text: Autosomal recessive form of type 2 diabetes mellitus
MODY type 3 is most common form

questions.solution:
The true statement about MODY from the given options is that type 3 is the most common form.

Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY):

It is an autosomal-dominant form of type 2 diabetes mellitus affecting the younger population with a strong positive family history. It is a monogenic diabetes i.e only one gene mutation is present. Clinical features include glucose intolerance, along with association with renal cysts. There is insulinopenia with no antibodies and no insulin resistance. The patient does not have obesity, hypertension, or hyperlipidemia and responds to sulfonylureas.

There are 5 types of MODY:

  • Types 1,3,5: HNF Mutation – Hepatocyte nuclear transcription factor. Type 3 MODY is the most common form.
  • Type 2: Glucokinase mutation
  • Type 4: Insulin Promotor Factor-1 (PDX 1) mutation.

questions.text: The vessel marked in the image below ascends upwards over the right hemithorax and ultimately drains into the superior vena cava. Its origin is from all of the given vessels except?
questions.solution:
The marked image represents the azygos system of veins and its origin is not from the right brachiocephalic vein. 

The azygos system of veins drains the thoracic wall and the upper lumbar region. It forms a connecting channel between the superior and inferior venae cavae. It occupies the upper part of the posterior abdominal wall and the posterior mediastinum. It also connects the portal, caval system, and vertebral venous systems.

It is formed by the union of the lumbar azygos, right subcostal and right ascending lumbar veins. It enters the thorax by passing through the aortic opening in the diaphragm. It ascends up to the 4th thoracic vertebra, arching forward over the root of the right lung, and ends by joining the posterior aspect of the superior vena cava before piercing the pericardium. 

Tributaries of the azygous system of veins:

  • The right superior intercostal vein is formed by the union of the 2nd, 3rd and 4th posterior intercostal veins.
  • 5-11th right posterior intercostal veins
  • Hemi-azygos vein at the level of the lower border of the 8th thoracic vertebra.
  • Accessory hemiazygos vein at the level of the upper border of the 8th thoracic vertebra.
  • Right bronchial vein near the terminal end of the azygos vein
  • Several oesophageal, mediastinal, and pericardial veins. 

The hemi-azygos vein is formed by the union of the left lumbar azygos, left ascending lumbar, and left subcostal veins.

9th to 11th left posterior intercostal veins and esophageal veins drain into the hemi-azygous vein. It is also known as the inferior hemi-azygos vein.

The accessory hemiazygos vein is also known as the superior hemiazygos vein. 5th to 8th left posterior intercostal veins and sometimes the left bronchial veins drain into the accessory hemiazygos vein.

Given below is a schematic representation of the venous drainage of the thoracic wall:

questions.text: An 8-month-old child was brought to the pediatrician with complaints of seizures. Examination revealed delayed milestones. Chest and abdominal examination showed no significant findings. Fundoscopy revealed the following image. The enzyme that could be deficient in the child is:
questions.solution:
The presence of seizures, developmental delay, and cherry-red spots in the fundus (seen in the image), in an infant without hepatosplenomegaly, is suggestive of Tay-Sachs disease, which is due to the deficiency of hexosaminidase A.

In this condition, there is an accumulation of the lipid ganglioside. Other features include mental retardation, blindness, and muscle weakness. 

Other options:

Option A: β-Glucosidase deficiency is seen in Gaucher disease, which commonly has a combination of developmental delay and hepatosplenomegaly with the accumulation of glucocerebroside.

Option C: Sphingomyelinase deficiency leads to Niemann-Pick disease, where infants exhibit a combination of hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, interstitial lung disease, and retinal cherry-red spots.

Option D: α-Galactosidase deficiency leads to Fabry disease, which has symptoms of skin rash, kidney, heart failure, and burning pain in the lower extremities.
