Ceramide

Hoarseness, dermatitis, skeletal deformation, mental retardation; fatal in early life

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient with renal insufficiency presented with reduced urine output, pedal edema, headache, and a BP of 160/90 mmHg. Chlorthalidone was started for the patient. What is the likely mechanism of the drug used?
questions.solution:
Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic that acts by inhibiting the Na-Cl symport situated in the apical membrane of the distal convoluted tubules of the kidney.

It is among the first choice of drugs used in the management of hypertension. They have a longer half-life than thiazide-type diuretics and result in better 24-h control of arterial blood pressure.

Other uses:

  • Edema associated with congestive heart failure, liver cirrhosis, chronic kidney disease, and nephrotic syndrome
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Kidney stones caused by Ca2+ crystals

Side effects include hypokalemia, erectile dysfunction, carbohydrate intolerance, hyperuricemia, dyslipidemia, and increased risk of sudden cardiac death.

Other options:

Option A: Aliskiren is the only direct renin inhibitor and is effective in treating hypertension.

Option C: Calcium channel blockers are widely used as antihypertension. They include 3 subgroups: dihydropyridines, e.g. amlodipine phenylethylamine (verapamil) and benzothiazepine (diltiazem) are equally efficacious antihypertensives, but dihydropyridines are mainly used.

Option D: Prazosin is a selective α1 antagonist. It does not impair carbohydrate intolerance, has a favorable effect on lipid profiles, and relieves urinary symptoms in males with prostatic hypertrophy. However, it is generally not used as a first-line agent in hypertension as it can cause fluid retention.

Related Pearl: Site and mechanism of action of diuretics

Diuretics  Site of action  

Enzyme/receptor/transporter inhibited 
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors   Proximal tubule   Carbonic anhydrase  
Loop diuretics  Thick ascending loop of Henle  Na+- K+- 2Cl- symporter
Thiazides Distal convoluted tubule  Na+- Cl- symporter
Epithelial sodium channel inhibitors  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts   ENaC 
Aldosterone antagonists  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts  Mineralocorticoid receptors (indirectly ENaC)

questions.text: A man was stuck inside a building that caught fire. He died of suffocation due to smoke. Burn injuries were minimal. Which of the following postmortem changes is likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
The person died of suffocation due to smoke. This indicates carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning, which causes cherry-red postmortem hypostasis.

Victims of smoke inhalation are affected by carbon monoxide poisoning. Carbon monoxide has a higher affinity to haemoglobin as compared to oxygen and hence the amount of haemoglobin available for oxygen transport is markedly reduced. It can cause anaemic hypoxia. The binding of CO to haemoglobin results in cherry-red discolouration.

Other options:

Option A- Greenish-blue postmortem hypostasis is seen in poisoning due to hydrogen sulphide poisoning.

Option B- Pugilistic attitude is seen when muscle proteins are coagulated at high temperatures. Since this person did not die of burn injuries, a pugilistic attitude will not be seen.

Option D- Rigor mortis is not delayed. On the contrary, it may have a rapid onset because of heat.

Related Pearl: Color of Postmortem Hypostasis in Various Conditions

Poisoning/Condition Postmortem staining

Carbon monoxide   

Cherry red
Cyanides     

Brick red/dark pink

Potassium chlorate

 Chocolate brown 
Phosphorous  Dark brown 
Nitrites   

Red-brown

Hydrogen sulphide

Bluish-green

questions.text: Permanent alteration of the fingerprint pattern occurs in all of the following conditions, except ________.
questions.solution:
Permanent alteration of the fingerprint pattern does not occur in acromegaly.

Fingerprints are impressions of patterns formed by the papillary or epidermal ridges of the fingertips. The arrangement and distribution of the ridges not only remain unchanged throughout life but is unique for each individual. The study of this ridge pattern in the skin is called dermatoglyphics or dactylography and helps in the identification of the individual.

However, permanent impairment of the fingerprint pattern occurs in leprosy, electrical injury, and subsequent radiation exposure.

In acromegaly, there is a change in the distance between the ridges but no permanent impairment in the fingerprint pattern. A similar change is observed in infantile paralysis and rickets. Ridge alteration can also occur in eczema, acanthosis nigricans, scleroderma, and dry or atrophic skin. Additionally, there is moderate epidermal ridge atrophy and loss of pattern in celiac disease.

questions.text: A patient is in prolonged second stage of labor and has a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. Operative delivery using the instrument shown below is decided. Which of the following fetal complications can occur when using this kind of instrument?
questions.solution:
The image shows a Wrigley's forceps, an outlet forceps, and facial nerve injury can occur when using this kind of instrument.

Operative deliveries are vaginal deliveries that are achieved by using forceps or vacuum device. It is applied to the fetal head, thereby producing traction and assisting maternal pushing to deliver the fetus vaginally. 

Indications include fetal causes, such as nonreassuring fetal heart rate and premature placental separation, and maternal causes, such as prolonged second stage of labor and maternal exhaustion.  

The three common varieties of forceps used today are:

  • Das forceps (Long curved forceps)
  • Wrigley's forceps (Short curved forceps)
  • Kielland forceps

Complications include both maternal and fetal injuries. Maternal injuries include urinary incontinence and cervical lacerations. Fetal complications include facial nerve injury, depressed skull fracture, brachial plexus injury, and corneal abrasions.

Other options:

Options A and B: Urinary incontinence and cervical lacerations are maternal complications of forceps-assisted delivery.

Option C: Fetal femur fracture is a complication that can be expected in breech delivery. However, this is not caused by the usage of forceps. Piper forceps is used to deliver the after-coming head in breech.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

Related Pearl: Criteria for forceps delivery

Procedure Criteria
Outlet forceps
  • Scalp is visible at the introitus without separating the labia
  • Fetal skull has reached pelvic floor
  • Fetal head is at or on perineum
  • Sagittal suture is in anteroposteriordiameter or right or left occiput anterior or posterior position
  • Rotation does not exceed 45 degrees
Low forceps Leading point of fetal skull is at station > +2 cm and not on the pelvic floor:
a) Rotation is 45 degrees or less, or
b) Rotation is greater than 45 degrees
Mid forceps Station of fetal head is between 0 and +2 cm.

High forceps

 Not included in classification. Not used anymore.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy presented with steatorrhea and chronic diarrhea. An evaluation revealed delayed intellectual development and ataxia. Acanthocytes were seen on the peripheral blood smear. Ophthalmological examination showed the following. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image showing retinitis pigmentosa and presence of acanthocytes along with the given clinical features is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia.

Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare genetic disorder in which there is defective chylomicron formation. Chylomicrons are required for the absorption and transport of fats and fat-soluble vitamins.

It presents in early childhood with steatorrhoea and diarrhea, hypolipidemia, failure to thrive, ataxia, sensory and motor neuropathies.

questions.text: You are an intern attending rounds and you see a 30-year-old male with the following picture as given below. What is the most likely condition that has led to the following complication ?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a sebaceous horn which occurs as a complication of a sebaceous cyst. Sebaceous horn results from the hardening of the released sebum through the punctum.

Sebaceous cysts can occur anywhere in the body. It is usually fixed to the skin and has a central punctum. Complications include Cock's peculiar tumor, infection, and abscess formation.

Treatment depends upon the state of the cyst. Incision and drainage is done if the cyst is infected. 

Other options:

Option A: Dermoid cysts are slow-growing benign lesions. They are mostly seen on the scalp and skull. It is made of hair, teeth, cartilage, and skin glands. Other common sites are the forehead, postauricular, and lateral part of the eyebrow.

Options C and D: Cutaneous horns and keratoacanthomas are types of actinic keratoses.

  • Keratin or cutaneous horns are actinic keratoses with a height of at least half the widest diameter of their base. They are more prone to develop into squamous cell carcinoma. 
  • Keratoacanthomas are rapidly growing nodular tumours. It has a central keratin filled crater and exhibits symmetry around the centre. It is twice more common in men. Usual sites include face or limbs.

questions.text:
A hemodynamically stable patient developed regular, narrow complex PSVT. The patient had a history of stroke. Which of the following is best indicated for termination of arrhythmia?

PSVT- Paroxysmal supra-ventricular tachycardia
questions.solution:
Intravenous adenosine is preferred for termination of arrhythmia in this patient who is stable with regular and narrow complex PSVT (paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia).

Carotid sinus massage is provided as first-line therapy only if there is a low risk of carotid vascular disease. It is contraindicated in patients with carotid bruit and prior history of stroke as in this patient (option A).

Adenosine may precipitate atrial fibrillation. In patients with WPW syndrome, where AF may lead to hemodynamic instability, IV beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers (verapamil, diltiazem) are used (option C).

IV Procainamide is used if the above agents fail to terminate the arrhythmia.

questions.text: A software employee came for a master health checkup. Blood samples for glucose level estimation were taken in a test tube containing a particular substance that inhibits enzyme enolase during glycolysis. What is that substance?
questions.solution:
The substance in the blood sample test tube that inhibits the enzyme enolase during glycolysis is fluoride.

Enolase plays an important role in glycolysis by catalyzing 2- phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate and it requires magnesium ions to do this process. Fluoride irreversibly inhibits the enzyme by removing the magnesium ions. If fluoride is not added, the glucose would be metabolized causing a lower sugar value to be obtained. Therefore, blood samples are taken in tubes containing fluoride to inhibit glycolysis.

Other options:

Option A: Iodoacetate inhibits the enzyme glyceraldehyde 3- phosphate dehydrogenase which converts glyceraldehyde 3- phosphate to 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate during glycolysis. 

Option B and D: Fluoracetate, arsenite, and malonate are inhibitors in the TCA cycle.

They inhibit the following enzymes:

Enzyme Inhibitor
Aconitase Fluoroacetate
Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase Arsenite
Succinate dehydrogenase  Malonate

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

Related Pearl: Inhibitors of metabolic pathways

Inhibitors of glycolysis

Agent Enzyme
Iodoacetate Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase
Arsenate Phosphoglycerate kinase
Fluoride Enolase

 

Inhibitors of TCA cycle

Agent Enzyme
Fluoroacetate Aconitase

Arsenite

Complex Inhibitors
Complex I Piercidin, Amobarbital, Rotenone

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida presents with a one-week history of tingling and burning sensations in her hand, which worsens at night. Examination reveals bilateral wasting of muscles in the thenar eminence and positive Phalen's test. All the following findings can be seen in this patient except:

choices.text: Positive Tinel's sign by percussion of median nerve
Loss of thumb abduction tested by pen test

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of tingling and burning sensation worsening at night, bilateral thenar muscle wasting, and positive Phalen's test in a pregnant woman suggests a diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. In this condition, paresthesia is not seen over the thenar eminence as the sensory supply of this region is by the palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve, which passes superficial to the flexor retinaculum. 

Carpal tunnel syndrome is a common entrapment mononeuropathy. It is a condition in which the median nerve gets entrapped in the fibro-osseous carpal tunnel while passing beneath the flexor retinaculum.

Usually, the condition is idiopathic. But it can be caused due to soft tissue thickening (myxedema, acromegaly, obesity, pregnancy), arthritic changes in the carpal bones (rheumatoid arthritis, gout), and thickening of the synovial sheaths of the flexors tendons (tenosynovitis) due to stress injury, etc. 

Patients usually present at an age of 40-50 years with complaints of burning pain, paresthesia, and numbness of the first three digits, and the lateral half of the fourth digit (ring finger). The symptoms are worse at night and are relieved by shaking the arm or hanging it over the side of the bed. It may progress to weakness and clumsiness of the hand, especially when carrying out fine movements. In advanced cases, there is wasting of the thenar muscles, weakness of thumb abduction, and decreased sensations in the median nerve territory.

Signs seen in carpal tunnel syndrome are - 

  • Ape-like hand due to wasting of the thenar eminence. 

 

  • Ape thumb deformity is characterized by the inability to abduct the thumb due to paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle supplied by the median nerve. The thumb remains in the same plane as the wrist. 

 

  • Pen test tests the abductor pollicis brevis muscle which is supplied by the median nerve. The hand must remain flat with palm facing upwards; a pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb - Positive sign is unable to touch the pen. 

 

  • Durkan's test is positive where direct median nerve compression elicits paresthesias and pain.
  • Phalen's test is elicited by holding the wrist fully flexed. The appearance of sensory symptoms within 60 seconds implies a positive test.

 

  • Tinel's sign - Sensory symptoms (burning pain, tingling and numbness) are reproduced by percussing over the median nerve implying a positive test.

The diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome is usually clinical. Nerve conduction studies are done to confirm the diagnosis in case of atypical presentation of carpal tunnel syndrome.

In cases of mild clinical symptoms, splinting or glucocorticoid injections may be first tried. Surgical division of the transverse carpal ligament is recommended for severe CTS or if non-surgical management fails.

Related Pearl: Compression neuropathies

Posterior Interosseous nerve (in proximal forearm)

Tarsal tunnel syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following describes the wound shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The wound shown in the image is best described as an abrasion wound on the hand.

Abrasions are superficial wounds produced due to the destruction of the epidermis. Though exact age cannot be determined, based on healing and appearance of the wound, an estimated time can be given.

Abrasion types:

  • Linear abrasions (scratches): caused by relative movement of a pointed object on the skin
    • Ex: nail, thorn, the point of sword or knife
  • Grazed abrasions (sliding /scrapping/grinding abrasion): caused by relative movement of a rough surface on a wide area of skin.
    • known as brush burns; are the most common type of abrasions
    • Ex: fall, a victim being dragged on the ground, road traffic accidents
  • Imprint abrasions (patterned abrasions): caused by the impact of a rigid hard rough surface over a localized area of the skin without any movement
    • Ex: fingernail, tire, grills, bicycle chain, bite marks
  • Friction abrasions (pressure abrasion): are caused by crushing of the superficial layers of the epidermis.
    • Ex: ligature marks around the neck in hanging,

Other options:

Option A: A bruise or a contusion occurs due to blunt trauma that causes rupture of underlying blood vessels and extravasation of the blood into surrounding tissues. A fresh bruise is usually tender and is slightly raised above the surface of the skin. It has a lighter colour in the center because the extravasated blood is pushed outward by the impact of the trauma. A picture of a bruise is shown below:

 

Option B: A puncture wound is a stab wound that is produced when force is delivered along the long axis of a narrow or pointed object such as a knife, dagger, or sword into the soft tissues of the body. An image of a puncture wound is shown below:

 

Option D: A scald burn is an injury that occurs when the skin comes in contact with any liquid at a temperature above 60ºC or steam. Immediate redness is observed at the site followed by blistering. With the removal of the blistered skin, a pink raw surface is observed which later becomes brownish, hard, and dry. An image of a scald burn is shown below:

Related Pearl: Age of bruise and abrasion

Age and color change of bruise/contusion:

 

Colour Due to Duration  
Red Haemoglobin (fresh blood) Fresh  
Blue Deoxygenated haemoglobin Few hours to 3 days 
Bluish black/ brown Hemosiderin 4th day  
Green Hematoidin 5 to 6 days 
Yellow Bilirubin 7 to 12 days 
Normal colour Pigment removed by phagocytes  2 weeks

 

The image given below shows the age and colour change of bruise:

 

Age of abrasion:

Colour of scab Duration
Bright red 12-24 hrs
Reddish brown 2-3 days
Dark brown to brownish black 4-7 days
Scab dries shrinks and falls off After 7 days

questions.text: A young woman presents with complaints of severe insomnia. She has been feeling ants walking over the skin of her legs, and an irresistible urge to move the legs when at rest or while trying to fall asleep. The drug of choice for treating this condition would be:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with insomnia feeling ants walking over her skin along with an irresistible urge to move her legs when at rest or while trying to fall asleep is indicative of restless leg syndrome and gabapentin is the first-line choice of treatment for this condition.    

Restless leg syndrome is a typical sensory-motor disorder that generally affects the legs during rest periods, especially sleep. There is an irresistible urge to shake the legs associated with a burning sensation, itching, and cramps of the legs. Moving the leg or walking alleviates the symptoms. This cycle sometimes continues for hours during the night and can result in profound insomnia. Decreased dopamine receptor expression and mild dopaminergic hypofunction are usually noted in these patients.

In patients with restless legs syndrome, iron stores are initially repleted, and the aggravating factors are eliminated. If RLS still persists, initial therapy with a gabapentinoid (pregabalin, gabapentin, gabapentin enacarbil) is preferred, rather than a dopamine agonist (pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine). This is due to the high frequency of intermediate and long-term augmentation with dopamine agonists, as well as their risk of impulse control disorders.

FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of restless leg syndrome: 

  • Gabapentin
  • Ropinirole
  • Pramipexole
  • Rotigotine 

A dopamine agonist is used as an alternative in patients with increased risk for side effects from gabapentinoids, such as those with obesity and its complications, a past or present history of moderate to severe depression, a disorder causing gait instability or respiratory failure, and a history of substance use disorder.

questions.text: An elderly postmenopausal woman with a history of fragility fracture has been evaluated in the orthopedics outpatient department. Her X-ray image is given below. Investigations reveal normal calcium and alkaline phosphatase. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An elderly postmenopausal woman with a history of fragility fracture, normal calcium and alkaline phosphatase levels, and X-ray showing thinning of the cortices is most likely to have osteoporosis. 

Risk factors for osteoporosis include:

  • Increasing age and female sex
  • Alcohol and smoking
  • Previous history of fractures and family history of hip fractures
  • Low body mass index of less than 18.5 kg/sq.m
  • Excessive use of glucocorticoids 

They are usually asymptomatic or present with fractures especially Colle’s fracture, fractures of the hip, and those of the vertebrae.

Laboratory examination reveals normal calcium and alkaline phosphatase levels.

Radiographic findings include loss of trabecular definition, thinning of the cortices, and fractures. In postmenopausal osteoporosis, wedging of the vertebra may be seen due to compression of vertebral bodies.

Treatment options include bisphosphonates, denosumab, parathyroid hormones (Preottact and teriparatide), selective estrogen receptor modulator, and romosozumab.

Other options:

Option A -  Osteomalacia is a disorder of bone mineralization characterized by softening of the bone. It is more common in adults and leads to fragility fractures. Lab findings reveal normal/low calcium and elevated alkaline phosphatase. 

Option C - Paget’s disease is a condition where there is an increased bone turnover followed by enlargement and thickening of the bone. In this condition, calcium levels are normal with raised ALP

Option D - Osteopetrosis is characterized by abnormally dense bone with poor or absent medullary canal formation. The skull base is uniformly radio-dense and radiolucent bands through sclerotic vertebrae are often seen and referred to as the ‘rugger-jersey’ sign.

Related Pearl: Biochemical parameters in metabolic bone diseases

Metabolic bone disease

 Calcium PTH Phosphate ALP

Rickets / Osteomalacia

  ↓/N    ↑         ↓    ↑

Primary

hyperparathyroidism

      ↑    ↑        ↓  ↑

Secondary

hyperparathyroidism

      ↓    ↑        ↑     ↑

Tertiary hyperparathyroidism

      ↑     ↑        ↑    ↑
Osteoporosis      N    N       N   N

 ↑: Increased,  ↓: Decreased, N: Normal

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: Maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for a country is best given as:
questions.solution:
The maternal mortality ratio is the number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 live births during the same period.

Maternal death is defined as

  • Death of a woman while pregnant.
  • Death during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

MMR = (No. of maternal deaths in a given year/Total no. of live births in the same year) x 100,000

In a developing country like India, maternal mortality is a huge public health issue. The most common causes are postpartum hemorrhage and infections, which mainly occur when women do not give birth at hospitals or health centers.

The main contributor to a decline in maternal mortality is the rise in institutional deliveries.

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.

In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

questions.text: Pseudocyst of the pancreas most commonly occurs due to:
questions.solution:
Pancreatic pseudocysts most commonly occurs due to inflammation. 

Pancreatic pseudocyst refers to a chronic collection of pancreatic fluid surrounded by granulation tissue and fibrosis. This complication is more common with chronic pancreatitis than with acute cases.

In chronic pancreatitis, pancreatic juice extravasates through a leak in the pancreatic duct and gets accumulated as a peripancreatic fluid collection (PPFC) which over a period of 3-4 weeks gets surrounded by granulation tissue and forms an acute pseudocyst and beyond 6 weeks forms a chronic pseudocyst. 

It causes symptoms such as abdominal pain, fullness, and early satiety.

Management options include

  • Conservative measures if asymptomatic
  • Internal drainage when conservative management fails
  • Surgical methods like cystogastrostomy, Roux-en-Y cystojejunostomy, or a cystoduodenstomy 
  • Resection if located in the tail of pancreas or distally located.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presented with breathlessness. He has been tachypneic for the past 30 minutes. He had a panic attack this morning and has been breathless since then. An arterial blood gas analysis (ABG) was done and the report is shown below. Which of the following is the correct interpretation of his ABG?

pH: 7.50

HCO3: 22mEq/L

pCO2: 31 mm Hg.

pO2: 75 mm Hg.
questions.solution:
The correct interpretation of the acid-base abnormality in this man who has been hyperventilating since morning would be respiratory alkalosis. 

In the given question,

  • pH is increased (normal pH - 7.35 to 7.45 )
  • pCO2 is decreased (normal pCO2 - 35 to 45 mm Hg)
  • HCO3- is normal (normal HCO3-  22 mEq/L to 28 mEq/L)

During panic attacks, there is alveolar hyperventilation. This leads to decreased PaCO2 and increased pH. If hypocapnia persists for more than 2-6 hours, then there would be a further decrease in renal filtered HCO3- reabsorption, and a decrease in renal ammonium and titrable acid excretion. 

Respiratory alkalosis leads to decreased blood flow, further resulting in dizziness, mental confusion, and seizures. This may occur in the absence of hypoxemia. Respiratory alkalosis may be seen in critically ill patients and before the onset of rapid respiratory failure. 

Other options:

Option B: In respiratory acidosis, the pH is decreased while pCO2 is increased. 

Option C: Metabolic alkalosis is associated with increased pH and bicarbonate levels.

Option D: Metabolic acidosis is associated with decreased blood arterial pH and loss of HCO3- 

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

Related Pearl: Causes of Acid-Base Disorders

Metabolic acidosis

Metabolic alkalosis

Respiratory acidosis

Respiratory alkalosis

Ketoacidosis

Lactic acidosis

Chronic renal failure

Salicylate intoxication

Methanol/formaldehyde intoxication

Ethylene glycol intoxication

Diarrhoea

Renal tubular acidosis

Vomiting

Hyperaldosteronism

Loop or thiazide diuretics

Opiates, sedatives, anesthesia

Guillain- Barre syndrome, Polio, ALS, multiple sclerosis

Airway obstruction

Adult respiratory distress syndrome, COPD

Pneumonia, pulmonary embolism

High altitude

Psychogenic

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A 26-year-old lady, with G2P1L1, at 34 weeks of gestation came for a regular check-up. On examination, her fundal height corresponds to 28 weeks of gestation. Doppler scan showed the following flow pattern in the umbilical arteries. What does the waveform indicate?
questions.solution:
The given flow pattern of umbilical arteries indicates absent end-diastolic flow, leading to intrauterine growth restriction. 

Other common flow patterns are shown below:

questions.text: A 58-year-old man on multiple antibiotics is suspected to have pseudomembranous colitis. The criteria for the diagnosis of the suspected condition include all, except ______.

choices.text: Detection of toxin A or B in stool
Stool wet mount microscopy to visualize the organism
Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days)

questions.solution:
Stool wet mount microscopy to visualize the organism is not part of the criteria for the diagnosis of pseudomembranous colitis.

Pseudomembranous colitis is caused by the gram-positive bacillus Clostridium difficile. It is most commonly associated with the use of antimicrobials like cephalosporin, ampicillin, fluoroquinolones, and clindamycin.

C. difficile produces two high-molecular-weight exotoxins, toxin A and toxin B, which are involved in the pathogenesis of the condition. Toxin A is an enterotoxin that attaches to gut receptors and may also be cytotoxic, while toxin B is a cytotoxin. The strains can produce either or both toxins. 

The diagnosis is based on a combination of two criteria:
1. Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days)
2. Detection of toxins A and B in stools, detection of toxin-producing C. difficile by NAAT/culture, and visualization of the pseudomembrane in the colon

The endoscopic image given below shows pseudomembranous colitis caused by C. difficile infection:

 

Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and adequate hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can also be used.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: A 21-year-old boy is brought by his parents with a history of nausea, anxiety, confusion, and delusions. He gives a history of ingestion of a beverage containing dried leaves and fruiting shoots of the following plant. Urine testing reveals positive traces of tetrahydrocannabinol. What is the most likely preparation used by him?
questions.solution:
The most likely preparation used by him is bhang.

The clinical vignette of a boy presenting with nausea, anxiety, confusion, and delusions subsequent to ingestion of a beverage made from the leaves of the cannabis plant, in addition to the presence of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) in the urine is indicative of acute THC intoxication.

Bhang is a preparation of dried leaves and fruiting shoots of the Cannabis plant which is ingested. It can be taken as a bolus or pills or mixed with water and strained through a muslin cloth before it is drunk.

The effects of THC depend upon dosage, frequency, route of administration, the experience and expectations of the individual, smoking technique, the amount destroyed by pyrolysis, and how quickly the drug is used. 

Acute intoxication is characterized by a feeling of cheerfulness and well-being and appetite is increased. Impaired memory, reaction time, perception, motor coordination, and attention are other common symptoms.

Large doses can give rise to nausea, anxiety, confusion, hallucinations, and delusions. Persons with an excitable temperament may exhibit violent behaviour. This is followed by a stage of narcosis characterized by giddiness, confusion, drowsiness, dilated pupils, and tingling and numbness of the extremities.

The images below show  process of making bhang. 


Other options:
Options A and C: Ganja and Hashish are cannabis preparations that are smoked with an addition of a little tobacco, in a pipe.

Option D: Majun has a sweet taste and is sold as a confectionary. It consists of bhang, sugar, flour, milk, and butter.

Related Pearl: Cannabis Forms

  • Bhang: Decoction prepared from dried leaves and fruit shoot
  • Majoon: Sweet prepared from bhang
  • Ganja: Prepared from flower tops of female plant and smoked
  • Charas: Most potent; resin exudate from leaves and stems that's smoked

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, nausea, and dizziness for the past few weeks. His investigations reveal hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. He also complains of skin changes as seen in the image below. He was previously diagnosed with Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation, along with the history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis and the image showing skin hyperpigmentation, is highly suggestive of Addison’s disease. Hyperglycemia is not a feature of this condition.

Addison's disease occurs due to primary adrenal insufficiency. The secretion of both glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids is impaired, resulting in various clinical manifestations.

The clinical features of Addison’s disease include:

  • Features of hypoaldosteronism- 
    • Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, salt craving
    • Dizziness, postural hypotension
    • Acute kidney injury due to volume depletion
    • Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis
  • Features of decreased cortisol-
    • Anorexia, weight loss, fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia, fever (increased IL-1)
    • Postural hypotension, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia (loss of feedback inhibition of ADH)
    • Slightly increased TSH (loss of feedback inhibition)
  • Decreased androgens-
    • Loss of libido, loss of pubic and axillary hair
  • Features of elevated ACTH- hyperpigmentation

questions.text: An emphysematous patient with a known alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency developed icterus, with mild hepatomegaly and flapping tremors. The liver biopsy findings of this patient are shown below. Which of the following properties correlate with the histopathology staining in this condition?

choices.text: Periodic Acid Schiff - Positive , Diastase - Sensitive
Periodic Acid Schiff - Positive , Diastase - Resistant
Periodic Acid Schiff - Negative , Diastase - Sensitive
Periodic Acid Schiff - Negative , Diastase - Resistant

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency and periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant staining properties of the liver histopathology correlate with this condition.

It is an autosomal recessive disorder of protein misfolding that occurs due to a mutation in chromosome 14 and results in impaired secretion of α1 antitrypsin into the serum. This results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase.

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is characterized by the presence of round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes, that are strongly Periodic acid–Schiff positive after diastase digestion of the liver, and highlights the characteristic magenta cytoplasmic granules. As a consequence of the abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes, deranged liver enzymes and icterus suggestive of cirrhosis, chronic hepatitis, and hepatocellular carcinoma can occur. 

Other uses of PAS include the demonstration of amoeba, mucin, fungi, macrophages in Whipple's disease, adenocarcinomas, and glycogen-positive tumors (Ewings sarcoma, renal cell carcinoma)

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Cells/inclusions stained Disorders
H&E Most common stain used in routine histopathology Commonly used for all slides
Papanicolaou stain Universal stain for cytological preparations Cytological studies
PAS Demonstrate glycogen, mucin, fungi, macrophages  Whipple's disease, adenocarcinomas, and glycogen-positive tumors (Ewings sarcoma, renal cell carcinoma)
PTAH (Phosphotungstic acid hematoxylin) Fibrin Gliosis, Ependymomas, Tumours of skeletal muscles, Fibrin deposits
Alcian blue For acid mucins: Positive stain for mucins of the intestinal mucosa and negative stain for mucins of gastric mucosa and Brunner's gland Barrett's esophagus, Gastric disorders
Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron Hemochromatosis 
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin Nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium Calcification of tissues
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in; Differentiate amyloid from collagen

Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle Connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases 
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers Distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis

Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma 

Microbiology stains:

Stain  Uses
Ziehl–Neelsen Stain Mycobacteria (all species, including Mycobacterium leprae), Nocardia spp. Cyst of Cryptosporidium parvum, Isospora spp., and Cyclospora spp., Head of sperms

questions.text: A primigravid woman at 34 weeks of gestation was taken for emergency cesarean section after presenting with premature rupture of membranes and severe abdominal pain. Laparotomy revealed patches of dark port wine color over the uterus. In which of the following conditions can this complication be expected?
questions.solution:
The laparotomy finding is suggestive of uteroplacental apoplexy/Couvelaire uterus, and this complication can be expected in abruptio placenta.

Abruptio placenta is the partial/total placental separation from its implantation site before delivery. The bleeding may be:

  • Revealed (blood dissects downwards between membranes and uterine wall to escape through the cervix) or
  • Concealed (blood accumulates between detached placenta and uterus)

Risk factors for abruptio placenta include prior abruption history, preterm premature rupture of membranes, and pregnancy-associated hypertension. Patients often present with sudden onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions.

Uteroplacental apoplexy/Couvelaire uterus is a complication seen in severe types of concealed abruptio placentae. There is massive intravasation of blood into the uterine musculature, potentially extending up to the serous coat. It is only diagnosed on laparotomy, where a port-wine-colored uterus (diffuse or patchy) is seen. Though the uterus may lose its contractility, increasing the risk of bleeding, it rarely causes uterine atony. Hence, Couvelaire uterus does not require hysterectomy until uterine atony occurs.

Other complications of abruptio placenta include: 

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Hypovolemic shock due to torrential bleeding
  • Acute kidney injury

Abruptio placenta is mostly managed by immediate delivery and management of complications such as shock with adequate blood products.

Other options: 

Option A: Placenta previa occurs when the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment over or very near to the cervical os. Vaginal bleeding is usually painless in this condition.

Option B: Preeclampsia is a multisystem disorder that occurs after 20 weeks due to the new onset of hypertension and proteinuria. Patients complain of headaches, epigastric pain, decreased urine output, and blurring of vision.

Option D: Uterine inversion is a complication that occurs in the third stage of labor. The uterus is partially/completely turned inside out due to various factors, such as fundally implanted placenta, uterine atony, placenta accrete syndrome, and cord traction before the placenta is separated. It produces acute lower abdominal pain with a bearing down sensation and leads to massive bleeding.

questions.text: A 20-year-old fisherman presents with firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules on the hairs of the scalp. He has no other complaints. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of black piedra. It is a fungal infection of the hair shafts caused by Piedraia hortae resulting in hard, dark, gritty superficial nodules. 

The fungus produces sexual spores in its parasitic phase. As the fungus grows into the hair shaft, the hair may fracture easily. 

Shaving or cutting the hair effects a cure and to prevent a recurrence, antifungal preparation such as benzoic acid ointment is used.  

Option B: Trichosporon beigelli causes white piedra or trichosporosis nodosa.

Option C: Hortaea werneckii causes tinea nigra.

Option D: Aspergillus niger causes otomycosis.

Image: Black piedra- formation of superficial, dark, and gritty nodules

 

Image: White Piedra - formation of superficial, soft, white, grey, or brown nodules.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with fever, joint pain, and dyspnea. X-ray findings revealed bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. A diagnosis of sarcoidosis was made and further biopsy of the lesions was sent for histopathology. Which of the following will not be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Birbeck bodies are tennis racket–like appearing pentalaminar tubules that are associated with Langerhan cell histiocytosis and will not be seen in sarcoidosis. 

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease involving multiple systems occurring due to disordered immune regulation. The diagnostic histopathologic feature of sarcoidosis, irrespective of the organ involved, is the non-caseating granuloma. Other organs involved in the disease process are: 

  • skin that shows subcutaneous nodules and erythema nodosum (painful lesions on the shin)
  • lungs that show non-cavitated consolidations 
  • lymph nodes that show hilar lymphadenopathy
  • eyes that show iridocyclitis and sicca syndrome

The other microscopic features that are seen include: 

  • Schaumann bodies: Inclusion bodies with concentric rings of calcification
  • Asteroid bodies: Stellate inclusions found within the giant cells

Related Pearl: Types of granulomas

GRANULOMA SEEN IN
Noncaseating granuloma

Crohn’s disease

Leprosy

Sarcoidosis

Hodgkin’s lymphoma
Caseating granuloma

Tuberculosis

Histoplasmosis

Syphilis

Coccidiomycosis
Foreign body granuloma

Silicosis

Berylliosis
Immune granuloma

Wegener’s granulomatosis

Giant cell arteritis
Durck’s granuloma Cerebral malaria
Stellate granuloma Cat scratch disease

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for inducing labor?
questions.solution:
Oligohydramnios is an indication for inducing labor.

Induction of labor is the process of stimulating uterine contractions for vaginal delivery by medical or surgical methods. It is indicated when the benefit to the mother or fetus outweighs the benefit of continuing the pregnancy.

Other options:

Options A, B, and D- Active maternal genital herpes infection, cephalopelvic disproportion, and placenta previa are indications for cesarean delivery. 

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented with a ​squint. On examination, the secondary deviation was found to be more than the primary deviation. Forced duction test is positive. Which of the following types of squint is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A restrictive squint is most likely in this patient.

The above clinical scenario of a patient presenting with a squint, with the secondary deviation more than the primary deviation, and a positive forced duction test is indicative of a restrictive squint.

In strabismus or squint, the visual axes of the eye take up a position other than the regular physiological position, relative to each other.

The squint may be either concomitant, where the amount of deviation in the eye affected remains constant in all directions of gaze, or incomitant, where the amount of deviation varies in different directions of gaze. 

The differences between concomitant and incomitant squint are:

Features Concomitant squint Incomitant squint
Magnitude of squint Same in all gazes Varies with the gaze
Diplopia Absent Present
Ocular movements Full Restricted
False projection Absent Present
Abnormal head posture Absent Present
Secondary deviation Equal to primary deviation More than primary deviation

Paralytic squint is one of the two types of incomitant squint, that results from partial or complete paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles. The other type is restrictive squint, where the movement of the extraocular muscle(s) is restricted due to conditions like fibrosis of the muscle.

Forced duction test helps differentiate between these two types. In this test, the patient is first asked to turn his/her eye maximally in the direction in which movement is being tested. Subsequently, the eyeball is moved in the same direction by the examiner, using toothed forceps placed at the limbus.

  • The test is negative if there is no resistance to the movement. This is seen in a paralytic squint.
  • The test is positive if there is resistance to the movement. This is seen in a restrictive squint.

The visual axes are parallel in apparent squint or pseudostrabismus, but the eyes seem to have a squint.

Related Pearl: Classification of Strabismus

  • Pseudostrabismus—Apparent squint
    • Pseudo esotropia
    • Pseduo exotropia
  • Heterophoria—Latent squint
    • Esophoria: Convergent
    • Exophoria: Divergent
    • Hyperphoria: Deviation upwards
    • Hypophoria: Deviation downwards
    • Cyclophoria: Rotation around AP axis
  • Heterotropia—Manifest squint
  • Concomitant
    • Amount of deviation remains constant in all directions of gaze.
    • Esotropia: Convergent
      • Infantile
      • Accommodative
      • Sensory
      • Consecutive
    • Exotropia: Divergent
      • Congenital
      • Primary
      • Secondary: Sensory deprived
      • Consecutive
    • Hypertropia: Vertical squint
  • Incomitant
    • Amount of deviation varies in different directions of gaze
      • Paralytic squint
      • Restrictive squint
      • A and V pattern heterotropia

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient is to undergo mastoid surgery. Which of the following instruments will not be required during this surgery?
questions.solution:
Lichwitz trocar and cannula (image 4) is not used in mastoid surgery. It is used for a proof puncture/antral lavage, where maxillary sinus is irrigated via puncturing of its medial wall.

Other options:

Option A: Lempert’s endaural speculum is used to spread open the meatus when giving a local injection or making an endaural incision. 

 

Option B: Lempert’s endaural retractor is used for endaural approach to ear surgery. It has two lateral blades that retract the flaps and a third central blade with holes. The central blade retracts the temporalis muscle and can be fixed to the body of the retractor by its holes.

 

Option C: Lempert’s curette (scoop) is used for the removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient previously treated for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma presents with similar symptoms. Radio-imaging confirms a recurrence with an inaccessible intracranial extension. Which of the following treatment approaches is considered now?
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is considered for recurrent inaccessible juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA).

JNA is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumor seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional mortality. 

Patients usually present with:

  • Epistaxis (most common presentation): Profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous
  • Mass: A mass may be present in either the postnasal space, resulting in progressive nasal obstruction, or nasopharynx, where it may obstruct both choanae. The mass is firm in consistency, but digital palpation of the same should not be done. If the mass obstructs the eustachian tube, conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion may be observed.
  • Proptosis, swelling of the cheeks, broadening of nasal bridge, and involvement of 2nd, 3rd, 4th and 6th cranial nerves: May occur

JNA can be diagnosed using CT, MRI, and carotid angiography. Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus due to the presence of a mass in the pterygomaxillary space is a characteristic CT finding of JNA. This is known as the Holman-Miller sign or antral sign, as shown in the image below.

 

Recurrence has been reported up to 35%. Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Recurrent angiofibroma is treated with revision surgery or radiotherapy when the tumor is inaccessible.

Other options:

Option A: Hormonal therapy can be used as primary or adjunctive treatment. Since it is commoner in adolescent males in their twenties, the tumor may be testosterone dependant. Therefore, hormonal therapy with diethylstilbestrol and an androgen blocker like flutamide may be considered.

Option B: Chemotherapy with doxorubicin, vincristine, and dacarbazine is used in case of very aggressive recurrent tumors and residual tumors.

Option C: Endoscopic approach is not useful as the stem clearly mentions that the tumor is inaccessible.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with diarrhoea, steatorrhea, low-grade fever, abdominal pain and joint pains. Colonoscopy is normal. Duodenal biopsy revealed the presence of PAS-positive foamy macrophages containing gram-positive bacilli. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: IV glucocorticoids for 3 days followed by oral glucocorticoids for 1 year
IV meropenem for 2 weeks followed by oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 1 year

questions.solution:
The clinical features and the duodenal biopsy showing the presence of PAS-positive macrophages containing gram-positive bacilli are suggestive of Whipple's disease. The current regimen for treatment includes intravenous ceftriaxone or meropenem for 2 weeks followed by oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) for 1 year.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by a gram-positive bacillus Tropheryma whipplei. It primarily causes malabsorption along with central nervous system & cardiac problems.

The disease has an insidious onset, characterized by diarrhoea, steatorrhea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and migratory large-joint arthropathy. Patients may also have ophthalmologic and CNS symptoms. Few patients who develop a relapse after remission may present with dementia.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is made through a biopsy which shows PAS-positive macrophages containing  the gram-positive bacilli in the small intestine.

The treatment regimen includes ceftriaxone 1 g intravenously twice daily or meropenem 1 g intravenously three times daily for 2 weeks. It is followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole 160/800 mg twice daily for 12 months.

Other options:

Option A: The use of IV glucocorticoids for 3 days followed by oral glucocorticoids for 1 year is not included in the management of patients with Whipple's disease.

Option B & D: Numerous randomized controlled trials have proven the failure of remission of patients when treated with tetracyclines or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole when used as monotherapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with oliguria, haematuria, and pedal edema over the past 3 days. He complains that his symptoms worsened rapidly. On examination, he has a BP of 190/140 mmHg. Blood workup shows elevated serum creatinine and blood urea. Histological studies show crescents in the glomeruli as seen in the image below. Which of the following type of nephritis does the clinical scenario suggest?
questions.solution:
The rapidly worsening symptoms and the histologic picture are suggestive of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) also known as crescentic glomerulonephritis. 

It is a syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis and the formation of crescents. The disease progresses rapidly and leads to renal failure in weeks to months when not treated. In the majority of the cases, RPGN is immune-mediated. In pauci-immune type of RPGN, circulating anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) are detected in most cases. Serum analyses for anti-GBM antibodies, antinuclear antibodies, and ANCAs are helpful in the diagnosis of specific subtypes.

Other options:

Option B: Minimal change disease - presence of difuse effacement of podocytes (epithelial cell foot process) which is characteristic. It is one of the common causes of nephrotic syndrome. However, this glomerular abnormality can only be detected using electron microscopy and appear normal by light microscopy. 

Option C: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis - presence of focal and segmental scarring of the glomeruli most prominently seen at the corticomedullary junction.

Option D: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis - presence of thickenend glomerular basement membrane with mesangioproliferation and are of three types where type 1 is associated with hepatitis C infection while type 2 and 3 are idiopathic or complement mediated.

Related Pearl: Types of Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis

Type I (Anti-GBM Antibody)

Renal limited

Goodpasture syndrome

Immunofluorescence: 

Linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3

Type II (Immune Complex)

Idiopathic

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Lupus nephritis

Henoch–Schönlein purpura

IgA nephropathy

Others: Cryoglobulinemia, Bacterial endocarditis, sepsis, acute pancreatitis/advanced liver disease

Immunofluorescence: Granular pattern of staining

Type III (Pauci-Immune)

ANCA-associated

Idiopathic

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis
Immunofluorescence: No immunoglobulin or complement deposits

 

Image: Crescentic glomerulonephritis (PAS stain) with the crescent-shaped mass of proliferating parietal epithelial cells and leukocytes internal to Bowman capsule.

questions.text: A patient presents to the ophthalmology OPD with a sudden, severe diminution of vision in his right eye. Relative afferent pupillary defect is present. What is the probable diagnosis in this patient with the fundoscopic findings shown below?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is ischaemic central retinal vein occlusion.

The clinical vignette of a patient developing sudden, severe painless diminution of vision, with relative afferent pupillary defect and funduscopy of the eye showing massive retinal haemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance, are all suggestive of ischaemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO).

Other features of ischaemic CRVO on fundoscopy include numerous cotton wool spots - usually more than 6 to 10, disc showing oedema and hyperaemia, and the macular area is full of haemorrhages and is severely oedematous.

In later stages, the fundus shows marked sheathing around veins, with collaterals and neovascularization seen around and at the disc or periphery respectively.
Macula shows marked pigmentary changes and chronic cystoid oedema.

The complications include Rubeosis iridis, i.e. neovascularisation of iris and neovascular glaucoma occurs within 3 months and this is also called "90 days glaucoma".

Vitreous haemorrhage and proliferative retinopathy may also occur in a few cases. Treatment usually involves treating the underlying cause and complications.

Other options:
Option A: Non-ischaemic CRVO, also called venous stasis retinopathy, is characterised by sudden onset mild to moderate blurring of vision. Relative afferent pupillary defect is either absent or if present, mild. Pathognomonic features of ischaemic CRVO differentiating it from non-ischaemic CRVO are the presence of relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), visual field defects and reduced amplitude of b-wave on electroretinogram

Option C: Branched retinal vein occlusion is characterised by a sudden painless onset of blurred vision if the macula is involved, whereas peripheral occlusion is asymptomatic. Iris neovascularization and neovascular glaucoma are both less common in BRVO than in CRVO. On fundoscopy, dilatation and tortuosity of the affected venous segment is observed, with flame-shaped and dot/blot haemorrhages in the retinal area. Cotton wool spots and retinal edema may also be present.

Option D: Central retinal artery occlusion is characterised by sudden profound loss of vision, that is painless and visual acuity is severely reduced. Relative afferent pupillary defect is profound, giving rise to an amaurotic pupil and fundoscopy shows the presence of a cherry red spot at the region of the foveola. The peripapillary retina appears swollen and opaque.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male patient presents with pain around the knee joint. His radiographic image is given below. Which among the following is the management for the condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the x-ray image showing sunburst appearance and Codman's triangle, in the proximal tibia are suggestive of osteosarcoma, and the management for this patient would be wide excision.

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone with bimodal age of distribution peaking in adolescence and during the 7th decade. The most common site involved is the distal femoral metaphysis which mainly presents with pain and swelling. Other sites commonly involved are the proximal tibia, proximal femur, and humerus.

X-rays are diagnostic showing Codman’s triangle (new bone formation in response to periosteal elevation) and a ‘sunburst’ appearance when the periosteum does not have enough time to lay down a new layer. 

Wide excision and reconstruction are preferred if the tumor is resectable and there are no skip lesions. It is done after starting neoadjuvant chemotherapy for 8-12 weeks. Chemotherapeutic agents used are doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate.

Other options:

Option A: Curettage is mainly used for the management of giant cell tumors. It is a benign, locally aggressive tumor presenting in the 2nd-4th decade with distal femoral metaphysis or epiphysis as the most common site. Radiographic findings include solitary lytic lesion and soap bubble appearance and the below image shows the same

 

 

Option B: Radiofrequency ablation is the preferred treatment for osteoid osteoma. It is a benign tumor formed of osteoid and woven bone. It is common in men and most commonly occurs in the diaphysis of the femur.

Option D: Intralesional steroids are used in the management of simple bone cysts that occur most commonly in males near the metaphyseal areas. On X-rays, it shows a fallen leaf sign ( a small fragment is seen within the cavity)

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient with short stature, disproportionate spine, barrel chest with pectus carinatum and a short neck came to the OPD. On evaluation, a diagnosis of lysosomal storage disorder is made. The glycosaminoglycan involved in the condition is a prominent component of which among the following?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucopolysaccharidoses IV and the glycosaminoglycan involved is chondroitin sulfate, which is a prominent component of cartilage.

It is composed of repeating units of N-acetyl galactosamine and glucuronic acid (GAG).

In this condition, the affected individuals survive into adulthood with normal faces and intellect. Short stature with a disproportionate spine, barrel chest with pectus carinatum, and short neck and limb abnormalities may be present.

Some important features of chondroitin sulfate are as follows:

  • The most abundant GAG in the body and is seen in the cartilage, CNS, and bone
  • They are located at sites of calcification in endochondral bone and are a major component of cartilage.
  • They are found in high amounts in the extracellular matrix of the central nervous system.

Other options:

Option A: Keratan sulfate I and II are the GAGs in the cornea. It is also found in cartilage and loose connective tissue. It is the only GAG that does not contain any uronic acid. The repeating units are galactose and N-acetyl glucosamine in beta linkage.

Option C: Heparan sulfate is the GAG present in the kidney basement membrane, where it plays a major role in determining the charge selectiveness of glomerular filtration. It is also found in the skin. It contains repeating units of sulfated glucosamine and glucuronic acid.

Option D: Hyaluronic acid is the GAG present in synovial fluid. It is also found in skin, bone, cartilage, vitreous humor, and embryonic tissues. It contains repeating units of  N-acetyl glucosamine and glucuronic acid. It plays a role in morphogenesis and wound repair. The high concentrations of hyaluronic acid along with chondroitin sulfates in cartilage contribute to its compressibility.

The images below show the structure of the cartilage matrix containing glycosaminoglycans and the structure of aggrecan, a major proteoglycan present in cartilage.

questions.text: Community weed removal from ponds for the control of a disease was documented in Shertallai, Kerala, India.  Which of the following water-related diseases can be controlled by this approach?
questions.solution:
Filariasis (caused by B.malayi ), a water-related disease, can be controlled by the removal of weeds from ponds. It is transmitted by the Mansonia species of mosquito that breeds in water bodies containing aquatic vegetation and can also be controlled by the use of herbicides that destroy aquatic vegetation.

Adult Mansonia mosquitos are big, black or brown mosquitoes with speckling on their wings and legs. They breed in ponds and lakes containing certain aquatic plants, especially the floating types like Pistia stratiotes and water hyacinth. Their breeding is not possible in absence of these plants. Thus, removing the aquatic vegetation and destroying the vegetation using herbicides can be done to control filariasis. 

The image below shows a picture of a Mansonia mosquito: 

Other options:

Option A: Weil's disease is a form of leptospirosis that occurs due to spirochaete Leptospira. It is excreted in the urine of infected animals for a long time.

Option C: Cholera is an acute diarrhoeal disease caused by Vibrio cholerae. It is usually acquired through contaminated water and food.

Option D: Giardiasis is a waterborne disease caused by protozoa Giardia intestinalis. It is acquired through contaminated food or water and causes diarrhoea.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding.

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady comes with complaints of abdominal cramping and breast pain that is cyclical and occurs once a month. It is associated with headaches and difficulty concentrating at work. She notices that the pain begins a week before menstruation and resolves after menses. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of premenstrual syndrome.

Premenstrual syndrome (premenstrual tension) is a functional disorder and is recognized by cyclical changes that are associated with ovulatory cycles. It is usually seen in middle-aged women and occurs 1-2 weeks before menstruation and resolves after menses. 

The classical symptoms include abdominal cramps, increasing breast tenderness, abdominal bloating, headache, sleeplessness, fatigue, difficulty in concentrating, and mood swings. The diagnosis is made on the basis of a carefully elicited history. Asking patients to document their symptoms in the form of a menstrual diary can also aid in diagnosis. 

Treatment includes counseling and therapy for psychological symptoms, limiting salt intake, and symptomatic treatment of breast tenderness and pelvic pain. Vitamins B1, B6, and E may be used.

Other options:

Option A: Spasmodic dysmenorrhea is the cramping pain that accompanies menstruation and is most pronounced on the first and second day of menses.

Option B: Periductal mastitis is a chronic relapsing infection of the subareolar duct of the breast. It can manifest as subareolar pain and erythema. Repeated infections can lead to scarring that causes inversion or retraction of the nipple, subareolar masses, etc. 

Option C: Endometriosis is a condition characterized by ectopic benign endometrial tissue that occurs outside the uterine cavity. Patients present with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, menorrhagia, and infertility.

questions.text: Which of the following neurodegenerative disease has superoxide dismutase 1 inclusions?
questions.solution:
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) has superoxide dismutase type 1 (SOD1) inclusions.

It is a form of motor neuron disease that includes upper and lower motor neuron pathology. It is a progressive disease occurring due to the accumulation of mutated SOD1 proteins causing increased free radicals followed by cellular injury of neurons and apoptosis. The disease is characterized by asymmetrical weakness and spasticity of arms and legs. 

The diseases and their associated inclusion bodies are given below:

Disease Inclusion bodies
Huntington's disease Huntington (Polyglutamine)
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis SOD1
Spinal-bulbar muscular atrophy Androgen receptor (Polyglutamine containing)
Multiple system atrophy

α-synuclein
Progressive supranuclear palsy

Tau
Frontotemporal lobar degeneration

Tau, TDP-43

questions.text: A patient who has been on phenytoin for the past 7 years presents with amenorrhea for 3 months. A urine pregnancy test is performed, and it is found to be positive. Which of the following complications is the fetus at greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
The fetus of a pregnant woman who is on phenytoin is at the greatest risk of developing fetal hydantoin syndrome. 

Features of fetal hydantoin syndrome include:

  • Craniofacial anomalies (such as upturned nose, midfacial hypoplasia, and long upper lip with thin vermilion border)
  • Fingernail hypoplasia
  • Developmental delay
  • Orofacial clefts
  • Cardiac anomalies
  • Growth deficiency

This complication can be prevented by pre-conceptional counseling for patients with epilepsy. The patient should be started on 0.4 mg/day of folic acid before 1 month of conception (which is then increased to 4 mg/day after pregnancy). Antiepileptic medications should also be adjusted with the goal of monotherapy using the least teratogenic drug.

Other options: 

Option A: Phocomelia occurs due to exposure of the pregnant woman to thalidomide. It is the absence of one or more long bones, resulting in hands and/or feet being attached to the trunk of the fetus. 

Option B: Grey baby syndrome occurs due to the administration of chloramphenicol to preterm neonates. They are unable to excrete the drug, leading to an ashen-grey color, vascular collapse, and respiratory abnormalities. 

Option D: Ebstein anomaly occurs due to exposure of lithium to the fetus. It is the apical displacement of the tricuspid valve, causing severe tricuspid regurgitation and right atrial enlargement in the fetus.

Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition and Harrison's Medicine 21st edition mention the dose to be 4mg per day.
