questions.text: A male patient with Ewing's sarcoma is scheduled for preoperative chemotherapy. Which of the chemotherapeutic drugs used in the management of this condition causes the most neurological side effects?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, vincristine is the chemotherapeutic drug used in Ewing's sarcoma that causes the most neurological side effects.

Therefore, when there is any sign of motor dysfunction, stopping the drug or reducing the dosage might be beneficial. It also causes moderate leucopenia. Other side effects include severe constipation which can worsen colicky abdominal pain and intestinal obstruction.

Other chemotherapeutic agents that can be used for Ewing's sarcoma are

  • Doxorubicin
  • Cyclophosphamide or ifosfamide
  • Etoposide
  • Dactinomycin 

Other options:

Option B: Vinblastine primarily causes leucopenia. Neurological side effects are mild, other side effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and anorexia.

Option C: Vinorelbine primarily causes granulocytopenia and moderate leucopenia. It has the least neurological side effects. It can also cause allergic reactions.

Option D: Methotrexate is an antifolate drug (acts by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase) commonly used as a chemotherapeutic agent in the treatment of childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia, choriocarcinoma, and intrathecally for meningeal leukemia and lymphomas. It mainly causes myelosuppression. It can also lead to spontaneous hemorrhage and life-threatening infection.

questions.text: In states that have an annual parasite index of less than 1 case per 1000 populations at risk, health workers are advised to carry out active and/or passive case detection for early detection and treatment of all cases of malaria. This strategy to interrupt the transmission of disease is an example of?
questions.solution:
The strategy to interrupt the transmission of disease in specific regions is an example of disease elimination.

Elimination is the process of interrupting the transmission of a disease and regional elimination is an important precursor for eradication. In this scenario, health workers were advised to carry out active and/or passive case detection in states with an annual parasite index of less than 1 case per 1000 populations at risk. This is done for early detection and treatment of all cases of malaria as interrupting the transmission of malaria, leads to regional disease elimination. 

Other options:

Option A: Tertiary prevention is defined measures that are taken to prevent complications and allow rehabilitation in people who have already developed advanced stages of a disease.

Option B: Primordial prevention is measures taken to prevent the development of the risk factors for disease in a population group they haven't emerged.

Option C: Eradication of disease implies termination of all transmission of infection by the extermination of the infectious agent. It implies the cessation of infection and disease from the whole world.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman was brought by her son to an eye clinic with complaints of diminished vision in her left eye. An image of her eye is shown below. What is the most likely type of corneal opacity in this patient?
questions.solution:
The corneal opacity shown in the given image is most likely a leucomatous type of corneal opacity.

The above clinical vignette and image showing a dense white opacity, and scarring of more than half of the stroma is characteristic of leucomatous corneal opacity. 

Corneal opacities can be graded, depending on their density, as:

  • Nebular corneal opacities or nebula, where only slight opacification of the cornea occurs due to scarring. It is possible to observe the iris clearly through this type of opacity.
  • Macular corneal opacities or macula, which is described as a semi-dense opacity that can be seen with proper illumination. This occurs subsequent to scarring that spans about half the corneal stroma. The iris and pupillary margins are usually visible.
  • Leucomatous corneal opacities or leucoma simplex, which is a white scar that is easily seen just by looking at the eye. It occurs due to scarring of more than half of the corneal stroma.
  • Adherent leucoma is observed when there is perforation and subsequent healing of the cornea, but with the incarceration of the iris in it.

Secondary changes in corneal opacity which may be seen in long-standing cases include hyaline degeneration, calcareous degeneration, pigmentation and atheromatous ulceration.

The treatment depends upon the type of opacity. Keratoplasty is the treatment of choice in leucomatous corneal opacities. Optical iridectomy may be performed in cases with central adherent leucomas. Phototherapeutic keratectomy (PTK) performed with excimer laser is useful only in superficial (nebular) corneal opacities.

Corneal tattooing is a treatment option in patients with corneal opacities with firm scarring and poor vision. It only improves cosmetic appearance.

Related Pearl: Corneal Opacities

Corneal opacity is formed when Bowman's layer (+/- deeper layer) is damaged.

Nebular opacity

  • Faint white
  • Only Bowman's layer is involved
  • Causes more visual handicap than macular opacity due to the scattering of light

Macular opacity

  • White in color
  • Bowman's layer + Half of stromal thickness involved

Leucoma

  • White and opaque
  • BM + half or more than half stromal thickness involved

Image: Leucomatous corneal opacity

questions.text: A young man presents with recurrent, excruciating, and stabbing type of left-sided headaches. He has been experiencing at least 1 episode every other day. It typically lasts for  an hour and occurs around the same time everyday. Examination reveals nasal congestion and a watery left eye. Which of the following can be given to manage this acute episode?
questions.solution:
A patient with repetitive brief unilateral, excruciating stabbing headaches, occurring almost at the same time everyday, associated with lacrimation and rhinorrhea most probably has a diagnosis of cluster headache. The acute episodes in this condition can be treated with 100% O2 at 10 -12 L/min. 

High flow oxygen is crucial in the management of an acute attack. The duration of oxygen therapy should last 15 to 20 minutes. Other treatment options for an acute attack of cluster headache include injectable/nasal form of sumatriptan. Noninvasive vagus nerve stimulation (nVNS) is also approved by the FDA for the treatment of acute episodes of cluster headaches.

Cluster headache is a form of primary headache characterized by excruciating recurrent headache, that is unilateral in nature, and typically lasting between 15 to 180 minutes. The important feature of this headache is periodicity. At least one of the daily attacks of pain recurs at the same hour each day. 

It also causes severe, unilateral retroorbital pain with autonomic features, such as unilateral lacrimation, nasal congestion, and conjunctival injection. Occasionally features of Horner's syndrome may be seen.  Patients with cluster headaches are more often smokers with a higher than average alcohol consumption.

The drugs used in the prophylaxis of cluster headaches are verapamil (most common), topiramate, gabapentin, etc.

Other options:

Option A. Verapamil is the drug of choice for the prophylaxis of cluster headaches.

Option C. Lorazepam does not have a role in the management of cluster headaches.

Option D. Indomethacin is used in the management of paroxysmal hemicrania. This condition is characterized by unilateral severe headaches lasting between 2 to 45 minutes and can occur more than 5 times a day. Unlike cluster headache, paroxysmal hemicrania has a very good response to indomethacin. 

Related Pearl: Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalalgia

  • Paroxysmal hemicranias

  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial autonomic features (SUNA)
  • Hemicrania continua

questions.text: A 53-year-old  obese male patient, who was diagnosed with new onset diabetes mellitus, was prescribed metformin.  What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of metformin is suppression of hepatic gluconeogenesis.

Metformin also enhances the glucose uptake into skeletal muscles and facilitates the peripheral utilization of glucose by interfering with the mitochondrial respiratory chain. All these mechanisms occur due to the activation of AMPK (AMP-dependent protein kinase).

Metformin promotes weight loss, and reduces the micro- and macrovascular complications of diabetes.

However, it can cause gastrointestinal intolerance when used at higher doses. Other side effects like abdominal pain, metallic taste, and diarrhoea can occur.

Other options: 

Option A - Sodium-glucose co-transport 2 inhibitor, like dapglifzolin, acts by inhibiting glucose reabsorption in the proximal tubules. It causes glucosuria and can also promote weight loss.

Option B - Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitor, like sitagliptin, enhances the release of insulin postprandially, decreases glucagon and thereby lowers mealtime as well as fasting glucose. It doesn't have any effect on weight.

Option D - Sulfonylureas, like glimepiride, binds to the sulfonylurea receptor on beta cells of the pancreas and thereby enhance insulin release. Side effects include hypoglycemia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, constipation, and hypersensitivity.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of an elderly male patient with bilateral pitting pedal edema, a 3.7 cm rise of jugulovenous pulse is noted on gentle compression with the palm over the abdomen for about 30 seconds. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
This sign is called positive hepatojugular reflux.

It is elicited by applying firm pressure over the liver for 15 to 30 seconds while observing the neck veins for increasing jugular venous pressure (JVP). This reflux indicates that the right ventricle cannot accommodate the increase in venous pressure.  

This sign is positive in right heart failure and severe tricuspid regurgitation. Additionally, there are prominent V waves and Y descent in tricuspid regurgitation.

JVP is measured as the distance between the top of jugular venous pulsation and the sternal angle of Louis. The normal height of JVP is between 6 cm to 8 cm H2O. 

Other options:

Option A - A large pericardial effusion can compress the base of the left lung. This is noted as Ewart's sign - an area of dullness and increased fremitus beneath the angle of the left scapula. 

Option C & D - Friedrich's sign and Kussmaul's sign are both seen in constrictive pericarditis. Friedreich's sign is the prominent y descent of the jugular venous waveform, and Kussmaul's sign is the rise (or lack of fall) of JVP with inspiration. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI) is not true?

choices.text: No specific focus of infection is seen
It is more common when splenectomy is done for malignancy and hematological disorder than for trauma
Initial presentation involves fever and chills
Most cases occur within 1 year of splenectomy

questions.solution:
Most cases of overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI) occur within the first 2–3 years after splenectomy.

OPSI is the most common fatal complication of splenectomy mainly caused by organisms such as S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, and H. influenzae with S. pneumoniae.

Risk factors include young age, thalassemia major, sickle cell anemia, lymphoma, idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, and an immunosuppressed state.

OPSI is characterized by fever, rigors, chills, and other nonspecific symptoms like sore throat, malaise, myalgias, diarrhea, and vomiting which can progress to fulminant infection and multiorgan system failure with the development of hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagulation, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presentation.

Asplenic or hyposplenic patients are recommended to take the following vaccines prophylactically-

  • 13- valent pneumococcal conjugate (PCV 13) vaccine followed by the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) at least 8 weeks later
  • H. influenzae type b conjugate vaccine
  • Quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate ACWY vaccine series
  • Monovalent meningococcal serogroup B vaccine series 

In addition, they should receive seasonal influenza vaccination, measles, mumps, rubella, varicella, tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis.

The vaccines should be ideally given 10 to 12 weeks prior to elective splenectomy and at least 14 days prior to surgery or 14 days after splenectomy incase of emergency procedure.

Daily antibiotic prophylaxis is preferred for children up to 16 years of age or a minimum 3-5 years post-splenectomy. Oral antibiotic of choice is amoxicillin or oral penicillin (macrolide in case of hypersensitivity). 

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the encapsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: A middle-aged man comes to casualty with altered mental status and confusion. He appears lethargic and complains of nausea and thirst. He is known to have small cell lung cancer but is not under treatment. Which metabolic abnormality will cause these features in this patient?
questions.solution:
A patient who is a known case of small cell lung cancer presenting with clinical features such as lethargy, confusion, altered mental status, and thirst is suggestive of SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone). Hyponatremia is the metabolic abnormality causing these clinical features in the patient. 

SIADH can be associated with several different tumors such as that of the lung, ovaries, pancreas, bladder, etc. In this condition, ectopic vasopressin is produced by the small cell lung cancer which is a neuroendocrine tumor. Ectopic vasopressin increases the anti-diuretic property of the kidney decreasing renal clearance and leading to SIADH. This causes increased free water retention, leading to hyponatremia. Initially, in response to SIADH, there is a decrease in thirst which prevents further progression of the hyponatremia. However, later with increased ectopic vasopressin secretion the osmostat controlling thirst and hypothalamic secretion of vasopressin gets altered causing more thirst in the patient. This mechanism worsens hyponatremia.

SIADH is a syndrome characterized by euvolemic hyponatremia due to a primary defect in osmoregulation. The causes of SIADH include neoplasms of the lung, duodenum, pancreas, ovary, head trauma, infections (tuberculosis, meningitis, pneumonia), and drug overdose (vasopressin, desmopressin).

Treatment involves administration of conivaptan or tolvaptan (vasopressin receptor V2 antagonist), demeclocycline, and fluid restriction to less than 500 ml (although this can be difficult). In severe cases, correction of hyponatremia is done by administering IV fluids with hypertonic normal saline along with diuretics such as furosemide (to increase free water clearance).

Related Pearl: Causes of SIADH

Neoplasms

Carcinomas

  • Lung
  • Duodenum
  • Pancreas
  • Ovary
  • Bladder, ureter

Other neoplasms

  • Thymoma
  • Mesothelioma
  • Bronchial adenoma
  • Carcinoid
  • Gangliocytoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma

Head trauma (closed and penetrating)

Infections

  • Pneumonia
  • Abscess
  • Cavitation (aspergillosis)
  • Tuberculosis
  • Meningitis, Encephalitis
  • AIDS

Vascular

  • Cerebrovascular occlusions, haemorrhage
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Neurologic

  • Guillain-Barre syndrome
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Delirium tremens
  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Psychosis
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Congenital malformations

Metabolic

  • Acute intermittent porphyria

Respiratory

  • Asthma
  • Pneumothorax
  • Positive-pressure respiration

Drugs

  • Vasopressin or desmopressin
  • Serotonin reuptake inhibitors
  • Oxytocin (high dose)
  • Vincristine
  • Carbamazepine
  • Nicotine
  • Phenothiazines
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Monoamine oxidase inhibitors

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic Syndromes and Underlying Cancers

Clinical Syndromes/ 

Endocrinopathies

Major Forms of Underlying Cancer

Causal Mechanism

Cushing Syndrome

Small-cell carcinoma of lung

Pancreatic carcinoma

Neural tumours

Renal carcinoma

ACTH or ACTH- like substance

Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)

Small-cell carcinoma of lung

Intracranial neoplasms

Antidiuretic hormone or atrial natriuretic hormones

Hypercalcemia

Squamous cell carcinoma of lung

Breast carcinoma

Renal carcinoma

Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma

Parathyroid hormone-related protein(PTHRP), TGF-a, TNF, IL-1

Hypoglycaemia

Ovarian carcinoma

Fibrosarcoma

Other mesenchymal sarcomas

Insulin or insulin-like substance

Polycythemia

Renal carcinoma

Cerebellar haemangioma

Hepatocellular carcinoma

Erythropoietin

Osteomalacia

Phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor

FGF-23

Acute promyelocytic leukemia

Prostatic carcinoma

Tumor products activate clotting

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male complains of shortness of breath on exertion, associated with dry cough for the past 2 months. Examination reveals grade 3 clubbing and basal rales on auscultation. HRCT of the chest shows bilateral subpleural reticular changes, traction bronchiectasis, and honeycombing of the lung parenchyma. Which of the following flow-volume loops is expected to be seen in this patient?

High-Resolution Computed Tomogram - HRCT
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of an interstitial lung disease probably idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). The flow-volume loop, in this case, would be similar to that of image 4 which corresponds to a restrictive pattern of the flow-volume loop.

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is usually seen in the fifth or sixth decade of life. Males are affected more than females. Clinical features include progressive dyspnoea more common with exertion, dry cough, and end-inspiratory crackles or rales on auscultation. Digital clubbing is seen. The HRCT findings include bilateral subpleural reticular changes, traction bronchiectasis, and honeycombing of the lung parenchyma.

The following image shows flow-volume loops in different pathological conditions-

Related Pearl: Flow-volume graph/Loop

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of blunt trauma to the pelvis was diagnosed with urethral rupture. Imaging revealed an injury to the bulbar urethra below the perineal membrane. The extravasated urine is likely to get accumulated in ________.
questions.solution:
Injury to the bulbar urethra below the perineal membrane leads to the accumulation of urine in the superficial perineal pouch.

The rupture of the urethra below the urogenital diaphragm will result in extravasation of urine into the superficial perineal pouch, penis, and scrotum in males and labia majora in females, and the anterior abdominal wall.

The superficial fascia of the abdomen is divided below the umbilicus into a superficial fatty layer (fascia of Camper) and a deep membranous layer (fascia of Scarpa). Scarpa's fascia is continuous with the membranous layer of the superficial perineal fascia (Colles' fascia). 

Colles' fascia is attached to fascia lata (the deep fascia of the thigh) along the Holden's line that extends from the pubic tubercle laterally for 8 cm. Extravasated fluid cannot pass into the medial thigh below Holden's line due to the firm attachment of Colles' fascia to the fascia lata. 

 

Contents of superficial perineal pouch: 

  • Corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum
  • Three muscles – the ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus and superficial transverse perineal
  • The greater vestibular glands (Bartholin’s glands) in females and duct of bulbourethral glands in males.
  • Arteries: Branches of perineal artery (Posterior scrotal and Transverse perineal arteries) and Branches of artery of penis (Artery to bulb, urethral artery, deep artery of penis and dorsal artery of penis)
  • Nerves: Long perineal nerve, Branches of perineal nerve (Posterior scrotal, Nerve to bulb and Muscular branches)
  • Clitoris in female
  • Urethra in male

 

Other options - 

Option A: Deep perineal pouch encloses the space between the endopelvic fascia and the perineal membrane and includes the following contents:

  • Membranous urethra
  • Muscles: Sphincter urethrae and deep transverse perinei muscles
  • Nerves: Dorsal nerve of penis and muscular branches of the perineal nerve
  • Vessels: Artery of penis
  • Glands: Bulbourethral glands in males

Thus, any injury to urethra in this pouch can lead to the accumulation of urine in the deep perineal pouch. It can even spread upwards into the extraperitoneal space around the bladder and prostate and into the anterior abdominal wall. 

Option C: Space of Retzius, also known as the retropubic space is an extraperitoneal space located posterior to the pubic symphysis and anterior to the urinary bladder. 

Option D: Pouch of Douglas, also known as the rectouterine pouch in females, or rectovesical pouch in males, is the most dependent part of the peritoneal cavity in the erect position. Any infection or fluid collection tends to get accumulated in this dependent region.

questions.text:
A patient underwent a TAPP repair for an incarcerated left inguinal hernia. During the procedure, while fixing the mesh, tacks were accidentally placed below the iliopubic tract. On follow-up visits, the patient complained of persistent pain in his lateral thigh. Injury to which of the following nerves has most likely caused the pain?

TAPP repair- Transabdominal preperitoneal repair
questions.solution:
Injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most likely cause of pain in the above scenario.

Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh lies in the anatomical landmark known as the triangle of pain (as described in the pearl) and can be injured in laparoscopic hernia repair. Any damage to the contents of this structure can lead to chronic pain following hernia repair. 


In laparoscopic TAPP repair, to reduce chances of nerve injury during mesh placement, tacks are ideally placed above the iliopubic tract (away from the triangle of pain which carries the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve, and the femoral nerve).

Other options:

Option A: Ilioinguinal nerve may be commonly injured during open hernia repair. It provides innervation to the groin and medial aspect of the thigh, the upper part of the scrotum, and the penile root.

Option B: Iliohypogastric nerve can be injured while making an incision in the right iliac fossa during hernia surgery. It mainly supplies the suprapubic skin.

Option C: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve (which supplies the skin over the upper anterior part of the thigh) lies in close relation to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. Injury to these also can cause loss of sensation over the thigh but these are less frequent.

 

 

Related Pearl: The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

It is bounded

  • Superio-medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Inferio-laterally by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

Related Pearl: The Triangle of Doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: A male patient with a history of panic disorder is brought to the emergency room. He complains of nausea, sweating, and palpitations. On examination, he appears anxious, and irritable. His pulse rate is 120/minute and respiratory rate is 30/minute. Upon inflating the BP cuff, the hand assumes the position shown below. Which of the following is the likely explanation for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Increased binding of calcium with inorganic salts
Decreased binding of albumin with calcium
Increased binding of albumin with calcium

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of panic attack and the image showing Trosseau's sign are suggestive of hypocalcemia in this patient. It occurs due to increased binding of calcium with albumin.

Panic attack leads to hyperventilation, which in turn, results in washout of carbon dioxide and acute respiratory alkalosis. An increase in extracellular pH increases the binding of calcium to albumin, lowering the ionized calcium concentration. Thus, respiratory alkalosis especially can precipitate tetany and laryngospasm in calcium-deficient patients.

Hypocalcemia can be associated with low albumin levels, hyperphosphatemia, tumor lysis syndrome and impaired parathyroid hormone secretion. 

The clinical features of hypocalcemia are:

  • Tetany: Increased peripheral neuromuscular irritability. May include perioral parasthesias, muscle spasms and cramps.
  • Trosseau's sign: Induction of carpal spasm when the BP cuff is inflated 20 mm Hg over the systolic BP for three minutes or more.
  • Chvostek's sign: Contraction of the ipsilateral circumoral facial muscles when the facial nerve is tapped just anterior to the ear.
  • Seizures
  • Papilledema
  • Psychiatric manifestations like emotional instability

 

Treatment for acute hypocalcemia:

Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia may be treated with calcium gluconate 10 mL 10% wt/vol (90 mg or 2.2 mmol) intravenously, diluted in 50 mL of 5% dextrose or 0.9% sodium chloride, given intravenously over 5 min.

A schematic representation of calcium binding to albumin is shown below

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was asked to take multiple rapid breaths while undergoing an EEG. The recording showed symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-wave discharges that began and ended suddenly, superimposed on a normal EEG background. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a child with a 3Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG, which was provoked by hyperventilation, suggests a diagnosis of absence seizures.

Absence seizures are the most common seizures in children. The electrophysiologic hallmark of typical absence seizures is a generalized, symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharge pattern. This EEG finding can be provoked by hyperventilation.

These seizures are characterized by a sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and without post-ictal confusion. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds. The patient presents with subtle, bilateral motor signs such as rapid blinking of the eyelids, chewing movements, or small-amplitude, clonic movements of the hands. These can occur hundreds of times in a day. The child is often misunderstood to be 'daydreaming' and parents are often told that there is a decline in the child's performance at school.

The first line treatment drugs for absent seizures include valproic acid, ethosuximide and lamotrigine. 

Other options:

Option A: Generalised tonic-clonic seizure is characterized by tonic contractions of muscles followed by periods of muscle relaxation (clonic phase). It is associated with unresponsiveness, muscular flaccidity, excessive salivation, and incontinence. The EEG is characterized by an increase in generalized low-voltage fast waves after which generalized high-amplitude, polyspike discharges in the tonic phase. In the clonic phase, a spike and slow-wave pattern are observed. 

Option B: Atonic seizures are characterized by sudden loss of postural muscle tone. Consciousness may not be impaired and postictal confusion is not usually present. The EEG shows generalized spike-wave discharge followed by diffuse slow waves which correspond to the muscle tone. 

Option D: Myoclonic seizures are characterized by sudden and brief contraction of part of or the entire body. The EEG shows synchronous spike-and-slow-wave discharges just before the onset of myoclonic movements.

questions.text: An infant presents with multiple episodes of non-bilious projectile vomiting 4 weeks after birth. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 4-week-old infant presenting with multiple episodes of non-bilious projectile vomiting and hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis is suggestive of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).

IHPS refers to the hypertrophy of the circular muscles of the pylorus of the stomach, resulting in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. It is common between 3 and 6 weeks of age. First-born male infants are at the highest risk. 

Infants usually present with an olive-shaped mass that is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is fed, visible peristalsis is observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile non-bilious vomiting leading to loss of potassium and chloride ions. It is associated with hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.

Ultrasound examination is the investigation of choice for this condition:

  • The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm.
  • The nipple sign is produced by the double-layered hypertrophic mucosa that protrudes into the stomach. 
  • The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is therefore called the cervix sign.

Management includes the correction of metabolic abnormality before the correction of the gastric outlet obstruction. The hypertrophic pylorus is surgically corrected by Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy.

The image below shows the cervix and nipple signs seen in IHPS:


Other options:

Option A: Hirschsprung's disease presents with delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, and a tight anal sphincter. The age of presentation and non-bilious vomiting make IHPS the more likely diagnosis in this case.

Option C: Duodenal atresia in neonates presents with bilious vomiting without abdominal distension, usually on the first day of life.

Option D: Biliary atresia is characterized by conjugated/direct hyperbilirubinemia and hepatomegaly. It is because of the obliteration of the extrahepatic biliary system. It is unlikely to present with vomiting.

questions.text: While studying the x-ray of a child brought to the casualty, the doctor notices a "string of beads" appearance in the paravertebral region. Which of the following conditions is this finding most likely associated with?
questions.solution:
String of beads appearance in the paravertebral region on an x-ray is associated with infantile whiplash syndrome. 

In battered baby syndrome/ Caffey syndrome / infantile whiplash syndrome, violent squeezing of the chest from side to side causes fracture of costochondral junctions and also along with the posterior angles of the rib. After callus formation which takes around 2 weeks, it gives a “string of beads” appearance in the paravertebral region on X-ray.

A battered child is one who is a victim of repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, inflicted by the parent or a guardian. The physical injury may also be associated with deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection.

It is usually seen in children less than 3 years of age with a history of emotional or financial problems in the family.

Laceration of the upper lip and tear of the fraenulum are frequently seen lesions, resulting from efforts to silence a crying child.

Bruises may be seen on either side of the chest, behind the axillae, and down the anterior chest wall, due to the child being gripped in a rough manner, between the perpetrator's hands and shaken. This shaking of a child leads to infantile whiplash syndrome, often resulting in subdural hematoma and intraocular bleeding in battered babies. Permanent brain damage can occur due to habitual, prolonged shaking. 

The most common cause of death is a head injury, followed by the rupture of any abdominal organ.

Other options:
Option A: Sandifer syndrome involves gastroesophageal reflux in infants resulting in episodes of generalized stiffening and opisthotonic posturing. This may be accompanied by apnea, staring, and minimal jerking of the extremities. These episodes often occur 30 min after a feed and in older children, it manifests with episodic dystonic or dyskinetic movements consisting of laterocollis, retrocollis, or torticollis.

Option C: Munchausen's syndrome involves feigning illness or injury and going from hospital to hospital for unnecessary investigations and treatment. It is seen in the adults themselves.

Option D: Sudden infant death syndrome is defined as the sudden and unexpected death of a seemingly healthy infant, and whose death remains unexplained even after a thorough case investigation, death scene examination, review of clinical history and a complete autopsy.

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient with an abdominal mass was diagnosed with gestational trophoblastic neoplasia. On further evaluation, it is found that neoplasia has metastasized to the liver and lungs. What would be the clinical staging according to FIGO classification?
questions.solution:
The patient would be classified to have stage-IV gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN).

International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) Staging for GTN is as follows:

  • Stage I - Confined to the uterus
  • Stage II - GTN extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structures
  • Stage III - GTN extends to the lungs, with or without known genital tract involvement
  • Stage IV - All other metastatic sites.

This patient with metastasis to the liver and lungs has Stage IV disease.

GTN includes tumors that cause aggressive invasion of the endometrium and myometrium by trophoblastic cells. This includes invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumor, and epithelioid trophoblastic tumor. GTN is diagnosed based on elevated β-hCG levels. Criteria for diagnosis of GTN:

  • Persistence of β-hCG level plateau in 4 measurements for 3 weeks or longer
  • Rise in β-hCG levels in 3 or more consecutive measurements done weekly, over a period of 2 weeks or longer
  • Elevated β-hCG level for 6 months or more
  • Histologic diagnosis of choriocarcinoma.

A modified prognostic scoring system by the WHO distinguishes patients at low risk for therapeutic failure from those at high risk. Treatment for the low-risk disease is chemotherapy with methotrexate, while those with high-risk disease are treated with etoposide, methotrexate, and dactinomycin alternating with cyclophosphamide and vincristine (EMA/CO) chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and FIGO staging of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

Risk factors

  • Older age
  • β-hCG levels > 100,000 mIU/mL
  • Uterine size that is large-forgestational age
  • Theca-lutein cysts > 6 cm
  • Slow decline in β-hCG levels
  • Postevacuation uterine sonographic surveillance showing myometrial nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia.

FIGO staging:

Stage I Disease confined to the uterus
Stage II GTD extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structure
Stage III Lung metastasis with or without genital tract involvement
Stage IV Other metastasis

questions.text: A young man is brought to the casualty following a blunt injury to the chest. His BP is found to be 80/60 mm of Hg and jugular venous pressure is found to be raised on examination. Auscultation reveals low heart sounds and air entry on both sides is normal. Which of the following changes is likely to be seen in his jugular venous pressure tracing?

choices.text: Prominent x descent and absent y descent
Prominent y descent and absent x descent
Accentuated v wave and rapid y descent
Absent v wave with rapid x descent

questions.solution:
The above features are suggestive of cardiac tamponade and the jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing of the patient will have a prominent x descent but an absent y descent.

Cardiac tamponade is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space. It will result in the obstruction of the blood flow into the ventricles. Patients present with a triad of hypotension, soft or absent heart sounds and raised JVP (Beck's triad). In JVP, there is a prominent x descent but an absent y descent. 

Another feature found in this is a paradoxical pulse. Normally the blood pressure falls during inspiration. But this fall is not more than 10mm of Hg. However, in the pulses paradoxus, the fall in blood pressure during inspiration is more than 10 mm Hg. This is called a paradoxical pulse. The mechanism for this is as follows: due to cardiac tamponade, the ventricles are now covered in a tight incompressible covering. During inspiration, there is an increase in the volume of the right ventricle. Since this ventricle cannot expand, it pushes the interventricular septum to the left causing decreased volume in the left ventricle. This in turn results in reduced stroke volume and arterial systolic pressure.

It is diagnosed using echocardiography. As soon as the condition is diagnosed, pericardiocentesis should be carried out.

 

Other important conditions and their JVP tracings are

  • Constrictive pericarditis will have prominent y descent, prominent x descent. Kussmal sign is associated with constrictive pericarditis and is characterized by increased fall in JVP during inspiration.

 

  • Atrioventricular dissociation will have cannon a waves

 

  • Atrial fibrillation will have absent a wave

 

  • Tricuspid regurgitation will have accentuated v wave with rapid y descent

 

  • Tricuspid stenosis will have prolonged y wave

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A young man was rushed to the casualty with multiple rib injuries. On examination, paradoxical movement of the chest was noted. He soon progresses into respiratory failure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of multiple rib fractures with paradoxical movements of the chest on respiration is suggestive of a flail chest.

A flail chest occurs when a segment of the chest wall does not have bony continuity with the rest of the thoracic cage. This condition results from blunt trauma associated with fracture of 2 adjacent ribs or 3 or more ribs fractured in two or more places. The blunt trauma can also lead to pulmonary contusion.

It is a clinical diagnosis characterized by paradoxical respiration (On inspiration, loose segment displaces inwards while during expiration it moves outwards).

The patient is also at high risk of developing a pneumothorax or hemothorax.

Treatment:

  • Oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates) or epidural analgesia, and physiotherapy.
  • IPPV (intermittent positive pressure ventilation) is reserved for patients developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen.

Treatment algorithm for treatment of flail chest with respiratory failure:

 

Other options:

Option A: Sternal injuries are uncommon. It can occur following a blunt trauma injury to the anterior chest.

Option B: Clavicle fractures are often associated with brachial plexus and injury to the great vessels. Management is mainly supportive.

Option D: Tension penumothorax can also occur following a blunt trauma of the chest wall, iatrogenic injury or mechanical positive pressure ventilation characterized by tachypnoea, dyspnoea and distended neck veins. Tracheal deviation may be seen in late stages. Treatment is insertion of cannula in the second intercostal space in the midclavicular line followed by insertion of chest drain in the fifth intercostal space in the midaxillary line.

questions.text: A female patient presents with disturbed sleep and difficulty concentrating at work for several months. She awakens early and feels fatigued all day. She is too anxious to fall asleep because she believes her neighborhood is unsafe. She is a single parent and worries about her son's school performance and their finances. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).

Generalized anxiety disorder is defined as excessive anxiety and worry about several events or activities for most days during at least a 6-month period.

It is more commonly seen in females, with onset usually in teenage or early adult life. It is often seen coexisting with another anxiety disorder (such as social phobia, specific phobia, panic disorder), major depressive disorder, or substance abuse disorder. 

Areas of the brain implicated in the pathogenesis of generalized anxiety disorder include the occipital lobe, basal ganglia, the limbic system, and the frontal cortex.

Diagnosis of generalized anxiety disorder is made using the DSM-V criteria-

  1. Excessive anxiety and worry about a number of events, occurring more days than not for at least 6 months, about a number of events or activities.
  2. Difficulty in controlling the worry.
  3. The anxiety and worry are associated with three or more of the following six symptoms (with at least some symptoms having been present for more days than not for the past 6 months):
    1. Restlessness or feeling keyed up or on edge
    2. Being easily fatigued
    3. Difficulty concentrating or mind going blank
    4. Irritability
    5. Muscle tension
    6. Sleep disturbance (difficulty falling or staying asleep, or restless, unsatisfying sleep).
  4. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other areas of functioning.
  5. The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition
  6. The disturbance is not better explained by another medical disorder.  

Treatment of generalized anxiety disorder includes psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy including benzodiazepines, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, buspirone, and venlafaxine.  

Other options:

Option B: Dependent personality disorder (DPD) is an anxious personality disorder characterized by an inability to be alone. People with DPD develop symptoms of anxiety when they’re not around others. They rely on other people for comfort, reassurance, advice, and support.

Option C: Social anxiety disorder/social phobia specifically involves the fear of social situations, unlike general anxiety disorder which involves anxiety about a lot of different things.

Option D: Panic disorder includes episodes of acute intense attacks of anxiety accompanied by feelings of impending doom. Generalized anxiety disorder is often confused with panic disorder and can be differentiated by the absence of spontaneous panic attacks.

questions.text: A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. He says that he first noticed it around 4 months back and is worried about the new lesions that are appearing at sites of injury. The lesions appear white on Woods lamp examination. This condition occurs due to
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of localized depigmented macules showing Koebner phenomenon, which are indicative of vitiligo, a condition that occurs due to a lack of melanocytes in the basal layer of the epidermis.

Vitiligo presents with localized depigmentation that occurs due to a progressive loss in the melanocytes. It is classified into segmental vitiligo, which appears as unilateral maculae in a segmented or band-shaped pattern, or non-segmental vitiligo, which appears as bilateral maculae distributed in an acrofacial pattern or scattered symmetrically over the entire body. The lesions become apparent between 20-30 years of age. 

Hypopigmented macules in vitiligo are commonly found in the hips, dorsum of the hands/fingers, feet, elbows, knees, and ankle areas. These are the areas of repeated friction. Rarely there may be complete vitiligo or vitiligo universalis, or trichrome vitiligo where there are areas of depigmentation, and hyperpigmentation, along with the normal skin. Koebner phenomenon is the development of lesions at the site of trauma on the uninvolved skin.

Several autoimmune conditions can be associated with vitiligo. They are thyroid disease (hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism), pernicious anemia, Addison's disease, diabetes, and hypoparathyroidism.

Under the Wood's lamp examination, the depigmented areas emit a bright blue-white fluorescence and appear sharply demarcated.

Treatment involves cosmetic camouflage and sunscreen. Topical corticosteroids are the first line of treatment. Topical calcineurin inhibitors like pimecrolimus and tacrolimus are also used. Psoralen photochemotherapy, khellin, and selective ultraviolet B therapy are second-line treatments. Surgical grafting can be used in refractory cases, where melanocytes from a normal pigmented area are transferred to non-pigmented areas. In patients with extensive vitiligo where only a few pigmented areas are left, depigmentation can be done.

Other diseases with decreased pigmentation are:

Piebaldism: commonly presents with a white V-shaped forelock. It is caused due to the impaired migration of melanocytes to the skin.

Albinism is a genetic disorder characterized by generalized depigmentation of the skin, hair, and eye, caused by a deficiency in melanin biosynthesis.

Idiopathic guttate hypomelanosis (IGH) is an acquired leukoderma caused due to decreased melanocytes and melanin.

Postinflammatory hypomelanosis and pityriasis alba occur due to an impaired transfer of melanin to the keratinocytes.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A 27-year-old pig farmer presented with fever, headaches, myalgia, and a sore throat. He later develops dizziness, altered consciousness, and seizures. The causative organism is believed to be a paramyxovirus. Identify the false statement regarding the condition.

choices.text: Fruit bats are the natural host

questions.solution:
This patient with fever, headaches, myalgia, a sore throat, dizziness, altered consciousness, and seizures with a history of exposure to pigs is likely to have been infected with the Nipah virus. The false statement regarding the Nipah virus is that human-to-human transmission does not occur.

Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus, which is transmitted by animals to humans. 

It is an emerging paramyxovirus that belongs to the genus Henipavirus. It has caused disease in humans who have had contact with infected animals. 

It has a wide range of hosts and is associated with high mortality rates. Its natural host is a certain species of fruit bat while pigs may be an intermediate host for transmission to humans.

Its transmission can occur by the following methods:

  • Unprotected exposure to the secretions from the pigs, or unprotected contact with the tissue of a sick animal.
  • Consumption of fruits or fruit products (such as raw date palm juice) contaminated with urine or saliva from infected fruit bats of the family Pteropodidae.
  • Human-to-human transmission through close contact with people's secretions and excretions.

The incubation period ranges from 4 to 14 days.

Patients present with symptoms of headaches, myalgia, vomiting, and sore throat. This is followed by the onset of encephalitis, which manifests as dizziness, drowsiness, and altered consciousness. Patients may also present with acute respiratory distress. Encephalitis and seizures occur in severe cases, progressing to coma within 24 to 48 hours. 

Diagnosis is by means of real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) from bodily fluids and antibody detection via enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) methods. The virus can be isolated by cell culture.

questions.text: Endotracheal intubation has been planned in a 6-year-old child. The type of laryngoscope blade that would be preferred for this procedure would be:
questions.solution:
Miller's laryngoscope blade would be preferred while performing an endotracheal intubation in a 6-year-old child.

A laryngoscope is an instrument used for examination of the larynx and facilitation of tracheal intubation. It has three components: the handle, the blade, and the light source.

Miller's blade is a straight blade. As the larynx is located higher in the neck in children compared to adults, a straight blade is preferred over a curved blade. Its curve begins 2 inches from the tip. It is inserted using the para-glossal technique that helps avoid contact with the maxillary incisors and also provides maximal tongue control.

It is used in:

  • Neonates, infants, and young children
  • Adults with short thyromental distance and long floppy epiglottis.

Other options:

Option B: The McCoy blade is a modification of a Macintosh blade. Its design allows the tip to be flexed, by using the lever alongside the handle. This helps to lift the epiglottis without the degree of force that would be required using a standard blade. It helps make some difficult intubations easier.

Option C: The Macintosh blade is a sharply curved blade with a large flange. It is inserted in the right side of the mouth, and the flange is used to sweep the tongue to the left. The blade is advanced and positioned in the vallecula. Advantages of a curved blade include:

  • Greater room available for the passage of an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth

Option D: The D-blade is a highly curved blade used in video-laryngoscopy.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions do not result in fat necrosis?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, brain infarct does not result in fat necrosis. Brain infarct undergoes liquefactive necrosis. 

Fat necrosis refers to the destruction of fat tissue due to various reasons like injury, surgery, etc. Examples of fat necrosis include pancreatitis, breast trauma, and panniculitis.

In pancreatitis, there is a release of activated pancreatic lipases into the substance of the pancreas and the peritoneal cavity. These enzymes act on surrounding tissue to release fatty acids, which then combine with calcium to produce grossly visible chalky-white areas (fat saponification). Histologic examination reveals foci of necrotic fat cells, with basophilic calcium deposits, surrounded by an inflammatory reaction.

Panniculitis is the inflammation of subcutaneous tissue characterized by painful nodules. The most common sites include the buttocks, legs, and trunk. 

Breast fat necrosis involves the injury to adipose tissue leading to tissue death. This can occur in a number of conditions like breast trauma and recent breast surgery. A palpable nodule is often noted as a result of necrosis. 

The various types of necrosis include:

Type Example
Coagulative necrosis Infarcts in all organs except the brain
Caseous necrosis Tuberculosis
Liquefactive necrosis

Brain infarct
Fat necrosis Pancreatitis, Breast trauma
Fibrinoid necrosis

Vasculitis

Malignant hypertension

questions.text:
A primary health care center evaluated school-going children to assess their nutritional status. The data collected is given below. What is the median weight in this case?

10kg, 15kg, 12kg, 19kg, 21kg, 17kg, 25kg
questions.solution:
The median weight, in this case, is 17kg.

The median is a measure of a central tendency of data and is obtained by arranging the data in an ascending or descending order of magnitude and then recording the value of the middle observation. For example, the data above needs to be rearranged in ascending order as:

10 kg, 12 kg, 15 kg, 17 kg, 19 kg, 21 kg, 25 kg

The middle value is 17 kg and hence the median in this case.

If there is an even number of values, then the median is estimated by taking the average of the two middle values. 

Central tendency provides a numerical summary that gives an idea about the central, average, or typical score in a distribution of scores for a variable. Other measures of central tendency are:

  • Mean - obtained by dividing the sum of individual observations by the number of observations.
  • Mode - defined as the most frequently occurring value in a distribution of data.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man came with complaints of long-standing arthralgia in the knee. On examination, bluish-black scleral patches were seen as shown. On further inquiry, he says that the urine turns black on exposure to air. Accumulation of which of the following compounds caused this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of alkaptonuria and the pathological discoloration shown in the image is ochronosis. Accumulation of the compound benzoquinone acetate has caused this condition.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase, the enzyme which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. The defect in this enzyme will lead to the accumulation of homogentisic acid that  oxidizes into benzoquinone acetate. Later, benzoquinone acetate polymerizes and binds to tissues (especially collagen fibres).

This oxidation process produces free radicals that cause tissue damage and incite inflammation. Additionally, the excess homogentisic acid is excreted in the urine. This results in the classical clinical features of alkaptonuria such as- 

  • Homogentisic aciduria- Black discoloration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate. 
  • Ochronosis- Bluish-black discoloration of tissues mostly involving ear cartilage, ocular tissue, the skin of the eyelids, forehead, cheeks, and hands, nail beds, and even deeper structures such as the larynx and tendons.
  • Arthropathy- Debilitating arthralgia or arthritis that may be seen after the fourth or fifth decade.

Other options-

Option B- Methyl malonyl-CoA is seen in urine (methylmalonic aciduria) due to deficiency of methylmalonyl Co A mutase which is a vitamin b12 dependent enzyme.

Option C- Increased orotic acid in the blood and urine is seen in ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency.

Option D- Sulfogalactosylceramide is accumulated in metachromatic leukodystrophy due to deficiency of Aryl-sulfatase A.

questions.text: In a family planning clinic, you see a flyer advertising the pills shown below as a method of contraception. Identify the true statement about it.

choices.text: Can be taken by diabetic women

questions.solution:
The true statement about desogestrel pills (synthetic progesterone-only pills) is that they can be taken by diabetic women. This is because they have minimal effects on carbohydrate metabolism.

Progesterone-only pills are also known as minipills. They are started 21 days postpartum and soon after an abortion. The woman needs to take precautions in the first 48 hours of the first cycle.

The mechanism of action of progesterone-only pills involves thickening of the cervical mucus that inhibits penetration of sperms (mainly), atrophy of the endometrium, and inhibition of ovulation.

Advantages of progesterone-only pills include:

  • Minimal or no effects on carbohydrate and lipid metabolism
  • Do not cause or exacerbate hypertension 
  • Do not impair milk production, therefore suitable during lactation
  • Safe for women with a history of migraine headaches
  • Safe for smokers who are older than 35 years

Contraindications include abnormal uterine bleeding, breast cancer, hepatic cancer, pregnancy, and active severe liver disease. Additionally, synthetic progestogens like desogestrel are associated with a higher incidence of thromboembolism.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching. Per speculum examination of the vagina is done as shown below. A wet smear with 10% KOH solution shows budding yeast cells. The clinician prescribes an oral medication. What is the likely mechanism of action of the given medication?

choices.text: Forms pores in the fungal cell wall

questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms of curdy white vaginal discharge and the KOH smear showing budding yeast cells are suggestive of vulvovaginal candidiasis. The oral medication given in this condition is fluconazole which acts by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis.

Azole group of antifungal are grouped into two types :

  • Imidazole- clotrimazole, ketoconazole, luliconazole
  • Triazole- Itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole, and isavuconazole

The azole group inhibits the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14-α-sterol demethylase and results in an impaired conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of membrane ergosterol.

Therapeutic uses of fluconazole-

  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis can be treated with fluconazole by taking 100–200 mg a day for 7–14 days. Uncomplicated vaginal candidiasis can be effectively treated with a single 150 mg dose. Treatment of candidemia in nonimmunosuppressed patients involves a loading dosage of 800 mg, followed by 400 mg daily.
  • For the first eight weeks of the consolidation phase of the therapy of cryptococcal meningitis in individuals with AIDS, fluconazole is administered.
  • Due to its excellent CSF penetration and significantly lower morbidity than intrathecal amphotericin B, fluconazole is the medication of choice for treating coccidioidal meningitis. Fluconazole is similar to itraconazole in treating various types of coccidioidomycosis.

Other options

Option A- Amphotericin B acts by forming pores in the fungal cell membrane. It has also been found that it forms aggregates that sequester ergosterol from lipid bilayers, leading to fungal cell death. It is indicated in invasive mucormycosis, fungal endophthalmitis following pars plana vitrectomy, and induction therapy in cryptococcal meningitis. 

Option B- Griseofulvin acts by inhibiting microtubule assembly, disrupting the fungal cell division. It is the drug of choice for tinea capitis in children. It is also effective in treating ringworm of glabrous skin, tinea cruris, tinea corprosis, tinea pedis, and tinea of the hands and beard. 

Option C- Terbinafine acts by inhibiting epoxidation of fungal squalene that reduces ergosterol biosynthesis. It is helpful for treating nail onychomycosis in adults and tinea capitis.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who has regular menstrual cycles presents with amenorrhea. A urine pregnancy test is done and found to be positive. She recalls that the first day of her last menstrual period was October 9. What would her expected date of delivery be based on Naegele's rule?
questions.solution:
Based on Naegele’s rule, the expected date of delivery (EDD) of this woman is July 16.

Naegele’s rule is based on a 28-day regular cycle and states that the EDD is obtained by adding 7 days and subtracting 3 months from the 1st day of the last menstrual period (LMP). In this case, the first day of LMP was October 9, the due date is 10-3(months) i.e. 7th month of the following year- July, and add 7 days to the date i.e. 9+7=16. Hence, the EDD will be on July 16.

questions.text: In a study of a group of 40 people, a physiologist is studying the pacemaker actions of the sinoatrial node and the action potentials of each one of them were plotted in the graph given below. The ion channels predominantly responsible for the phase 0 marked in the graph is?
questions.solution:
The ion channels predominantly responsible for phase 0 marked in the graph is the L-type calcium channels. 

The graph in the given image represents the action potential of the SA (sinoatrial) node (i.e., the pacemaker potential). In the figure, phase 0 corresponds to the impulse/upstroke and, this is predominantly due to the opening of 'L' (long-acting) type of calcium channels resulting in an intracellular movement of the calcium ions down its electrochemical gradient.

The resting membrane potential (RMP) of the SA node is -55 to-60 millivolts. Phases of this potential are: 

  • Phase 0 - Upstroke wave. It is due to the influx of Ca2+ ions by the opening of voltage-gated L-type channels.
  • Phase 3 - Downstroke wave. It is due to the efflux of K+ leading to repolarization.
  • Phase 4- Prepotential. Because of ongoing K+ efflux, hyperpolarization sets in. This makes the channel more permeable to Na+ ions and since these Na+ channels are activated during hyperpolarization they are referred to as funny currents (Ih/ If). They form the first half of the pre-potential. The second half of the prepotential is completed by the opening of the voltage-gated T-(transient) type Ca2+ channel. The slope of Phase 4 in the SA node determines the heart rate. 

Clinical aspect:

i) Vagal stimulation activates the cholinergic fibres to the SAN and leads to a decreased slope of phase 4. This occurs by depolarizing effect of funny Na+ (If) channel on M2 receptor stimulation. There is also decreased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) causing the decreased firing of the T-type Ca2+ channel. Similar action is seen upon administering digitalis. 

ii) The frequency of SA node discharge is increased when the temperature rises. Thus, fever is usually associated with tachycardia.

questions.text: All of the following are features of the secondary stage of lymphogranuloma venereum except:
questions.solution:
All of the above features are associated with the secondary stage of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) except esthiomene of the vulva. It is observed in the tertiary stage of the disease.

Lymphogranuloma venereum is a sexually transmitted disease caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis.

It occurs in three stages. The primary stage is observed about 3-30 days after infection and the lesion is a single, non indurated, shallow ulcer or pustule or papule that may be painless. It heals rapidly without any scar formation.

This is followed by a secondary stage that occurs about 2-6 weeks after the primary stage and manifests as painful lymphadenopathy that may be unilateral/bilateral and enlarged, tender, painful glands in the groin called buboes. A groove-like depression may be observed above and below the inguinal ligament due to enlargement of femoral or inguinal lymph nodes; this is called the groove sign.

A tertiary stage usually follows chronic untreated infection. It is associated with stricture formation and fibrosis and fistulae of the anogenital region. Chronic disfiguring granulomatous fibrosis and scarring of the vulva with esthiomene formation are also observed in this stage. 

Esthiomene or elephantiasis of the genitals refers to the hypertrophic enlargement, chronic ulceration and scarring of external genitalia. The given image shows esthiomene, a feature of lymphogranuloma venereum.  

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline
