Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with sudden-onset loose stools, vomiting, and muscular cramps. Stools were colorless, like rice water, and had an inoffensive sweetish odor. Damage to which of the following structures is likely to have resulted in diarrhea?
questions.solution:
This patient with sudden onset of loose, colorless, rice water stools with a sweetish odor, vomiting, and muscle cramps is likely to have cholera, with damage to zonula occludens (tight junction).

Zonula occludens toxin (Zot) is produced by Vibrio cholerae and has the ability to increase mucosal permeability by reversibly affecting the structure of tight junctions.

The mechanism of action of cholera toxin is given below:

  • The cholera toxin molecule consists of A and B subunits. The B (binding) units attach to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. The A (active) subunit is the active part.
  • A subunit causes activation of cellular adenylate cyclase and accumulation of cAMP, which causes secretions of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the small intestinal lumen. This leads to watery diarrhea, which is isotonic with plasma but contains much more potassium and bicarbonate.

The toxin also inhibits the intestinal absorption of sodium and chloride. All clinical manifestations and complications in cholera result from the ensuing massive water and electrolyte depletion.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is not seen in Behcet's disease?
questions.solution:
Myocarditis is not seen in Behcet’s disease.

Behcet’s syndrome is characterized by:

  1. Erythema nodosum
  2. Athralgia/arthritis
  3. Oral and genital ulcers

Diagnostic criteria: Recurrent oral ulcerations plus two of the following is required:

  • Recurrent genital ulcerations 
  • Eye lesions which include anterior and posterior uveitis
  • Skin lesions which include erythema nodosum, papulopustular nodules and pseudofolliculitis.
  • Positive Pathergy test: it is an inflammatory skin reaction that occurs due to scratching or injection of normal saline in patients with Behcet's syndrome

questions.text: You are attending to a patient who is in labor. You can see the biparietal diameter of the fetal head stretching the vulval outlet. As the contraction gets over, the head remains in that position without recessing back. What do you expect to happen next?
questions.solution:
The biparietal diameter of the fetal head (maximum diameter of the head) stretching the vulval outlet and not recessing after the end of contraction is known as crowning. Extension is expected to happen next.

The mechanism of labor refers to the positional changes of the presenting part required for the fetus to travel through the pelvic canal during labor.

In normal labor, the most common presentation is cephalic and the presenting part is the vertex. The vertex enters the pelvis with the sagittal suture in the transverse pelvic diameter. The fetus generally enters the pelvis in the left occipitotransverse position.

The specific cardinal movements of labor are:

  • Engagement is the mechanism by which the biparietal diameter (in occiput presentation) passes through the pelvic inlet.
  • Descent is a continuous process that is completed with the expulsion of the fetus.
  • Flexion of the head occurs as soon as the descending head meets resistance from the pelvic floor/pelvic walls/cervix. With this movement, the chin is drawn closer to the fetal thorax, and the appreciably shorter suboccipitobregmatic diameter replaces the longer occipitofrontal diameter
  • Internal rotation is the mechanism by which the occiput gradually turns away from the transverse axis. Crowning occurs after internal rotation when the vulval outlet is stretched by the maximum diameter of the head and there is non-recession of the head after the contraction is over.
  • Extension- with progressive distension of the perineum, the head extends out in order as occiput, anterior fontanelle, brow, nose, mouth, and chin.
  • External rotation/restitution is the visible passive movement of the delivered head by which it untwists its neck and regains a transverse position.
  • Expulsion is the process by which the anterior shoulder is followed by the posterior shoulder and the rest of the fetal body is delivered.

The below image shows the cardinal movements of labor.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient is set to undergo a daycare procedure. Which of the following drugs should be avoided for the said procedure?
questions.solution:
Morphine would be avoided for the daycare procedure as it increases the risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting.

Morphine is a long-acting opioid and since opioids increase the risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), it should be avoided in daycare surgery. Instead, analgesics like paracetamol and other NSAIDs are preferred to manage pain in daycare procedures. 

Day surgery involves a patient being admitted and discharged for a specific procedure within a 12-hour working day. Each component of the pathway has to be safe and efficient and to be performed in sequence. This is ensured by the following measures:

  • the patient is informed and fit for the procedure
  • the procedure itself is achievable as a day case
  • the procedure is scheduled early on the operating list to allow safe recovery and discharge
  • the home environment can support a postoperative ambulatory patient.

The IV anaesthetic of choice for daycare surgery is propofol (Option A) due to its smooth induction and rapid recovery. The antiemetic action is also beneficial. Thiopental results in prolonged postoperative sedation and is not preferred in ambulatory anaesthesia, also benzodiazepines and ketamine are avoided for similar reasons.

The inhalational anaesthetic of choice for daycare surgery is sevoflurane (Option C). The low blood-gas partition coefficient, blood-brain coefficient, and minimal airway irritation of sevoflurane promote rapid induction and rapid recovery.

Sugammadex (Option D) produces a rapid and complete reversal of neuromuscular blockade produced by rocuronium or vecuronium.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Opioids

  • Post thoracotomy pain managed by: IV fentanyl
  • Drug of choice for controlling severe pain in cancer patients: Morphine
  • Drug of choice for OPD analgesia: Alfentanyl
  • Most potent: sufentanyl
  • Shortest acting opioid-remifentanyl

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker patient is brought to the hospital due to pain and weakness in the left arm for the past week. He also complains of left-sided chest pain for the last 3 weeks along with malaise, fever and weight loss for the past month. Which of the following tests is more preferred to point to the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical features of left-sided chest pain, fever, weight loss, and malaise combined with pain and weakness of the left arm are suggestive of a Pancoast tumor. Chest CT is more preferred along with PET scan. MRI can be supplemented to aid the diagnosis.

Pancoast syndrome/superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots.

It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs. Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or postobstructive pneumonitis.

Regional spread of the tumor can cause:

  • Tracheal obstruction,
  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis).

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to your clinic complaining of progressive hearing loss in the left ear for 8 months. She says that she hears conversations better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. Her audiometry report is given below. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of progressive hearing loss and paracusis willisii, along with Carhart's notch seen in the audiogram, is suggestive of otosclerosis.

Paracusis willisii is hearing voices better in noisy than in quiet surroundings.

Interpretation of the given audiogram:

  • The blue color indicates the left ear.
  • × indicates air conduction [AC] and the threshold is >15 dB hence AC is abnormal. So it indicates conductive deafness.
  • ] indicates bone conduction [BC] and the threshold is <25dB. A characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz called Carhart's notch is seen.
  • The air-bone gap is a feature of conductive hearing loss.
  • Hence, left-sided otosclerosis is the diagnosis

Otosclerosis is the disease of the bony labyrinth in which a normal dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by irregularly laid spongy bone. It has a positive family history with an autosomal dominant trait. It is more commonly seen in females between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy and menopause. It may be associated with osteogenesis imperfecta and a viral infection like measles. 

Stapedial otosclerosis is the most common type of otosclerosis. Here the lesion starts just in front of the oval window in an area called fissula ante fenestram.

On examination, Schwartz sign/flamingo flush showing a red blush of the tympanic membrane due to vascularity can be seen.

The image given below shows otoscopic findings of otosclerosis showing Schwartz's sign:

 

Treatment includes medical, surgical management, and hearing aids. Medical management with sodium fluoride is used in the active stage to speed up the maturity of the active focus and halt further cochlear loss. The treatment of choice is the surgical management that includes stapedotomy/stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis. Hearing aids are used in patients who refuse or are unfit for the surgery.

Other options:

Option A: Cholesteatomas are abnormal collections of keratinized squamous epithelium, usually in the middle ear and mastoid. It presents with conductive hearing loss and otorrhea. On otoscopy, it shows the presence of a large mass of white keratin debris.

The image given below shows the otoscopic findings seen in cholesteatoma:

 

Option B: Meniere's disease (endolymphatic hydrops) is an inner ear disorder where the endolymph distends the endolymphatic system. The disease is usually unilateral. It is characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sense of ear fullness. Pure tone audiometry reveals a sensorineural type of hearing loss with lower frequencies affected first. It shows a rising type of curve.

The below image shows PTA depicting the rising curve seen in the early stages of Meniere's disease:

 

Option D: Glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear that arises from the glomus bodies. When the tumour is intratympanic, the hearing loss is a conductive type and pulsatile tinnitus that is synchronous with the carotid pulse is heard. On otoscopic examination, a red reflex through the tympanic membrane is seen. This is known as the rising sun appearance which occurs when the tumour arises from the floor of the middle ear.

The image given below shows otoscopic findings seen in glomus tumor:

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

 

Related Pearl: Meniere’s disease vs. Otosclerosis

Meniere’s Disease

Otosclerosis

Middle age (M>F)

Middle age (F>>M)

Unilateral

Bilateral

Sensory neural hearing loss

Conductive Hearing loss

Cochlear pathology (endolymphatic system)

questions.text: A forensic expert is assisting the police in investigating the death of a woman. On examination, he notices the Kevorkian sign. What is the estimated time since the death?
questions.solution:
The Kevorkian sign is a postmortem change that occurs in the retinal vessels. It lasts for about 1 hour.

It is characterized by fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels. It appears within minutes after death and lasts for about 1 hour. It can be visualized by using an ophthalmoscope as shown below.

Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:

  • Cornea - dull, hazy, opaque, wrinkled
  • Flaccidity of eyeballs occurs due to falling in intraocular pressure. IOP reaches zero at the end of 2 hours after death
  • Tache Noir: A film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera on either side of the cornea, with base towards the margin of cornea and apex towards medial or lateral canthus of the eye. It appears within 3-4 hours of death
  • Increase in potassium concentration in vitreous - linear increase up to 100 hours following death. It is helpful in determining the time since death

questions.text: A man presents with pain in the ear. Otoscopy shows pearly white debris. A diagnosis of keratosis obturans is made. This condition occurs due to:
questions.solution:
Keratosis obturans occurs due to desquamated epithelial cells.

It is usually seen between the ages of 5-20 years and is commonly unilateral. Clinical features include severe otalgia and difficulty in hearing. It is associated with systemic conditions like bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis. 

On otoscopic examination, there is a thickening of the tympanic membrane and a keratin plug appearing like a pearly white mass occluding the canal. The keratin that is shed from the entire circumference of the deep ear canal appears to have an onion skin arrangement. There is also hyperemia of canal skin, sometimes with ulcerations and granulations. 

Sometimes, the extent of bone absorption is such that it leaves the facial nerve exposed to injury and subsequent paralysis. Extensive erosion of the bone can also result in automastoidectomy.

Treatment involves the removal of the plug by syringing or instrumentation. Any recurrence can be prevented with the use of keratolytic such as 2% salicylic acid.

questions.text: A patient presents with right lower abdominal pain and loose stools for the past 8 months. He smokes 12 cigarettes per day for the last 10 years. Endoscopy findings are shown below. Smoking increases the relative risk of which among the following?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of loose stools, right lower quadrant pain and endoscopy showing cobblestone appearance, with a history of smoking suggest a diagnosis of Crohn's disease (CD) and smoking increases the relative risk of Crohn's disease.

The risk is increased threefold times with smoking. The cessation of smoking has a beneficial effect on the disease activity. 

Features include

  • Non-caseating granulomas on the layers of the small bowel, lymph nodes, mesentery, peritoneum, liver, and pancreas.
  • Submucosal or subserosal lymphoid aggregates, microscopic skip areas, transmural inflammation, etc are also seen.
  • Inflammation of the ileum and colon, with rectal sparing.
  • Aphthous ulcers in early stages and later spreads to result in transmural inflammation.
  • Skip lesions are seen in microscopy. There is normal mucosa in between the ulcers which gives them a cobblestone appearance.
  • Creeping fat is the growth of mesenteric fat leading to extensive fat wrapping around the bowel wall.

In ulcerative colitis, smoking has a protective effect (option A).

questions.text: Two brothers presented with bilateral painless progressive visual loss. After a thorough examination and investigation, the diagnosis of a rare inherited disease was made. The pedigree chart shown in the image below was drawn to explain which family members may be affected (colored red). Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows mitochondrial inheritance, and the condition showing this pattern of inheritance is Leber optic neuropathy.

The mitochondrial pattern of inheritance is when the mother is affected and the father is normal, which leads to all their children (both male and female) being affected. However, children born to an affected father and a normal mother will not be affected.

The unique feature of mitochondrial inheritance is maternal inheritance, as the disease is transmitted through the affected mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which is derived from the maternal mitochondria. The ovum contains several mitochondria, while the spermatozoa have very few mitochondria, if present. Hence, the mitochondrial DNA of the zygote is entirely derived from the ovum.

Therefore, while the affected mother transmits the disease to all the offspring (both male and female), only the daughters of the affected mother can further transmit the disease.

 

Characteristic features of mitochondrial inheritance are as follows:

The mitochondrial DNA encodes enzymes required for oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, organs that are most dependent on oxidative phosphorylation are the ones most affected in diseases due to mutations in mtDNA. These organs include the central nervous system, skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, liver, and kidneys.

There are several thousands of copies of mtDNA in each mitochondrion, of which only a few copies are affected in case of mutation. Therefore, a diseased individual possesses copies of both wild-type mtDNA and mutant mtDNA in each mitochondrion. This phenomenon is called heteroplasmy. 

The disease manifests if a minimum number of copies of mutant mtDNA are present in the mitochondria, which can lead to oxidative dysfunction; this phenomenon is called the threshold effect. In most cases, this threshold effect is reached in the organs as mentioned above.

Also, during cell division, the wild and mutant copies of the mtDNA are unequally distributed among the daughter cells. As a result, the expression of the disease varies even among different cells of an organ.

Other options:

Option A: Ocular albinism is inherited as X-linked recessive or autosomal recessive disease.

Option B: Retinitis pigmentosa may be inherited as autosomal dominant, recessive, or X-linked based on the involved genes.

Option C: Leber congenital amaurosis is inherited as an autosomal recessive inheritance.

Related Pearl: Diseases of mitochondrial inheritance

  • Caused by mutations of the mitochondrial genome
  • Inherited exclusively from the affected mother
  • These diseases include: (mnemonic: KLMNOP)
